title: brexit deal theresa may opinion james forsyth
story: That evening, MPs will vote on a series of Brexit amendments designed to show the EU what kind of withdrawal agreement the Commons would accept. At least one of them needs to pass.If one does get the support of a majority of MPs, then Theresa May can go back to Brussels and say, look, this is what will get the deal through my parliament.It will strengthen her negotiating hand, make the EU engage and give her a chance of securing some changes.As one secretary of state says: “She needs to demonstrate she can carry something through.”No insiders tell me that May will only go back to Brussels “when we have a very clear set of proposals”. Butnone of these amendments can muster a majority, then the EU will just sit tight.It knows this parliament is fiercely opposed to No Deal and so isn’t concerned that the UK will actually go down that route.Instead, the EU will wait, confident that the UK will request either an extension to the Brexit process or a softening of it.So far, there are a iety of amendments down. One from the shop steward of backbench Tory MPs, Graham Brady, says the Commons will support the withdrawal agreementthe backstop is replaced by “alternative arrangements” to prevent a hard border in Ireland.Another from the Tory chairman of the Northern Ireland Select Committee, Andrew ­Murrison, seeks to time-limit the backstop. Influential cabinet ministers have also been pushing for the Government to put down its own amendment.They are confident that they are winning that argument and one will go down before Tuesday — though some in Number  still prefer to put their faith in the Murrison amendment.The signicance of a Government amendment would be that Speaker John Bercow would have no choice but to call it. One indispensable minister involved in these discussions tells me: “A Government amendment could well be a more objective exit mechanism which would allow us to ­demonstrate that this is not going to be permanent.”The outline of this amendment has, I understand, been discussed with the DUP and ministers believe that the “likelihood” is that they will support it. But one cautions that “what may seem a given one day can suddenly unravel”.No won’t be drawn on whether a Government amendment will be tabled or not. But leading cabinet ministers are confident it will be. One says: “This is the best chance of moving everyone forward together.”One option being discussed is for a series of clear tests which,met, would allow the UK to exit the backstop. The aim is to make it clear that the EU couldn’t keep the UK — or Northern Ireland — in the backstop forever.There is also, I understand, “a parallel conversation” going on about what the EU will accept in terms of changes to the backstop. If a Government-backed amendment passed the Common it would also, in the words of one source, give the Government “half a chance of stopping Cooper-Boles”.The amendment from Labour’s Yvette ­Cooper and former Tory minister Nick Boles would require the Government to ask for an extension to Article  to avoid No Dealthe UK and the EU can’t come to an agreement.As this source points out: “Cooper-Boles does best when people think there isn’t an alternative.” There is no guarantee that a Government amendment will carry the day.“To pull this off, you need the ERGto come in behind it — and that’s quite a big ask,” says one of those intimately involved in these discussions.This source warns that “emotionally a lot of them will find it very dficult”. But these Brexiteer MPs need to realise thatnothing passes on Tuesday, then parliamentary efforts to extend Article  will gather more support.Brexit itself will be in danger and this country will end up with a super soft Andrex Brexit — or no Brexit at all.MPs should not do anything to suggest that they want to take No Deal off the table. This week, the EU and the Irish government have been all over the place about what No Deal would mean for the Irish border.The contradiction at the heart of the backstop is beginning to become apparent. It is, the EU and ­Ireland say, necessary to prevent a hard border. Butthe backstop results in there being No Deal, then it will lead to precisely what it is meant to avoid: A hard border.As this inconsistency becomes more and more obvious, there is more chance of member states pressing the EU to move on this issue.One minister who has been talking to his ­counterparts across the EU in the last few days tells me: “They’re ­definitely budging.”So, this would be precisely the wrong moment for MPs to undermine May’s negotiating position by talking about taking No Deal off the table. As one of those close to the PM puts it: “This has been a dficult week for the EU. Don’t make it easy for them.”This is one of the reasons why MPs MUST REJECT the Yvette Cooper amendment. At the moment, this amendment looks like it will probably pass. But given how many Labour MPs in leave-voting seats have qualms about it, this is far from certain.Tory MPs, let alone ministers, shouldn’t help it through as doing so would pull the rug from under the UK’s negotiating position.VENEZUELA is a sorry tale of where state socialism leads. In an oil-rich country, people are starving. It is embarrassing, and shaming, that Jeremy Corbyn’s ideological blinders mean that he can’t see what is happening there.Labour talk about opposing “outside interference” in Venezuela even as a slew of democracies in the region recognise the head of the national assembly, Juan Guaido, as the legitimate president.Labour’s opposition to outside interference puts them in the same position as Russia, China, Turkey, Bolivia and Cuba. This is the company we’d be keepingCorbyn became Prime Minister.AT Cabinet this week, Theresa May told ministers that to get the deal through she would have to go to the Commons and “present a changed backstop”.This is signicant because it is her recognising that she needs substantive – not just cosmetic – changes to the backstopshe is to get her deal through.TALK of an early election just won’t go away at Westminster. It is not that the Tories want one, but that there is a sense that the Commons is so deadlocked on Brexit that it might end up as the only option.One possible route to an election is that Yvette Cooper’s plan to extend Article  passes the Commons, a deal is then eventually agreed but can only pass with the rider that there is a second referendum. I understand that, in these circumstances, the Government would rather go for an early election.One senior Cabinet Minister says that Theresa May’s “reddest of red lines is we have to leave the EU”. A ­referendum with Remain on the ballot paper would threaten that.“Political parties ought to make sure they are ready to fight an ­election”, a member of the Tory party board tells me as he explains why they are rapidly stepping up candidate selection and the like. But I am told that “no one is planning an election”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chavez socialist experiment venezuela opinion
story: GDP growth will stall. Taxes will rise. We’ll even run out of Mars bars.But across the Atlantic, something has been ­happening that should give us all some perspective.Over the past decade, Venezuela has plunged into the abyss — but there’s been no civil war, no earthquakes or hurricanes.Just a brutal, corrupt government that has turned what was once Latin America’s richest country into a hellhole.Starvation rations plunged millions into hunger and ­malnutrition, with some resorting to eating dogs, cats, even zoo animals.People got into kne fights over the right to scavenge from a dumpster.Its economy is more than three times smaller than in . Inflation climbed into the thousands, then millions of per cent.The result has been a refugee crisis on the scale of the Syria conflict.No wonder tens of ­thousands of people took to the streets of the capital Caracas this week, declaring national assembly head Juan Guaido the legitimate president.All this is awful for the poor bloody Venezuelans.But what does it have to do with Britain The answer is that Venezuela wasn’t just a ­disaster. It was an experiment — cheered on by Jeremy Corbyn and his cronies.In , Hugo Chavez took over Venezuela.He ruled until his death in , when he was succeeded by his hand-picked protege Nicolas Maduro.Chavez modelled himself on Latin American ­revolutionaries like Fidel Castro and Simon Boli. He nationalised much of the oil industry — which dominates the ­Venezuelan economy — and imposed punitive taxes on foreign firms.He introduced price controls and later currency controls. He declared “economic war” on the “stateless ­bourgeoisie” and seized the goods of private companies he denounced as saboteurs.For Corbyn, the Chavez regime was an inspiration — a chance to see true socialism brought to le.Venezuela, Corbyn has said, “showed us that there is a dferent, and a better, way of doing things. It’s called socialism”.It wasn’t just Corbyn. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell, Shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott and Corbyn’s media chief Seumas Milne have all praised the ­Venezuelan revolution.That “better way of doing things” has ruined tens of millions of lives but there has not been a hint of an apology from Corbyn.Normally, the fact that people are taking to the streets to free themselves of a vicious regime would be cheered to the rafters by the Left.Instead, there is the silence of those who find themselves ­hideously embarrassed.The few who are not ­staring at their shoes claim that Venezuela has been the ­victim of an American plot.That Maduro took, in McDonnell’s words, a “wrong turn” from Chavez’s true socialism.That it was all down to a falling oil price.Yes, Maduro took a wrong turn. But that turn was to follow the path laid out by Chavez.From the Soviet Union to Cuba to Venezuela, there is a long and shabby history of British left-wingers acclaiming a workers’ paradise — only to declare, once its ­failure is clear, that it wasn’t really socialist after all.Never mind the millions of lives ruined — let’s have another go!If he became Prime ­Minister, Corbyn might not succeed in turning Britain into Venezuela. But we’d be Caracas to let him try.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: remain wreckers should listen to queen
story: Her Majesty is right that MPs must find the common ground. But whatever compromises are made on the finer details, that “common ground” must at its core deliver on . million votes to leave the EU, and the promises made in both Tory and Labour manestos at the last election.Those trying to derail Brexit are the ones who are, as Her Majesty puts it, “losing sight of the bigger picture”. After all, it is they who are willing to rip up centuries of democratic understanding and procedure to keep us locked within the European Union.So terried of Britain flourishing, free from Brussels’ dead hand, that they will happily destroy public trust in Parliament in order to succeed.We wish they shared Her Majesty’s obvious confidence in her country.As MPsto their constituencies this weekend, they will hear the same thing over and over again: deliver what we voted for.Those still hoping to delay Article  or even for a second referendum MUST realise the stakes.MARCH th should be a momentous day, our first outside the European Union. And it should also be the day the Prime Minister fires her hapless Chancellor Philip Hammond.Free to set our own course again, we can create the world’s most competitive economy — with lower taxes and business-friendly regulation that allows our brightest companies to prosper here and across the world.Our Eeyore Chancellor is about as far away from the dynamism we need as it is possible to imagine. At a time when we need to put energy into the economy, Hammond is human chloroform.And that’s before we get on to his outrageous disloyalty in Davos this week.The clock is ticking.JUST as most serious European leaders are thinking of creative ways to stay close to the UK after we leave, Leo Varadkar and Emmanuel Macron show just how hopeless they both are.That France’s Macron — a Poundshop Napoleon without the self-doubt — dares to lecture us when he’s got riots on the streets and approval ratings to match his stature really is quite something.Meanwhile Ireland’s Leo, who never knowingly turns down the opportunity to insert his foot squarely into his mouth, threatened that he would send the Army to the border yesterday before being forced into a screeching U-turn.And they say we’re the problem…Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady influencers dont see kids friends cash
story: Weirdly, for those of us who grew up before the internet took off, that’s an actual job now.And who can blame people for ­saying: “‘Yes please” to money for doing not very much But there is something wrongInstagram users aren’t aware the ­celebrities they follow are being paid thousands of pounds — or even hundreds of thousands — to promote the products they are “recommending”.Advertisers know Instagram — which has a BILLION monthly users posting some million photos a day — is an incredibly powerful way of reaching young people.The more followers a star has, the greater their selling power.Kylie Jenner, who has million ­followers, is paid a whopping £, for every sponsored post.Under the  UK Consumer Protection From Unfair Trading regulations, ­celebrities paid to plug products are supposed to make that clear.But there are no simple guidelines.So while some celebs might say “sponsored” or “#ad” on a post, others are less open about it.That is why the Competition  ­Markets Authority conducted an ­investigation.And this week  British celebrities and “influencers” were found to have failed to follow consumer protection guidelines.They include singers Rita Ora and Ellie Goulding, models Alexa Chung and Rosie Huntington-Whiteley and video blogger Zoella.While all agreed to change their ways, none was taken to court where they might have faced fines or even jail time.“Influencers” might say the clue is in the name. They are paid to inspire you to buy stuff.Most insist they only endorse ­products they actually believe in — and we’d all hope they take their responsibility seriously.But it is easy to see how an offer of, say, £, to endorse something they “sort of” believe in might make it harder to hang on to those principles.Equally,guidelines aren’t strictly enforced, you can understand the temptation to convey the impression that you just happen to really like a particular laxative herbal tea, say, or a moisturiser that gives you a “glow”.It’s a grey area. And you might ask why it matters.But given recent news about the ­negative impact social media can have on the mental health of young people — and young women in particular — regulation of this brave new world affects us all.I need only point to another big story this week.Schoolgirl Molly Russell was  when she took her own le after showing “no obvious signs” of severe mental health issues.Her family later found she had been viewing material on social media linked to anxiety, depression, self-harm and suicide.Her father even went as far as accusing Instagram of “helping to kill her”.Social media makes it so easy to tap into someone’s daily le, their home-decor proclivities and their innermost thoughts.The intimate nature of Instagram lets you feel like these influencers are your friends, and the products they rave about their personal ­recommendations, not the outcome of a business deal.This is a real problem. But the mistake is much harder to makeadverts are clearly labelled as such.Part of the problem is how obsessed with celebrities our young people have become.When I was growing up, my main influenceswere my parents and my friends.Now, young people are influenced by people they will never meet.Some of these people, dare I say it, are talentless nobodies.You might argue you would have to be naive not to realise they are selling you something.Perhaps young people are not as cynical as the likes of me.And that is why regulation is key.IT’S hard to sympathise with Fungi, a “star” of hit telly documentary Benefits Street, who says universal credit is “the worst thing in the world”.Tracked down by this paper, James Clarkeclaimed his monthly payments had been more than halved and the all-in-one benefit was causing “hell” for him and others like him . . . because their booze budget has been cut.Fungi was claiming £ a month to spend on food and sundries. But this was slashed to £ – which doesn’t cover the £ a month he and his partner spend on strong cider.His rent, meanwhile, is paid in full via a separate taxpayer-funded handout.Fungi also says his drinking habit means he can’t work. Sorry, what Here’s another way of looking at it. People who work for eight hours a day don’t have the time to down three litres of cider a day.If Mr Clarke got a job, he might recover some of his self-esteem – and probably save his le in the process.Just to be clear – I BELIEVE in the benefits system.But it was invented to help people get back on their feet, to help those who can’t help themselves because of illness or disability.It should be a short-term measure, not a lestyle choice.In the meantime, the rest of us go to work to pay for this man’s rent and booze.All because he can’t be bothered to sort himself out.No wonder people get angry.In fact, I suspect most readers will have steam coming out of their ears.This man must start taking responsibility for himself.I SUPPOSE it was worth a shot for Diane Abbott to complain that Fiona Bruce was “badly briefed” and that her treatment as a list on Question Time was racist.But she can’t blame Fiona for her own incompetence in answering questions – and not just on Question Time.There are so many car-crash interviews to choose from . . . although the one in which Diane suggested police officers could be paid £ a year springs to mind.WHAT a nasty piece of work Dancing On Ice judge Jason Gardiner seems.We expect the judges to give feedback.And we know it won’t all be good.But his comment to Gemma Collins last week – “We are not going to see big lts from you” – came across as body-shaming.Because his real point is that she is overweight, right It’s shocking, really. I’m surprised ITV allowed it.THE secret behind Elle Macpherson’s phenomenal bod has been revealed.In an interview, she said it all comes down to . . . late breakfasts.Hmmm. No matter when we eat breakfast, most of us will never come close to looking how she does at .Actually, forget breakfast times. What struck me is her diet seems to contain just FIVE ingredients . . . one of which is nut cheese.And the only liquid is water.Elle looks great.But by God, she must be miserable.THE Premier League’s popularity continues to soar, as a study into attendances across Europe proves.And I was immensely proud to see West Ham ranked seventh by attendance in all of Europe last year.We are up there with the Continent’s elite, in a table headed by Barcelona.And that will only get better now the capacity of the London Stadium is up to , – adding to the incredible support we get from what I believe are the league’s best fans.This week, accountancy firm EY published a report on the impact the Premier League has on our economy.It generates £.billion a year in tax for the Exchequer, supporting , jobs and contributing £.billion overall to the country’s GDP.Last season, Premier League players paid more than £billion in taxes.But never mind the money.It’s still the best league in the world.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no delaying halting brexit john mann
story: Across the country people who voted dferent ways in the Brexit referendum are ­becoming bored and irritated by the silly games at Westminster.The truth is that a large majority of MPs are Remainers in their hearts and souls and are struggling to bring themselves to recognise the reality of the situation.It was us MPs who voted to give you, the people, the say on leaving or remaining in the European Union.And you voted, in higher numbers than you have ever bothered voting for any of us. Yet the same MPs who gave you a say are coming up with every excuse for why your views should not be listened to.Of course there are Remainer MPs whose constituencies voted heavily to remain.There are MPs with, I have to say it, courage, who have always argued strongly in a way that they have always known is dferent to their ­voters. These people are ­consistent and have my respect.But there are just as many who are in danger now of sitting on the fence until rigor mortis sets in, coming up with process rather than substance.They are simply hoping that others will do the dirty deed and respect the will of the people.It is also, for every Labour and Conservative MP, the manesto ­promise that we stood on at the last election. We voted for a referendum. We promised to respect the result.We got re-elected promising the same, yet Parliament continues to sit on the roundabout to nowhere.It is time to stop the shenanigans and work across the political ide to bring our country and our people together.At stake is our democracy. And in a democracy the winner prevails.Of course, in future years, people can argue that we have got it wrong and that people are entitled to change their mind. But for democracy to be true and real, we have to deliver the mandate we have been given and leave the EU on March .The referendum ided people and families, with lots of strong and dfering views. But in cherishing our democracy, we now need to come together to deliver a Brexit that respects the people’s vote and helps heal that ide.In le we have to compromise. We all have our own perfect Brexit, me included. And with ten of my colleagues we have forced through a big part of that, guaranteeing in law workers’ rights, health and safety and environmental standards. We will be competing with Europe by being the best, not by being the cheapest.I would love to have been a fly on the wall when Theresa May told union bosses that she was meeting their key demands not just with a promise but with a legal guarantee. But then she knew it was only right, because union members were the bedrock of leave voters across the country.And, I believe, we can get more in the next fortnight. A clear commitment to a once-in-a-generation investment into the Leave-voting areas that have long been starved of our fair shares — those former coal, iron and steel industrial heartlands, the unfashionable places, the areas still manufacturing. I think, as well, that union bosses and industrialists can be brought to act as advisers to the trade negotiations when we have left the EU, bringing their expertise into play to ensure a jobs-first Brexit for Britain.A country, proud and independent, standing on its own two feet, ­confident again in our democracy, bold enough to compete by being the best, British workers making high- quality products and delivering high-quality services.A country that says it will be the best by having better pay, conditions and a healthier environment than anyone  in Europe or worldwide.Is that not something to be confident in voting for, my fellow MPs  Let’s get on with it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cult of brexit remainer fading
story: I will try, but it is hard to see eye to eye with those who regard the .million who voted Out in  as pig- ignorant racists.Or to forgive Chancellor Phil Hammond for twisting Treasury data to undermine the British economy.I will simply wish him well in retirement at the earliest possible moment.Anna Soubry is a bit of a challenge too, but I will ­eventually find something nice to say.As for EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier, even Her ­Eurosceptic Majesty would find little common ground with the man who vowed to punish her United Kingdom for daring to leave.But it will be cult-like Remainers who find it hardest to kiss and make up.Their hatred of Leavers has reached sectarian proportions.Astonishingly a poll found many would ban marriage outside the EU faith.Indeed, my old friendMatthew Parris insists Her Maj was wrong to suggest there is any common ground at all, because it might appear to endorse Theresa May’s dodgy deal.The Times sage has abandoned the Zen-like equilibrium which once made him ­compulsive reading. Along with the likes of megabucks Remainers Tony Blair, Peter Mandelson and PR guru Roland Rudd, he seems to think Brexiters are basically pond le.That theory should be buried forever after this weekend’s passionate plea from leading academic Sir Noel Malcolm for MPs to stop wrecking Brexit.Writing in the devoutly pro-EU Financial Times, this distinguished Fellow of All Souls, Oxford, spells out the essence of the Leave case: “Brexit is about sovereignty — and parliament must respect that.”“If the UK is now on the brink of a constitutional crisis,” he adds, “one major reason is that a signicant number of MPs still oppose any version of Brexit, and seek a second ­referendum solely for the sake of reversing the decision of the last one.”Sir Noel does not believe people voted Out because they were racist.“The most important reason was democracy,” he says.“They wanted to live under laws made by the people they elected. Immigration came second.What they objected to was a supranational government ­making some of their laws and lting all immigration controls on the inhabitants of  other countries.”Another Remainer fiction is that Brexiters are narrow-minded Little Englanders.Yet the Daily Mail found space for a German view that Brussels should stop “insulting Britain” and honour us as champions of peace in Europe.“Such blinkered and sour responses are wrong-headed,” says Alexander von Schoenburg, a senior editor of Germany’s biggest newspaper, Bild.“They ignore the great debt Germany and the whole ­Continent owes our friends across the Channel.“We must always remember that throughout your history, independence and sovereignty have been paramount.“Germany in particular should tread lightly when it comes to dealing with your proud nation. It was Great Britain that first stood up to Hitler in .And it was Britain that opened its doors to thousands of ­Jewish refugees fleeing certain death during the Holocaust.“Put simply, there would be no free Europe without you and the bloody sacrice you made to rescue the Continent.”This remarkable tribute ­follows a recent love letter to the UK from Germany’s next Chancellor calling for a friendly Brexit orce and an end to bitterness.It is now clear hardline Remainers have over-reached themselves. The worm has turned.Talk of a second referendum is dead and voters are on the warpath against MPs plotting to scupper Brexit in tomorrow’s Commons showdown.Brussels is in chaos over the Northern Ireland backstop.Michel Barnier has started muttering about new tech- nology to police post-Brexit ­frontiers — a UK idea initially dismissed as “magical thinking”.EU allies are breaking ranks to demand a decent deal — for their sake as much as ours.It is way past time now for Theresa May to scrap the backstop and tell Brussels exactly what she needs to get her deal through Parliament.“There is absolutely no truth in speculation that ­passengers are being advised not to book,” stormed Brittany Ferries as it announced plans to INCREASE services.Meanwhile, mischief-making aviation giant Airbus admits it was asked by Downing Street to warn – incredibly – that it would shut up shopBritain left without a deal.Project Fear is shameless.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk fattest ten year old 16 stone
story: The lad weighs more than  stone, three times the average for a boy of his age.However, the mum, , insists his obesity is the result of a stress hormone disorder and not of gorging on junk food.She claims he does not eat enough and has only a sandwich for lunch and dinner.She said: “He goes without meals. title: molly russell social media blame
story: Vulnerable Molly Russell faced a flood of self-harm images on Instagram and Pinterest — helping drive her to suicide.The sites haven’t done enough to stop a repeat of this tragedy.And the power of the web giants is only growing. title: beautician sneezes out ring nose 12 years
story: The stunned woman only noticed when she saw something glistening in her snot after a sneezing fit.Abigail Thompson had no idea the piece of jewellery, a gt for her eighth birthday, was up her nose the whole time.The -year-old said she noticed it had gone missing a few months later and assumed someone had taken it.She said: “I never ever in a million years would have guessed it had got stuck up my nose.”“I always had a few friends over, we always would sit on my bed and she thought one of them must have just taken it when they were over at my house.“Mum thought one of them must have stolen it.“There was no other explanation as to where it could have gone.”Abigail, of Keighley, West Yorks, said she was shocked when she saw the silver ring fly out of her conk after a particularly bad sneezing fit.She said: “Well it was just a normal day, I was sat on my sofa and I started sneezing loads and then I looked in the tissue and I was like ‘What the hell is that ’“I felt a sharp feeling but I didn’t think of it until I looked in the tissue.“Then I looked at it and I went: ‘Oh My God, that’s the ring!’”“My mum was so shocked, I called her straight away when it happened.“I said ‘You’ll never guess what ’ and she said: ‘Oh my God, never’.”After speaking with her mum, Abigail came to the conclusion that the ring must have got stuck up there when her younger self picked her nose.She said: “Maybe I was picking my nose and it got washed back up there. There’s no other explanation.”“I never had a clue that it was up there. I never felt it.“I had no problems with breathing growing up, nothing has changed since it has come out either.”Having been hidden away for more than a decade the ring is still in decent condition.She said: “It’s gone very rusty but the diamond is still in it.“You can’t see it because of where it has rusted over.”Dr Naveen Cavale, the Consultant Plastic Surgeon at Real Plastic Surgery, said that incidents like this are quite common.He said: “It doesn’t surprise me, it is an unusual story, but kids have beads and toys stuck up their nose all the time.“It is possible that it was just wedged in and as she has grown up, the space in which it was wedged in would have got bigger and it was able to riggle loose and come out.It has probably being wedged at the back of the nose between two hard boney bits and they kept it in place.“You don’t often feel these things stuck at the back as a lot of the parts of the nose to the back, dont have sensation.

title: madeleine mccann parents kate gerry hope twins birthday
story: As the th anniversary of their daughters disappearance approaches, a Facebook page endorsed by Kate and Gerry McCann revealed a heartfelt message.Sharing a poignant image used four years ago, the statement reads: Thank you for keeping hope alive.The haunting graphic features an angel-like figure with long blonde hair and face obscured, holding a heart in the palm of her right hand.The tender words “Becauseyou keep hope alive, it will keep you alive” accompany the “journey to peace” image.It has been posted on the Find Madeleine campaign website, run by a close pal of the McCanns.Madeleines twin brother and sister Sean and Amelie, who are both aspiring amateur athletes, will have one special wish as they turn  on Friday - for their sister to come home.A family friend said: “The twins have spent so much of their lives without their big sister but they never forget her and they pray for her. They just want her to be found safe and well after such a long time.Three-year-old Madeleine vanished from a Portuguese holiday apartment in Praia da Luz nearly  years ago.She had been left alone sleeping with the twins while her parents were dining with pals in a nearby tapas restaurant. She would now be .Earlier this month heart doctor Gerry and former GP Kate, both , of Rothley, Leics, welcomed “such great news” that a teenage girl has been found alive nearly three months after her alleged kidnap.American school girl Jayme Closs, , had an miracle escape from a man accused of abducting her after her mum and dad were murdered.As the freed youngster was pictured smiling beside her relieved aunt the Maddie website posted: “Such great news,” adding: “Jayme is an example of why we never lose hope and never stop searching.Kate and Gerry wrote in a Christmas message: May  be a peaceful and positive one for us all. The investigation is ongoing and our hope remains.”Scotland Yard have have two more months of guaranteed funding to continue searching for Maddie. Cops are understood to be chasing two vital lines of inquiry and are “hopeful of getting a result.”Family spokesman Clarence Mitchell said the McCanns remained greatly encouraged” that police could finally be closing in on their daughter’s kidnapper.The Sun Online recently revealed that Maddie’s parents had been storing £, in a special account which they are “keeping for a rainy day.”They are planning to use the cash, being held aside in the public Find Maddie Fund, to continue searching for their daughter with private detectives,the Government’s overstretched Home Office refuse future funding.Met Police were last autumn handed their latest £, top up from the public purse - so far totalling £. million - to carry on the Maddie inquiry codenamed Operation Grange until the end of March.Detectives have refused to discuss details of the “important final lines of inquiry” they are pursuing.A Scotland Yard spokesperson said: “We cannot give a running commentary on the investigation while it is ongoing.

title: workman engulfed flames static shoe ignites lorry foam
story: The man was loading the cargo with a colleague in China when the whole lot spontaneously exploded.It is believed a tiny spark created by friction from his footwear ignited colourless but highly flammable butane gas inside the lorry’s hold.Butane is used in the production of polyethylene foam, also known as pearl cotton.Bundles of the stuff can be seen inside the lorry as the two workmen finish loading and hop down fro the pile.The second man was engulfed in a fireball but miraculously escaped with only minor burns and a whole lot of singed hair.Static electricity is created by friction between surfaces, giving rise to an imbalance of electric charge.This static can be enough to create a spark - as weve all experienced when taking off a woolly jumper.In the wrong setting, the spark can be enough to ignite a fire.Polyethylene foam packing is made by blowing butane gas through plastic.Lingering vapour from the manufacturing process is in danger of combusting explosively.In footage widely shared online, the man, only known by his surname Wei, can be seen jumping down from a bundle of the cargo and landing on the metal lorry box.A static electricity charge created by the sole of his shoe striking the metal ignites the gas in the enclosed space, engulfing him in a ball of flames from which he is luckily able to escape.The explosion is so intense it seems to light fire to a roll of the polethylene foam sitting outside the truck as well.

story: Dozens of rowdy teenagers can be seen running amok outside the fast food restaurant metres from Dagenham Tube station in East London.The blurry Snapchat video appears to show chaos reigning directly outside, with one teenager perched on a friends shoulders amid a sea of rioters.Amid cheering and jeering, a security guard is seen pointing a fire extinguisher at the crowd to stop yet more teens pouring into an unknown store.But instead of stopping the brawl, teenagers can be seen using a wet floor cone to smash a shop front as a crowd cheers them on.The video, accompanied by the comment Only in Dagenham, was taken by one of those gathered shortly before pm on Friday afternoon.Reports on social media suggested the group had congregated because of a free sandwich deal were later dismissed by Subway.Online users expressed their disgust at the horrying incident, with @kpeezyreactions commenting: “These youth man are out of control and horrible.And @fkubik said: “I want every single one of these motherf****** to get jailed for le because of causing vandalism to a shop!”A spokesperson for the politan Police said that no arrest were made and that no parties were injured following the incident.Police enquiries are ongoing.A Subway spokesperson confirmed an incident took place on Friday evening which was unconnected to the Subway store.We can categorically confirm it was not as a result of the store giving away ‘end of the line’ food, they said.In fact, a Subway staff member was injured due to the large crowd gathering and had to be taken to hospital.We want to thank the security guards from the next door shopping centre for stepping in to help disperse the crowd that had congregated, by using a fire extinguisher.We are working closely with the store owners and their employees affected to support them and to assist the police with their inquiries.

story: The daylight thief has been looting homes in the north of Albuquerque, but it is what he or she leaves behind that has baffled cops.Residents say a pile of monkey nuts was found at the scene of each crime - which they believe are used to tella home is empty or not.The peanuts have been spotted on local paths and its thought the thief may be checking to seethey have been stepped on.Now worried locals say they are all walking on shells over fears their home may be raided next, reports KOB News.Resident Joe Slanga said his neighbours property was targeted and thousands of pounds worth of jewellery was stolen after she popped out for a few hours.It was only later the pile of nuts were spotted just outside the family home in a quiet cul-de-sac in New Mexico.Slanga believes the peanuts were left behind by the burglars, so they could tellsomeone had stepped on them when leaving their house.He said hes been writing down the time, date and location of all the peanuts he finds scattered around his neighbourhood.The amateur beekeeper has now installed an alarm system hoping it will deter the crafty criminal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum left two kids car 33c heatwave new zealand
story: The youngsters were spotted by another woman who came across them in supermarket car park in the town of Napier, New Zealand.Chrystal Alatasi says as she was about to drive away she heard the sound of a baby crying coming from the Subaru car, which had tinted windows.While the temperature outside was C, experts estimate that inside a car that could climb to C.She then put her face up to the window but couldn’t see any adults so called the emergency services, Stuff.co.nz reported.“I looked around for where this baby was. It was a distressed cry. Im a mum of four, so I know the dference, she said.“If it wasnt for one of the babies raising their hand or foot in the car, Id never have seen them. I could just make out movement.She said one of the children was a girl aged around four or five and the other was younger.The emergency services suggested she ask one of the children to open the door, which the girl then did, before the kids mum arrived arrived and opened the door.A blast of heat came out as the car door opened. The two children were dripping, sweating profusely, with red cheeks, and crying.It was shocking, that baby was in the full-blown sun.After about half an hour the woman ed and the police arrived about five minutes later.A police spokesman said the offender was given a formal warning for leaving children unaccompanied and a report would be made to children’s services.The Victorian Department of Health has warned parents not to leave children in hot cars as the temperature can quickly climb to dangerous levels.The temperature can double in just five minutes, so on a -degree day the temperature inside a car can reach a scorching  degrees very quickly, the department advises.Children can dehydrate quickly and suffer from heatstroke or worse in a short amount of time.

title: no deal brexit stockpile food medicine
story: So what should a worried citizen stockpile in case the shelves become bare There willBritain leaves the EU without a deal, a lobby group representing Sainsburys, Asda, McDonalds, KFC and other firms believe. Problems would be particularly acute around March, when Britain is scheduled to quit the bloc, and when most of its produce from lettuces to tomatoes is out of season, with a higher percentage imported, the British Retail Consortiumadded.The statement, also signed by the bosses of the Co-operative , Marks  Spencer, Lidl and Waitrose supermarkets, was published before key Brexit votes in Parliament set for Tuesday January .Responding to the BRCs letter, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said plans were in place to keep customs working and traffic flowing in the event of a hard Brexit. Food security was high and that would continue to be the case whether we leave the EU with or without a deal, he said.In terms of stockpiling it has to be remembered that meat and vegetables cannot be stockpiled unless they are frozen. Manufacturer Emergency Food Storage is selling so-called Brexit Boxes for £.Inside the package, which has a shelf le of  years, there are  freeze dried meals,  portions of meat, a water filter and fire starting gel.Some of the meals included in the Brexit Box are beef and potato stew, chicken tikka and pasta bolognese.Emergency Food Storage UK also sell a deluxe Brexit box, which includes puddings and breakfasts.A government spokesperson said: People dont need to stockpile food, water filters or fire starters.The UK has a strong level of food security built upon a erse range of sources including strong domestic production and imports from third countries. This will continue to be the case whether we leave the EU with or without a deal.

title: this morning nta ally ross tv opinion
story: Six days a week now, This Morning hammers home the message its viewers are the most helpless, mollycoddled invertebrates on the planet.A form of le so useless that last November Dr Chris Steele, the show’s resident quack, genuinely felt the need to give us all bottom-wiping advice.“It’s a front-to-back action for women,” more of a hit-and-hope exercise for men.Infor this constant nannying, we pick up a phone once a year and gurgle: “You’re absolutely right. We are useless. Have a trophy.”And it’s a depressing cycle that will continue for as long as there are National Television Awards, live from The O.A ceremony where the categories may chop and change every year, but the stupidity remains ritualised.As well as getting all the usual winners though, viewers also had to endure a technical nightmare on Tuesday, where things went wrong — from the shambolic opening scenes right through to the unedited version of the closing credits: “With thanks to — Television Centre White City or just Television Centretoo long.”It’s always a case of fine margins, of course, at the NTAs, and the evening might have strayed into so-bad-it’s-good territorythe cameras had just focused on one of the Love Island gang when host Dermot O’Leary said: “Danny DeVito will be in Dumbo next year.”They didn’t, though. So a night bedevilled by sound issues, rotten acceptance speeches and foul Danny Dyer language was crowned by Special Recognition winner David Dimbleby eulogising the BBC and ordering us to be nicer to politicians, in a speech that could hardly be descri- bed as “mood capturing”.It’s the awards themselves though, that I know get viewers’ goats the most, starting, painful as it is to admit, with the fact perennial winners This Morning absolutely robbed Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain operation in the Daytime category.Given that Jack Whitehall’s Travels With My Father managed to scrape on to the Comedy shortlist, there’s also an argument that says Chunk, Charlotte Hawkins, Richard Arnold and Susanna Reid — who was styled quite magnicently on the night as Waitrose’s answer to Vicky Pattison — should have made that final five as well.Because almost no show made me laugh as loud or as regularly as Good Morning Britain did in .A glaring omission too in the TV Judge section — always won by David Walliams — which included X Factor’s Robbie Williams on the shortlist, but not Craig Revel Horwood, who didn’t take a two-week sabbatical in the middle of Strictly, cost the BBC £million or throw in his other half as part of the deal.The award that made a nonsense of the whole occasion though was Ant  Dec winning Best Presenters for the th time in a row, despite the presence of Bradley Walsh and Graham Norton on the shortlist, and the fact Ant spent far more weeks in rehab than he did in a TV studio.The mutual affection is touching in one way, of course, but it ultimately does neither them nor the NTAs any good at all and has robbed both of a glorious moment of redemption when they win the  award.Before that foregone conclusion takes place, please stay tuned to This Morning and sit tight until mid-March, when Dr Chris will be along with part II of his bottom-wiping masterclass: Flushing, FLU-SHING.Practially the only programme I watched at the weekend that wasn’t punctuated by uncontrollable sobbing fits from the participants was BBC’s landmark Holocaust documentary The Last Survivors.Men and women who are all in their late eighties and nineties now and understand that time is precious.When you’re a living part of history you also know facts are far more precious than tears.So in the words of the remarkable Anita Lasker-Wallfisch, who avoided the Auschwitz gas chamber purely because she could play the cello: “I won’t give people the pleasure of seeing my emotions.”The very least we owe all of them is an audience. The Last Survivors is available on the BBC iPlayer and will probably be the most unforgettable  minutes of television you’ll watch all year.At approximately : hours, Sunday, Gemma Collins stumbled over while Dancing On Ice.The tectonic plates groaned a little on impact, the front row scattered like ten pins and there was a surge on the national grid as several million viewers went “click, rewind, play,” then “click, rewind, play,” again.In fact, by the time I’d stopped rewinding and playing, Gemma had “bounced back,”and Piers Morgan, no doubt angling for a Le Stories interview, had claimed it was “the gutsiest thing I’ve seen on a talent show” – probably since the days Piers himself was wedged in behind the judges’ desk on Britain’s Got Talent.It was an undeniably great television moment, though.A proper face plant, with a full Klinsmann snow plough to finish.The downside, obviously, is that it’s guaranteed she’ll be back next week, when Melody, Wes, James and the others will be performing to a Fairytale theme and Gemma will be clearing the B Fettercairn to Banchory road,ITV want to find a proper use for her.Click, rewind, play.Things remain cheerful as hell on EastEnders.Alfie Moon’s car has been discovered near some clfs and a policeman has the job of breaking the most awful news imaginable to Kat and the Slaters.“Considering the location and the evidence at hand, we would suggest you prepare yourself for the worst.”Big Mo: “You understand what they’re saying ”Yes, bloody Redwater’s getting a second series. Stay strong, viewers.Celebrity Coach Trip, Roxanne Pallett: “I knew as soon as Jedward got on the coach it was going to be fun.”The One Show, Matt Baker: “If you haven’t seen The Greatest Dancer yet, watch it on the iPlayer. It’s well worth it.”And Icons, Kathleen Turner: “Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and smash social barriers.”No, Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and make people laugh.Tell the BBC to try it some time.Good Morning Britain, Piers Morgan: “Every cloud. We lost the NTA, but I got a kiss off Gemma Collins.” Yeah, every cloud’s got a gigantic p***-storm.No one from Peaky Blinders bothering to turn up to the NTAs to thank: “The best fans a show could hope for.”Celebrity Coach Trip contestants Jedward ­providing the finest argument yet for theof a hard Irish border.Sheridan Smith’s accent doing the London to Doncaster trip in . seconds flat, on that Cleaning Up tosh.The Greatest Dancer’s pre-performance sob stories straying horribly close to moral blackmail territory.And E fly-on-the-wall moron Vogue Williams asking: “Is Gandhi the Dalai Lama ” in total ­ignorance of this remarkable man’s wisdom, serenity and even his landmark campaign for Dolce  Gabbana’s Light Blue fragrance . . .Martin Keown: “It should be a great spectacle, so sit back, hide behind the sofa and enjoy it.”Phil Thompson: “You never know what’s going to happen and that’s exactly what happened.”And Paul Merson: “If he was at Arsenal doing this, he wouldn’t be doing it.”.This week’s winner is the bellowing great Orca herself, Gemma Collins, and Sugar, from Total Drama Island.Sent in by Rich, of Lincolnshire. Picture research: Alfie Snelling.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “At the  Olympics, what birds were first released as a symbol of peace ” Georgina: “Eagle.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “What is the name of the monument in Trafalgar Square built in ­honour of Admiral Horatio Nelson ”Gemma: “Pass.”Ben Shephard: “Which British comedian ­presented the television programme Backchat with his father Michael ”Linda: “Jasper Carrott.”And Ben Shephard: “The Tartan Army is the nickname for fans of which national football team ” Najam: “Newcastle United.”Najam. A word . . .ITV’s The Paras: Men Of War, evenit needed three more episodes and better editing.BBC’s The Last Survivors. Tom Jones singing Cry To Me, with the talented Bethzienna Williams, on The Voice.The sudden, joyful NTA realisation the old bald bloke with the white beard in row A was Tim Lovejoy.And Celebrity Coach Trip guide Brendan Sheerin telling Jedward, Charlotte Crosby, Roxanne Pallett et al: “Today, you’re all going to a donkey sanctuary.” Well it’s about time.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lottery trick winners jerry marge selbee hollywood
story: Humble maths genius Jerry Selbee and his we Marge became multi-millionaires after he hacked the lottery and reaped the benefits for years.And after cracking the code to win millions, the couple are about to crack Hollywood after selling the rights to their story, according to CBS News.A big screen version of their incredible small town tale is apparently now “in the early stages of development, says the broadcaster, which featured the pair in a  Minutes episode.The down-to-earth couple were high school sweethearts, and raised six kids while running a convenience store in Michigan.They kept the store in their home town of Et for  years, before retiring in their early s to enjoy le a little bit.Back in , Jerry, who has a bachelor’s degree and a MBA in mathematics, noticed a flaw in the state’s new lottery game.The family man, then aged , realised in “about four minutes” that the new Winfall’s “roll-down” gimmick actually gave favourable odds to the player, prompting him to bulk-buy thousands of tickets at a time.Like other lotto games,no player guessed the six numbers required for the jackpot, the windfall would roll-over to the next week.However, in this particular game,the roll-over exceeded more than million then the jackpot would roll down to every single tier of winners - including those who correctly chose two, three, four or five numbers.Jerry, who is a lelong puzzle solver, realised that as long as no one guessed the six numbers on roll-down weeks, then a  ticket was statistically worth more than .He told the HuffPo: “I just multiplied it out and then I said, ‘Hell, you got a positivehere.’”After losing  on his first try, the seasoned mathematician persevered knowing that this was simply bad luck.On his next two attempts he won , from , worth of tickets and , from ,.He soon told his we Marge and they, along with their kids and close friends, started up a betting group GS Investment Strategies LLC in the small town of Et.The group bought hundreds of thousands of tickets every time there was a roll-down week and earned between .million and million .After Michigan shut down the Winfall game unexpectedly, Jerry and GS Investment Strategies LLC began playing Massachusetts Winfall game despite the state being  miles away.But after six years of playing and winning, Massachusetts lottery officials cracked down on group betting after it emerged that Jerrys firm and two other betting groups - including one led by an MIT computer genius - were dominating the states Winfall game, reports Boston.In , the Boston Globe was tipped off about their extraordinary success, and started investigating, suspecting initially that the game was rigged.Greg Sullivan, then state inspector general in Massachusetts, also became involved, and looked to seethere was any corruption or organised crime.But, he soon discovered that the couple had figured out a loophole in the state lottery game, and had won millions of dollars legally.He told CBS News that he was dumbfoundedly amazed that these math-nerd geniuses had found a way legally to win a state lottery and make millions from it.”Whats more, the state got very rich as a result, making  million courtesy of the high-volume betting.Prudent Jerry and Marge invested their winnings wisely, helping their kids financially, and payed for the education of their  grandchildren and  great-grandchildren.He also bought gold and silver coins in an anticipation of economic downturns, adding: I think devaluation of the dollar is a certainty.”However, theres been no flash holidays, new hot tub or even a sports car, as Jerry told CBS: We dont cruise.

title: nick timothy brady brexit vote
story: With the deadlock among MPs still not broken, nobody knows for sure what will happen.Theresa May says Brexit must go ahead on time. But she also says Britain will not leave the EU without a deal.And her deal — the only one on the table at this late stage — was defeated in the House of Commons by a record majority just two weeks ago.Tonight’s Brexit votes are not quite the final shoot-out between the dferent factions in Parliament. The Government has promised that MPs will vote soon on a new plan.Remainers and soft Brexit supporters in government are pushing to hold that vote as soon as possible.And MPs — backed by a Speaker who will rewrite any Commons rules to soften or stop Brexit — will force more votes on what happens next.Nevertheless, tonight’s votes do matter.One proposal comes from Yvette Cooper, a Labour MP.Her Yorkshire constituents voted to leave the EU by more than two to one and, during the election, she promised them she would “not vote to block Brexit.”Yet that is what her plan does:     MPs vote for her   amendment, they will be able to stop Brexit happening this year.Cooper has the support of several rebel Tories, soJeremy Corbyn whips his MPs to vote for it, she stands a good chance of getting her way.Caroline Spelman and Jack Dromey, Conservative and Labour, have an amendment that calls on the Government to avoid a no-deal Brexit.Dominic Grieve wants MPs to control the Commons timetable, allowing Parliament to vote on dferent ways of watering Brexit down.Labour want to present MPs with options that include, predictably, a second referendum.Despite drafting a manesto saying “Labour accepts the referendum result”, the Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer says in a second referendum he would campaign to overturn the result of the first.It is possible that none of these amendments might pass.Remainers and soft Brexiteers are ided about what should happen.Some want to delay Brexit, some want to tie us to European rules and regulations, and others want another referendum to stop it altogether.Evenno proposal wins a Commons majority, the votes cast by MPs will probably demonstrate that there is a majority to water down Brexit one way or another.For Brexit supporters, this is very dangerous indeed.Some believe they simply need to run down the clock and, in  days, we can leave without a deal.For Leavers who want a negotiated departure, this feels like a serious risk.But Leavers who favour no deal need to ask themselves, can they really be so sure they will get what they want With several Cabinet ministers, many more junior ministers and a Commons majority against no deal, it seems increasingly likely that MPs will ultimately find a way of stopping no deal.When they do, Brexit will only get softer and softer.This is why the amendment proposed by Graham Brady, a senior Conservative, is so important.His idea is to approve the Prime Minister’s original Brexit deal, but with the “backstop” removed.The backstop is hated by unionists, because to prevent barriers to trade between Ireland and Northern Ireland, it creates new barriers to trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.And it is hated by Leavers, because it ties the UK to the EU’s customs union, and Northern Ireland to EU single market rules.Brady wants MPs to vote simply for “alternative arrangements” to the backstop.By avoiding a specic proposal, he hopes the amendment can win a Commons majority and, in doing so, demonstrate to Brussels that the deal they struck with Theresa May can be ratied — but only without the backstop.Critics, largely Remainers, say this is impossible.But in the past week or so, Angela Merkel has questioned whether the backstop is such a good idea after all.The Polish foreign minister has suggested it should expire after five years. And the European Commission effectively conceded that in the event of no deal, they would use policy and technology to prevent a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.In other words, they proposed solutions they once dismissed as “unicorns” and “magical thinking” when they were suggested by the British — and which could render the backstop unnecessary.But this is not all. Some European officials have floated, in private, a more inventive solution: that the UK and Ireland should form a British Isles customs zone, with Britain compensating Ireland for any new friction in their trade with Europe.So it is clear: whatever Remainers claim, alternatives to the backstop are technically and politically feasible.Recognising this, the Brady amendment would give the Government one last chance to negotiate something better.Yet Tory Brexiteers say they might not vote for it. They fear the ambiguity of “alternative arrangements” could allow ministers to negotiate an even worse deal, perhaps tying the whole of the UK to the EU’s customs union and single market rules for good.They do not trust May, her advisers, or most of her Cabinet and demand a specic time limit on the backstop.Butthey vote down the Brady amendment, they will not get what they want, and are more likely to get what they fear.As the clock ticks on and bottoms get even squeakier, MPs will coalesce around a plan to stop a no-deal Brexit.The EU will have no reason to compromise, and Parliament will soften our departure by aligning us with more and more European laws.If Leavers vote against Brady, they will be shooting themselves not in one foot, and not even in both feet, but in the head.As the Commons debates the proposals today, Leavers need to start compromising with reality. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: us invade venezuela colombia john bolton troops
story: John Bolton said President Trump is leaving open the possibility of military intervention to protect the countrys opposition leader Juan Guaido.Bolton told reporters at the White House on Monday: The president has made it clear that all options are on the table.He also stood with a notepad which appeared to read: Afghanistan -gt Welcome the Talks. , troops to Colombia.Maduro was re-elected last year in an election widely seen as fraudulent.The once prosperous nation has been in an economic collapse, with several million citizens fleeing to neighbouring countries.It led the US and other  nations last week to recognise Guaido - the opposition leader of the National Assembly - as the interim president of Venezuela instead of Maduro.Bolton and Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin, who also appeared at the Monday briefing, announced the US was imposing sanctions on the state-owned oil company of Venezuela.The potentially critical economic move is aimed at increasing pressure on President Maduro to step down.Petroleos De Venezuela S.A. has around  billionin assets and is one of the countrys most important sources of income and foreign currency.Bolton said: We have continued to expose the corruption of Maduro and his cronies, and todays action ensures they can no longer loot the assets of the Venezuelan people.Bolton said he expects the actions against PDVSA will result in more than bnin lost export proceeds over the next year.He added: We also today call on the Venezuelan military and security forces to accept the peaceful, democratic and constitutional transfer of power.Welcoming the move, Senator Marco Rubio blasted: The Maduro crime family has used PDVSA to buy and keep the support of many military leaders.The oil belongs to the Venezuelan people, and therefore the money PDVSA earns from its export will now be ed to the people through their legitimate constitutional government.US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo earlier told the UN security council to pick a side.He said: “Either you stand with the forces of freedom or you’re in league with Maduro and his mayhem.End this nightmare. No excuses.”Guaido has continued to ramp up his challenge against Maduro, calling for anti-government protests on Wednesday and Saturday.Protests have already resulted in burned out cars, looted shops and deaths as civilians take to the streets to support the effort to oust Maduro.Maduro has turned Venezuela into an economic basket case during his five-year reign, with uncontrolled inflation hurting the lives of everyone in the oil-rich nation.Maduro was sworn in for a second term earlier this month after an election marred by an opposition boycott and allegations of vote-rigging.Since Guaidó swore himself in, China, Russia and Syria have all backed Maduro, with Russia warning America off military force.On Sunday, colonel Jose Luis Silva, Venezuelas top military representative to the US, defected from Maduros government.In a statement, apparently read in his Washington office, Silva said: Today I speak to the people of Venezuela, and especially to my brothers in the nation’s armed forces, to recognise President Juan Guaido as the only legitimate president.Guaido has said he will continue as interim president until a free and fair election can be called.Last week Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov told CNN: We warn everyone, not just the US, but some others that can entertain these ideas from this type of action.He said: The resort to military power would be catastrophic.

title: sainsburys asda kfc no deal brexit
story: A study also claimed higher fruit and veg costs will lead to thousands more fatal heart attacks and strokes — though this was dismissed by critics.Lettuces, tomatoes and fruit could all run out in April, say chains including KFC, McDonalds and Pret A Manger.The inflammatory claims come as MPs prepare to vote on the next steps ahead for Brexit.In an unprecedented show of unity, the bosses of Sainsbury’s, Asda and Lidl, plus the UK arms of McDonald’s and KFC, today urged them to find a solution that avoids the shock of a No Deal Brexit on March .They told MPs their “complex, just-in-time” supply chains would be “signicantly disrupted”.The Commons could back a controversial amendment which would see Brexit delayedBritain is heading for No Deal.The letter from retailers warned that a third of food consumed in the UK comes from the EU, and more in March, when produce such as lettuce and tomatoes is out of season, they claimed.It said: In March, the situation is more acute as UK produce is out of season:  per cent of our lettuces,  per cent of our tomatoes and  per cent of our soft fruit is sourced from the EU at that time of year.We are extremely concerned that our customers will be among the first to experience the realities of a No Deal Brexit.“For consumers, this will reduce the availability and shelf le of many products in our stores.We anticipate signicant risks to maintaining the choice, quality and durability of food that our customers have come to expect in our stores, and there will be inevitable pressure on food prices from higher transport costs, currency devaluation and tarfs.It was also signed by the bosses of Marks  Spencer, Waitrose, Pret a Manger, Lidl and Costcutter. They say shoppers will face higher pricesWorld Trade Organisation import tarfs, currently imposed on just ten per cent of food imports, are extended to those from the EU. Meanwhile, researchers said a No Deal Brexit could also lead to thousands more deaths as people eat less fruit and veg.Imperial College London estimated banana prices will go up  per cent, citrus fruits by  per cent and tomatoes by  per cent. It said low fruit and veg intake was a “major risk factor” for cardiovascular disease. Fatal heart attacks could rise by . per cent and deadly strokes by . per cent — with more than , extra deaths from  to , they claim.Labour MP Tonia Antoniazzi, a backer of the pro-EU Best for Britain campaign, said: This shows up the lies of Brexiteers who promised lower food prices and greater prosperity after Brexit.Now we’re seeing study after study saying food prices will rise and our top supermarkets worried about empty shelves.But an alternative study today found that a Clean Brexit could drive down the cost of food and give the economy an £billion boost.Economists for Free Trade said Britains GDP would soar by  per cent in the event of No Deal, which would allow us to make a trade deal with America.Edgar Miller, from Economists for Free Trade, described the research as “Project Fear at its very worst”. Christopher Snowdon, from the Institute of Economic Affairs, added: “It would be perverse to impose tarfs on food we do not produce. There are many problems with a No Deal Brexit, but paying more for bananas and satsumas is unlikely to be one of them.” Professor Patrick Minford said: The effect of Britain quitting the EU customs union and quickly striking a free-trade agreement with the US would be a huge double bonus for our economy.“We should think of the US economy as a giant supermarket, a kind of global Walmart, which we are currently barred from entering.But once we are out of the protectionist EU customs union, as a nation we would be allowed to go shopping at this giant Walmart. And, based on our research, we will find that prices are much lower.

title: commons brexit vote theresa may drama
story: During an electric confrontation after summoning all Tory MPs, the PM pleaded for them all to support a senior backbencher’s unity plan.Mrs May threw the Government’s weight behind Sir Graham Brady’s call for the current Irish backstop to be removed to keep her deal alive as Parliament tries to seize control of Brexit.Giving it a majority in tomorrow’s vote would “give a very clear message around what Parliament wants” and deliver her a mandate to take it back to Brussels, Mrs May insisted.But minutes earlier, arch-Eurosceptic Jacob Rees-Mogg declared his hardline European Research Group of Tory MPs would refuse to the unity plan.Instead, he demanded the PM spell out exactly what changes she would press the EU for.But that sparked a major split inside the ERG itself and a vicious bout of insults, as other members defied Mr Rees-Mogg to declare they would vote for the Brady plan.Boris Johnson also tried to pin down Mrs May during the tense meeting, several times yelling at her: “But what do YOU want to do Prime Minister ”The PM would only reply that she’ll continue to “battle away”.Loyalist Tory MP Simon Hart said: “Boris raised a question around, how is this going to manest itself in meaningful change.“She said, ‘we won’t know unless you support us Boris - get behind us and you’ll find out’.“It was the sparkiest that she was, and it got a cheer.”One Tory whip tonight put the number of refusenik Tory Brexiteer MPs as low about  diehards, meaning tomorrow’s Commons vote will be very close - and Mrs May will need some pro-Brexit Labour MPs help.The DUP also kept No sweating overnight.Its  MPs, who are propping up Mrs May’s minority government, will meet on Tuesday at .am to decide whether to vote for the Brady amendment, and what their terms will be for doing it.Asked whether Mrs May has the votes to win tomorrow, one senior Cabinet minister told The Sun: “I think so”.Wavering Tory MPs said what the PM commits to in her final speech just before the pm vote will be crucial.Two other senior Tory Brexiteers, John Baron and Andrew Murrison, also withdrew their amendments to toughen up the backstop tonight, to give Sir Graham Brady’s a better chance of getting picked by the Speaker.No heaped pressure on John Bercow to choose the Brady amendment.ERG chief Jacob Rees-Mogg appeared to soften his opposition to the Brady amendment – just minutes after ruling out ever backing it.He had declared the ERG group would only sign up to an amendment tabled by the Government itself that promised to reopen the Withdrawal Agreement to remove the backstop or replace it with an alternative technological solution.But after the PM addressed Tory MPs he said simply a government statement explaining its new position on the backstop could be enough to win over his and the ERG’s support.Mr Rees-Mogg told The Sun: “It really depends on the Government –there is a new government policy and this is claried and it’s a government motion that’s one thing.“Butit’s simply a standalone backbench motion that means nothing then that’s another question.“It will depend on the tone of the opening statements.”The Brexiteer added: “There are people with dfering views on what it means. There is no great appetite for it but the appetite would changeit becomes new government policy.”As insults flew between Tory MPs today, one likened Mr Rees-Mogg’s hardliners to Millwall-style football thugs.The PM’s former policy chief George Freeman branded Jacob Rees-Mogg’s European Research Group members as “hardline Brexit ultras”.He tweeted: “Everyone will have to compromise a bit. But hardline Brexit “ultras” need to compromise, too, to secure Brexit”.Issuing another appeal tonight, Tory party chairman Brandon Lewis said: “I would hope the ERG, when they look at this and actually look through the detail of what this gives the PM tomorrow, in terms of a meaningful vote that will come back later,it is about giving a message to Europe about what can go through Parliament in terms of dealing with the backstop issue and why that matters.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: unlimited eu immigration no deal brexit
story: The Home Secretary said that any EU national coming after March  will be able to stay for at least three years – subject to security checks.Mr Javid said it was important in the event of a No Deal to be “practical” and avoid “sudden shocks for business”.Any post-Brexit border controls would only come into force from January  – as they would do under the PM’s deal.The Home Secretary separately scrapped the PM’s target to reduce net migration to below the “tens of thousands”.Challenged as he presented the Government’s Immigration Bill in the Commons, he confirmed there were “no targets” in his post-Brexit strategy.“In the white paper, which sets out our approach to the future immigration system, there are not targets,” he said.Border Force insiders last week said there was no way the UK would be in a position to stop free movement in a No Deal from April given the lack of any new customs infrastructure.They claimed it was impossible to dferentiate between EU nationals who already lived in the UK or those who should be turned away.Speaking yesterday Mr Javid said that in a No Deal, anyone would be able to come for an initial three months.They will then be able to stay for a further three years by paying a fee for European Temporary Leave to Remain – subject to identity and security checks. The Home Secretary said the plans meant that EU free movement was ending as planned on March .But insiders admitted it was “unlikely” any EU national who doesn’t apply for temporary leave to remain after their initial three months would be deported.Mr Javid earlier came under pressure from Tory MPs to guarantee an end to “indefinite” detention for illegal immigrants. Conservative former Brexit Secretary David Davis urged the Home Secretary to take action about the “national shame” which he claimed has seen thousands detained for months.Ex-Minister Andrew Mitchell said there was “deep concern” on both sides of the House that so many were being “administratively detained” for more than  days.Lord Green, co-founder of Migration Watch, said: “This is free movement in all but name. Yet again the Government has entirely caved in to the business lobby.“This is an astonishing concession before the situation of the million British people living in the EU has even been considered.“Most of the public want to see a reduction in immigration, not to see it prolonged for years on end.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no deal brexit medicines priority food
story: Matt Hancock said it was necessary move as half of drugs currently used in the UK originate from EU member states.Asked by MPs whether NHS supplies are more vital than keeping supermarket shelves stocked, he said: “Of course, medicines will be prioritised.“The explanation I give in terms of food is the proportion of what is imported is much smaller than for medicines, whereas for medicines the proportion imported is half have some touch point with the EU.”Speaking at a Commons hearing on the future of health service, Mr Hancock said “very signicant” planning was underway to ensure patients can continue accessing le-saving medicines.Mr Hancock said: We have been through detailed, line-by-line analysis of the , medicines that are licensed in the UK... in order to ensure that there is a plan for the continuity of supply for all medicines in the event of a no-deal Brexit.The pharmaceutical industry have risen to this challenge and done their duty thus far.Theres a lot more work that still needs to be done in the remaining time but we do have the time necessary to do what we need to do.Simon Stevens, chief executive of NHS England, told the committee no-deal contingency plans have been activated.The health service have dedicated  staff to ensuring a smooth Brexit transition.Earlier this month the head of the NHS Confederation, Niall Dickson, told the committee no-deal would be a real disaster for the NHS.Labour shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth said it was shocking ministers were choosing between medicines and food.He said: “The fact that the Health Secretary is forced to make decisions over whether to prioritise medicine over food in the event of a Tory No Deal Brexit is simply astonishing.“Playing Russian Roulette with the national interest and putting people’s health at risk like this is shameful and scandalous.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
