title: family friendly commons vote held
story: NewsFamily friendly Commons vote held in middle of the night in ultimate ironyMPs were left furious after Labours Tulip Siddiq delayed her caeserean birth to ensure she voted on Theresa Mays Brexit dealShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsTulip Siddiq delayed a caeserean to vote on Brexit "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bid to make the House of Commons more family friendly is being voted on in the middle of the night in the ultimate irony. The Government is introducing a one-year trial for proxy voting to protect pregnant MPs. But the vote is not due until .pm - hours after bedtime.MPs were left furious after Labours Tulip Siddiq delayed her caeserean birth to ensure she voted on Theresa Mays Brexit deal.The heavily pregnant MP was pushed into the Commons in a wheelchair after Tory whips were accused of breaking previous pledges to pair pregnant MPs to give them a night off. But after the backlash the Government rushed through reforms to allow a one-year trial of proxy voting. If MPs approve the pilot, it will allow MPs expecting a child or with a new child to nominate another MP to vote on their behalf.   Pregnant and sick MPs are usually allowed to “pair” with members of the opposing party who abstain to avoid them having to physically travel through the lobby. But the systems flaws were exposed when Conservative chair Brandon Lewis broke such an agreement with the heavily pregnant Liberal Democrat Deputy Leader Jo Swinson in July .It helped Theresa May narrowly avoid a humiliating Commons defeat on Brexit trade plans.Pairing also means MPs do not have their names recorded as having voted - especially important on contentious issues. Ms Swinson, who has long campaigned for proxy voting, described the change as another step towards making it [the Commons] a workplace fit for the st century . But she described the timing of the vote, scheduled for .pm, She said: Of course in the ultimate irony, we will be voting on this modernisation at around :pm tonight! Valerie Vaz MP, Shadow Leader of the House said:“Proxy voting for MPs on parental leave is long overdue. After Tulip Siddiq MP was forced to delay the birth of her child two weeks ago, it couldn’t be clearer that we need to drag Parliament into the twenty-first century. “But a system of proxy voting could have been in place today. The Conservatives have dragged their feet on this important issue for too long. A trial is a step in the right direction, but Labour believes that proxy voting rights must be permanent and implemented immediately to ensure no MP is blocked from representing their constituency.”

title: health secretary backs firm profiting
story: NewsHealth Secretary backs firm profiting from patients who cant NHS dentist due to cutsEXCLUSIVE: Mark Hancock has thrown his weight behind MyDentist - an enterprise that targets areas with a shortage of NHS servicesShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent:,  JAN NewsThere is a chronic shortage of NHS places - including in Matt Hancocks own constituency"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA firm profiting from patients whocannot get to an NHS dentist because of cuts is being endorsed by Health Secretary Matt Hancock. Access MyDentist targets areas with big shortages of Health Service practices and offers more expensive private work. Visiting one of its surgeries in shyrural Mildenhall, Suffolk, Mr Hancock said: “Companies like MyDentist play a really important role in delivering a good service to keep our nation’s teeth strong.” Half of all NHS surgeries are closed to new patients because of a Tory funding crisis, it is estimated. In Mr Hancock’s West Suffolk constituency, fewer than one in  is taking new adults and some patients face a -mile round trip for a place. Access MyDentist is expanding in such areas, promoted as “almost as cheap as the NHS”.  But some treatments cost more than double and children, pregnant women, the unemployed and disabled are charged despite getting NHS work done free. Access MyDentist offers dentures at pound compared to pound. on the NHS. A routine procedure of one filling and one root canal with a crown costs pound at a MyDentist surgery compared to pound on the NHS. Mr Hancock, previously criticised for endorsing a private firm’s GP-finder app, posed for photos in front of MyDentist branding.   He said: “Dentistry has always been a mixed market with some people paying. That has served Britain well for a long time and any ideas for how to strengthen that offer are welcome.” Shadow Health Secretary Jon Ashworth said: “Surely the priority should be expanding access to NHS dentistry for everyone, not endorsing private firms for the better off.” MyDentist boss Tom Riall said: “We’ve developed an affordable range of private dentistry because so many shypractices are closed to NHS patients.” Askedhe hoped to see Mildenhall re-open to NHS patients soon, Mr Riall said he would prefer people to “take up an affordable private option”. British Dental Association chair Henrik Overgaard-Nin said: “Patients value a choice between private and NHS, but Matt Hancock seems content many of his constituents have no options.”

story: NewsWhat is a No Deal Brexit   ways youll be affectedUK leaves EU with no dealThe UK is due to leave the EU on  March  - and No Deal Brexit is becoming a bigger threat. Weve looked at  ways it would affect your everyday leShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video here-how-no-deal-brexit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UK is due to leave the European Union on  March  - and every day, No Deal Brexit is becoming more likely. A Brexit deal was agreed between the UK and the EU, but it was voted down in the House of Commons. So with time running out, plans are being put into action in case a deal doesnt happen. The government has published  technical notices outlining the practical effects of No Deal - from driving licences to cats. Meanwhile ministers have , troops held at readiness, could call up Army reserves and declare martial law. Ministers could quit in protestNo Deal happens while supermarkets and hospitals are stockpiling food and medicine. If theres no arrangement in time, well lose  international trade deals in a blink, shed access to EU criminal databases and troops couldto the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic.   A lot of the effects are on business. UK farmers face a nine-month wait for approval to export organic goods to the EU. Fishermen could be blocked from EU waters. And manufacturers fear their supply chains drying up. But businesses are not what whove written this guide for. Instead we have tried to establish  ways No Deal Brexit will affect you, the reader and your everyday le. Of course, these are worst case scenarios. Theyre not exhaustive. They may never happen. But youd better wise up...   What is a No Deal Brexit  No Deal is the default optionMPs, the EU and the UK government cant agree a Brexit Withdrawal Agreement by  March . The -page deal on the table will ensure businesses arent cut off by continuing rules in a transition period until December . But it comes at a cost - a backstop that could trap the UK in an EU customs union from . That means MPs have opposed it. Leaving with no deal will mean falling back on World Trade Organisation trade tarfs - increasing the price of imports and exports - and could leave legal black holes where EU law stood before. The UK government has been ramping up preparations for no deal since the beginning of summer . MPs believe they can find a way to block No Deal through Parliament - including by delaying the March  date - butthey dont its still the default option at pm on March .  More than , troops are being held at readiness in case there is a disastrous no-deal Brexit. Army reserves are also legally able to be called upthere is civil unrest, while councils are braced for possible runs on banks, fuel and food. Local Resilience Forums are reporting back to Whitehall and expect several months of disruptionthere is no deal. The government has plans in case it needs to impose martial law - military law - and curfews to restore order. Cabinet minister Matt Hancock admitted the plans existed but insisted the government was not specically looking at martial law and it was not the focus of our attention.  At the moment, British citizens can enter Schengen area countries with a valid passport eventhey only have a day left before they expire. But in a no deal Brexit, after  March  you may not be able to travel to these countriesyou have less than six months left on your passport. The government is advising travellers to renew any passports older than nine years and six months. . Usually this means renewing six months before your passport expires. Butyour passport had more than  years validity, youll have to renew earlier, because the extra months on top of  years dont count. The following are members of the Schengen Agreement: Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland.  There is a huge surge in red tape for pet owners who want to take their beloved animals abroad. Currently dogs , cats and ferrets can travel anywhere in the EU as long as they have a pet passport. The main requirement is that three weeks before the first visit, owners must go to the vet to have their pet vaccinated against rabies and microchipped. But in the worst case no-deal Brexit, pet owners must visit a vet at least four months before taking their pet the EU. And because talks are ongoing, that means youd better book in now. The animal must have a rabies vaccination followed by a blood test at least  days later, to prove the vaccination worked. Pet owners must then wait at least three months before visiting the vet to obtain a health certicate. But this cannot be done more than  days before the date the holiday starts.  Food is being stockpiled forwe crash out of the EU without a deal, and ministers have promised an adequate supply. But thats not the same as having the range of food we do now. Leaked plans in December warned Brits could have to y their diet. And in January, big names KFC, Pret, Lidl, Co-Op, MS, Waitrose, Sainsburys, Asda and McDonalds signed a damning letter warning food supplies could run short because of disruptions to the supply chain.They wrote in a joint letter to MPs: Our ability to mitigate these risks is limited. As prudent businesses we are stockpiling where possible, but all frozen and chilled storage is already being used and there is very little general warehousing space available in the UK. They added: Retailers typically store no more than two weeks inventory and it becomes dficult to restock storesthe supply chain is disrupted.  A string of firms have either moved jobs out of the UK or are threatening to do so in a no-deal situation. Airbus, which employs , people in the UK with around , more jobs in supply chains, warned it may move where. Car plants are moving forward standard shutdowns to be around Brexit in case there are supply chain issues. And critics fear new investment will not come the UKs way, hitting jobs in generations to come.  Major motorways in the South of England are set for serious disruption in case of a no-deal Brexit. From early  the Mwill be closed as needed from junctions -, with a contraflow of both directions on the opposite side, so it can be used as a lorry parkthere is gridlock at Dover. A backup lorry park will be in place at Manston Airport. The M in Kent is also expected to be used as a holding area for lorries. And a similar fate could befall a -mile stretch of the M towards Southampton.  The International Air Transport Associationwarn up to million plane tickets could be cancelledthere is no deal. Currently it is not known exactly which tickets could be hit, or how passengers would find outthey are at risk. The situation arose because in a no deal, there will be no automatic legal basis for flights between the EU and UK after pm on  March . Under a pact struck between the UK and EU in December, basic connectivity will be maintained for a -month periodtheres No Deal. But according to the IATA - which represents  airlines including British Airways - that only means maintaining the number of flights in . It does not allow an increase in services - yet tickets have already been sold based on a predicted increase. Talks are ongoing, but Amyas Morse, head of the National Audit Office, previously warned flights could be groundedgoodwill fails.  Currently a UK driving licence is the only thing visitors need to get behind the wheel on the continent. But under a no-deal Brexit, you should get an International Driving Permit. The pound. documents were due to be sold at , post offices from February. Before they were sold at fewer than . The number of permits issued would have to soar from , a year to million. Meanwhile you will also be forced to apply for a green card to prove you have the right car insurance. The certicates are free of charge and available from insurance companies. But the government warns firms may increase administration fees in order to cope with the extra bureaucracy. Those who forget their green cards would be forced to buy expensive frontier insurance in the country they are visiting. . Up to a million Brits may be forced to take a new driving test  British people driving in Europe could be forced to take a new driving testtheres a no deal Brexit. Up to a million Brits living in Europe were told to replace their driving licence with a local permit immediately. Guidance issued by the Department for Transport said: If you are aUKlicence holder living in theEUorEEAyou should exchange your UK driving licence for a local EU driving licence before  March . From that date, in the event that there is noEUExit deal, you may have to pass a driving test in theEU country you live in to be able to carry on driving there.  More than million EU citizens living in the UK will have less concrete rights to stay. Whether theres a Brexit deal or not, EU citizens can stay in Britainthey register for settled status with the government. But the rules are stricter in a No Deal Brexit. In No Deal, only EU citizens arriving before  March can apply, not those arriving by December . The deadline to apply will be  December , instead of  June there is a Brexit deal. And family members will only be able to join settled EU citizens in the UK before  March . As for the other way round - major EU nations have inidually said theyll allow UK ex-pats to stay, but this could y by country.  Pharmacists have requested special powers to ration medicinesthere is no Brexit deal. Under plans by the Healthcare Distribution Association, they would have special powers to y doctors prescriptions and offer something a drug is unavailable.  million packs of medicines are imported to the UK from the EU every month, and the NHS is preparing for a doomsday scenario to prevent supplies running dry. Government and NHS chiefs have set up a war room called the Operational Response Centre and industry firms are creating six-week stockpiles of medicine. Health Secretary Matt Hancock has chartered a plane to fly in short-shelf-le products, like isotopes for cancer treatment, from Maastricht. Insulin could also be stockpiled. Mr Hancock claimed hes become the biggest buyer of fridges in the world, after fitting out facilities for storage of the crucial drugs. NHS staff are being directed to urge patients not to stockpile medicines personally to avoid shortages throughout the system.  Mobile phone roaming charges could be hiked - less than two years after they were slashed across the EU. Costs were cut in June , meaning there is no extra fee for using a British device on the continent for calls, texts and data. Operators would not be bound by the agreementthe UK crashes out without a deal. The biggest companies, servicing % of customers - Three, EE, O and Vodafone - have no plans to reimpose roaming charges after Brexit. But in terms of the entire mobile market, surcharge-free roaming when you travel to the EU could no longer be guaranteed, the government has warned. . You should get insurance and flexible tickets for Eurostar disruption  Eurostar services could be suspended in a worst-case no deal Brexit. The government has told international train passengers - including the Eurostar - to make sure they have insurance and ticket terms and conditions that are sufficient to cover possible disruption. That implies passengers should buy FLEXIBLE tickets - not the fixed cheap ones that are popular for their low cost. The UK will need bilateral deals with France, Belgium and the Netherlands to ensure international trains keep running. Without such a deal, Britain has proposed recognising EU operator licences until March  to ensure services can continue. But this isnt guaranteed, and UK operators would have to reapply with the EU. Former Transport Secretary Andrew Adonis claimed the notice seems to be saying that the vital train link between Britain and Europe could be severed. . You might have to go through airport security twice  Air passengers changing flights in the EU may have to undergo two security screenings under a no-deal exit. Travellers boarding a plane in the UK to fly to a European airport, before changing flights for an onward destination, would be screened in Britain as they are now. But they might have to have a second check in the EU before getting their connecting flight. “Currently passengers flying from the UK and transferring at an EU airport for an onward flight do not have to be re-screened at that EU airport, because the UK applies, and exceeds, the EU baseline aviation security measures,” says a Department for Transport briefing note. “If there is no deal, and the EU decides not to recognise the UK aviation security system, then passengers and their luggage will have to be re-screened when changing flights in EU hub airports.” . You could be barred from using Netflix and Spoty on holiday  Britons could be barred from accessing their accounts for Netflix, Spoty and other online entertainment while travelling to EU statestheres a no-deal Brexit. Under the EU-wide portability regulation, which took force in April, citizens can access accounts set up and based in one country while visiting other member states. But a government technical notice said: The portability regulation will cease to apply to UK nationals when they travel to the EU. This means online content service providers will not be required or able to offer cross-border access to UK consumers under the EU Regulation. UK consumers may see restrictions to their online content services when they temporarily visit the EU. . If you live in Northern Ireland, you face electricity blackouts  Northern Ireland will be forced to take drastic measures to stop the lights going out. A worst-case No Deal Brexit would scupper the all-island electricity market shared by Northern Ireland and the Republic - leaving it without any legal basis. This would make both markets less efficient, with potential effects for producers and consumers on both sides of the border, the government warns. And it may be necessary to seek additional [legal] powers to preserve security of supply. To stop the lights going out, Northern Ireland would have to take more electricity from British power stations through an interconnector running under the Irish Sea. But Northern Irelands Transmission System Operator may need to rely on fall-back arrangements to ensure power keeps flowing, the government warns. That is why, eventheres a no deal, the government will take all possible measures to keep the all-island market running. There has been talk of barges in the Irish Sea. Dustin Benton of Green Alliance warned:Any emergency action to keep the lights on, both in Northern Ireland and across the rest of the UK, would likely be highly polluting and expensive. . You could be stranded on your package holiday  Package holidaymakers could be left with no legal protectionthe firm they booked with goes bust. Currently Brits have insolvency protectionthey book with a package holiday provider thats based anywhere in the EU. But in a No Deal Brexit, that protection would only applythe firms are targeting the UK market. That means those booking with, say, a cheaper Spanish firm online that has no UK presence could be unprotected. Eventhe UK government could act, in practice it will be much harder to take enforcement action against foreign firms because other countries will no longer recognise UK courts. . Youll lose rights to take action over dangerous products  Government documents reveal the same problem - UK courts not being recognised - will strip Brits of their consumer rights for EU goods bought online. Alex Neill of consumer group Which  warned: A no-deal Brexit would massively weaken peoples rights to take action when they purchase faulty or dangerous products from outside the UK. The Governments advice that we all become experts in international consumer law is hopelessly unrealistic. Securing a good deal with the EU is vital to ensure that Brexit doesnt result in a bonfire of consumer rights and protections.” . Your cigarette packets will change  Graphic warnings on cigarette packets will be replaced by Australian versions in a no-deal Brexit. And in some ways they are even more gruesome than the ones we have now. The grim pictures show a foot ridden with peripheral vascular disease, a clogged artery, a bleeding brain and high-resolution teeth stained black. The photos will be changed in a No Deal Brexit because the European Commission owns theon ones we currently use. That means the UK would be unable to use them after  March . . If youre going through a family breakdown, you could be trapped in limbo  Families who are midway through orce or child custody cases involving another EU country could find themselves trapped in limbo. If there’s a no deal Brexit, the UK will cease to be part of co-operation between EU family courts on  March . Instead the UK will fall back on legal conventions drawn up in The Hague. But these are complicated and do not cover every area of the law. The government has advised families with ongoing cases to seek legal advicethey will not finish by Brexit Day. A government technical note says: Broadly speaking, cases ongoing on exit day will continue to proceed under the current rules. However, we cannot guarantee that EU courts will follow the same principle, nor that EU courts will accept or recognise any judgments stemming from these cases.” . Your everyday medicines and perfumes could become more expensive  Currently, popular ingredients in cold medicines can usually be traded within the EU without a licence. In a no deal, a licence will be required to trade these so-called precursors. Sowe leave without a deal, firms who want to trade such chemicals with the EU will have to register with the Home Office, which can cost between pound and pound,. They will also need an import export license, which costs pound. Critics say this could push up prices for consumers in the shops. Similarly, cosmetics firms will be slapped with more red tape to prove their products are safe for human health. Currently they can use one legal “nominated person” to certy a product for the whole EU market. Butthere’s a no deal Brexit, UK checks won’t be recognised in the EU - and EU checks wont be recognised in the UK. That means two sets of checks. Labour MP Owen Smith claimed drug giants will look to pass on the costs. And finally... your regular caviar parties are doomed!  Caviar imports will be snarled up or stop completely in a No Deal Brexit. Sturgeon eggs join snowdrops, orchids and reptiles in endangered species that would need import and export permits to cross an EU border. Youd only be allowed to bring in g of caviar for personal use. A tragedy.

title: amber peat inquest girl 13
story: NewsAmber Peat inquest: Girl, , found hanged had argument with family over choresThe schoolgirls mum reported her missing eight hours after she left her home in Mansfield, NottinghamshireShareByJosh PayneNeil Murphy:,  JAN NewsAmber Peat went missing from her home in Mansfield in  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA schoolgirl who was found hanged had an argument with her mum over household chores, an inquest has heard. Amber Peats body was discovered three days after she went missing from her home in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, on May , . Nottingham Coroners Court heard the dispute was about cleaning a cool box which was used to store food on a recent family holiday in Cornwall - where the the -year-old hatched plans to run away with her cousin. The youngsters mother Kelly Peat had heard the front door slam shut shortly after the dispute at around .pm. She was reported missing to police by her mum eight hours after the argument. The inquest heard a passer-by had seen somebody of Ambers description enter a hedgerow area near the address around  minutes later. Although up to  police staff were involved in the search for Amber, her body was recovered on June .   The youngster - who had a history of running away - was reported missing at .am on May . Detective Constable Tina Gilfoyle, of Nottinghamshire Police, said Mrs Peat and Ambers stepfather Danny Peat had been to Tesco and had tea while the youngster was missing. Providing background of the the teenagers disappearance, Ms Gilfoyle said the family had moved  times in Ambers letime. The Peats decided to move to Mansfield after concerns about Amber running away and that she may have been groomed by a paedophile. Ms Gilfoyle said: The reason for wanting to move was that Amber had been running away and there were concerns the she may have been groomed by a paedophile.   There were no social workers allocated in her letime but there had been an assessment of the family. Addressing statements given by the younger members on the extended family holiday, Ms Gilfoyle said: They reported Amber had been troubled quite a lot there. There had been lots of arguments - she had been prevented from going to the beach, and together with her cousin she had written a run away list.was a wig, a torch and some rope to run away and her cousin thought it was a joke. Ms Gilfoyle said Ambers stepfather had threatened to hit her after she had scowled at him on the way back from the holiday.  She said: In the car on the way home, she had taken some cherryade without asking and had been scowling at Danny Peat. She was made to sit in the very rear of the family car. Danny Peat saidshe scowled at him again he would hit her. Summarising what had happened on the day Amber disappeared, Ms Gilfoyle said: She was trying to get her mums attention but her mum shuts the door on her, leaving Amber alone in the hallway. A short while later, the door slams and Amber is gone. They went up the street and Kelly thought she saw someone in the bushes but when they went, there was no-one there. Detailing what Mr and Mrs Peat did before they called the police, Ms Gilfoyle said: They went to Tescos and did some shopping and had their tea.  The matter was reported to police by Kelly Peat at .am on May , . Ambers former teacher at John Davies Primary School in Sutton-in-Ashfield, Joanna Holt, said the teenager had always seemed unhappy. Mrs Holt said: She was quite an unhappy child, that stands out most in my head. She never really seemed happy. She felt very put upon at home. She said she had a lot of jobs to do that her siblings werent expected to do... and she wasnt treated fairly in comparison to her siblings.  She would be a little bit dramatic about things. She was quite emotional at times as well. Mrs Holt added: She told me that she felt her mum loved her sister more than she loved her and that her sibling was the favourite. The inquest heard there was no evidence of physical neglect and no sign that Amber was malnourished at the time of her death. Home Office pathologist Frances Hollingbury said there were no traces of alcohol or drugs in her body and no suggestion of a mental illness. The inquest continues. If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or byemailingjo@samaritans.org

title: brit parents walk equivalent london
story: NewsBrit parents walk equivalent of London to Barcelona in buggy miles in ONE YEARThe average mum and dad is pacing  miles on the pavements each week - with mums heading out on walks while dads tend to take longer strollsShareCommentsByRichard Jenkins:,  JAN NewsBrit parents are walking hundreds of miles, a new poll has found "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe average parent clocks up almost  ‘buggy miles’ a year – further than travelling from London to Barcelona, a study has found. A poll of , mums and dads found the typical tot will be strapped into their pram eight times a week, for a stroll of around . miles on each occasion. That amounts to more than  miles a week - or  miles a month.But the study by ChannelMum found that while mums tend to take their children on more walks, dads will go on longer strolls.One in  parents even walk for more than five miles each time they go out with their baby in a buggy.ChannelMum founder Siobhan Freegard said: “Getting out and about in a buggy can be intimidating, especially for new parents.  “That first time out the door with a baby wrapped up is a huge event, akin to learning to drive and hitting the road on your own for the first time. “But there are so many benefits to taking your children out for a walk in the pram – it can help soothe babies, it’s sociable and it’s a great to keep active too. “Buying a pram is a right of passage. Many mums see it as the biggest step after taking a pregnancy test to becoming a parent. “A buggy plays a massive part in parents lives and is often more important than the family car – and as this study shows, many UK prams are putting in as many miles as a family car too.” How to stay safe when meeting someone from a dating app, according to experts The study also found the average pushchair is worth pound – although more than a tenth have splashed out pound or more. And the average British youngster spends more than  minutes a day strapped into their pram or pushchair. More than a third of parents admit they have taken their kids out in their pram for no other reason than to get them to sleep, while  per cent combine a stroll in the pram with the opportunity to get the dog walk out of the way. Seven in  parents also own up to taking their child out in the pram eventhey were able to walk for themselves for an easier le. And the age that children ‘should’ stop using the pram and walk for themselves was revealed to be just two years and nine months.The study, carried out via OnePoll also found almost a fth of scatter-brained parents have left their pushchair in an unusual place. More than one in five have left it at a zoo or wildle park, and a quarter have left the supermarket without realising their pram was still lurking in the aisles. Other common areas parents have mislaid their buggies include swimming pools, the doctor’s or even airports. More than a quarter of parents have even attended a ‘buggy boot camp’ to try and get in shape while using their pram. Forty per cent have used their pushchair as a substitute shopping trolley, and a tenth have even used it as a Trojan horse to sneak home extra purchases without their partners seeing.

title: delivery driver spots zoos red
story: NewsDelivery driver spots zoos Red Panda on driveway after it went on the runBrendan Magill described how he was delivering a parcel to house when he spotted another man peering towards the ground looking worried - before spotting Amber the pandaShareCommentsBySarah ScottAbigail OLeary:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video red-panda-found-safe-after-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA delivery driver spotted a zoos escaped Red Panda on a driveway after it went on the run. Brendan Magill described how he was delivering a parcel to house on Monday morning, when he spotted another man peering towards the ground looking worried.Walking to the end of next doors driveway, Brendan revealed how he was shocked to see the Red Panda, called Amber, wandering towards - hours after reading about its escape from Belfast Zoo, reports Belfast Live .The father-of-three said: I was delivering a parcel next door and when I came back it was walking up the driveway. The guy had called the police and they arrived but were a bit hesitant as they had been told not to approach it.   It kind of cornered itself, we were at the top of the driveway and it was under the car then trying to climb up the way, it was frustrated. “It was only the size of a fox.The zoo had been contacted and arrived pretty quickly. I could not believe my eyes, it was only a small, cute wee thing. It was so funny seeing it as I had read about it on Belfast Live earlier in the day.I took a few pictures and put it on Facebook and my phone hasn’t stopped since.  The panda had gone missing from its enclosure at Belfast Zoo on Sunday, with the police issuing an urgent appeal for members of the public to avoid approaching the animal. Zoo manager Alyn Cairns said: We are pleased to report Amber has been safely ed to Belfast Zoo after a short time exploring the local area. We would like to thank all of those involved in the search. We received several calls from local residents who reported sighting which helped the search team track its location.

title: inside eerie forgotten cave people
story: Inside eerie forgotten cave where people once queued to have sickness curedIncredible images were taken inside Holywell Cave close to Newquay in Cornwall, once popular with pilgrims and people with health conditionsShareCommentsByMirror:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsStunning pictures show the inside of Holywell Cave in Cornwall, which was once thought to have secret healing powers Stunning pictures show the inside of one of Britains most remarkable locations - a cave which was once thought to have secret healing powers.The images were taken at Holywell Cave - also known as St Cuthberts Cave - close to Newquay in Cornwall.Over the centuries thousands of people have descended down its steps to drink from the holy well, Cornwall Live reports.It was popular with pilgrims and people with health problems, as it was said to possess incredible healing properties.If the water from the sacred spring in St Cuthbert’s Cave really can heal, it may have the rich deposits of minerals within it to thank. Certainly the mineral deposits can be credited for the vivid red, green, blue and yellow deacutecor.  of As rainwater passes through the ground at Ky Head, it becomes a weak carbonic acid from the limestone deposits. This acid dissolves the calcite in the rock, forming calcium bicarbonate, which, mixed in the rainwater, drips down into the cave creating a natural spring. As some of the water evaporates and carbon dioxide is released in the cave, the spring water is left with a high concentration of calcium, which forms speleothemscreating a series of descending, milky yellow calcareous basins.  of As the sea cave floods completely, it is very important to only visit it at low tide, and to be aware of the incoming sea. It is also advisable to not visit the cave alone, and to take a bright torch to see all the magnicent colours hidden in the darkness.  of A slightly earlier book, John Cardell Olivers Guide to Newquay from  gives us a detailed description of the cave from that era: It is a somewhat curious place. After passing over a few boulders the mouth of the cave will be reached, where steps will be found leading up to the well.  of This rock-formed cistern is of a duplicate form, consisting of two wells, having a communication existing between them. The supply of water is from above and this water, being of a calcareous nature, has coated the rock with its earthy deposits, giving to the surrounding walls and to the well itself a iegated appearance of white, green and purple. Above and beyond the well will be seen a deep hole extending into the clf.  of The legend respecting the well is, that in olden times mothers on Ascension Day brought their deformed or sickly children here, and dipped them in, at the same time passing them through the aperture connecting the two cisternsand thus, it is said, they became healed of their disease or deformity. It would seem that other classes also believed virtue to reside in its water for it is said that the cripples were accustomed to leave their crutches in the hole at the head of the well.  of This well has Nature only for its architect, no mark of mans hand being seen in its constructiona pink enamelled basin, filled by drippings from the stalactitic roof, forms a picture of which it is dficult to describe the loveliness. What wonder, then, that the simple folk around should endow it with mystic virtues   of However, the popularity of St Cuthbert’s Cave is recorded much earlier than Oliver’s “Guide to Newquay”, by William Hals in his “History of Cornwall”, which he compiled from  until   of More OnCornwallCommentsShow more comments

title: meghan markle kate middleton targeted
story: NewsMeghan Markle and Kate Middleton targeted by racist and sexist social media commentsAbuse and threats, including some of violence, aimed at the Duchess of Sussex, the Duchess of Cambridge and their fans have sparked a #HelloToKindness campaignShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAbuse has been aimed at the Duchess of Cambridge and the Duchess of Sussex, as well as fans arguing amongst themselves "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRoyal aides are battling “sexist and racist” social media comments aimed at Duchess of Sussex and Duchess of Cambridge, it emerged yesterday. Kensington Palace staff are spending hours each week moderating vile hate against the two royal women. Some users have even made “violent threats” towards the two women, while others are targeting ‘rival’ fans for vicious personal abuse. The rise in abusive comments aimed at Kate and Meghan and their fans has prompted HELLO! magazine to launch the #HelloToKindness campaign, championing positivity online. A royal source told the magazine: “The Palace has always monitored comments but it’s a hugely time consuming thing. “They can block certain words, but some of it is quite serious. “Over the course of last year, with hundreds of thousands of comments, there were two or three that were violent threats. “You can delete and report and block people and the police have options around particular people. It’s something you have to manage because there’s no other way to control it.”  Neither Kate nor Meghan have inidual public social media accounts, with Meghan famously closing her Instagram , Twitter and Facebook accounts a year ago ahead of her marriage to Prince Harry .Royal aides stress that the majority of comments left by some of Kensington Palace’s . million Instagram followers and . million Twitter followers are positive. A source added: “A lot of hours are being spent reviewing old material and moderating comments under posts.”

story: NewsObese mum sheds staggering st in  months – WITHOUT going near a gymJoanne Thomas, , from Berkshire, vowed enough was enough after she struggled to lt herself off the floor at a parent and toddler group classShareCommentsBySophie Norris:,  JAN NewsJoanne Thomas, , after giving birth to baby Noah "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA st mum who had to wear maternity clothes for months after her pregnancy has dropped st in eight months - without ever hitting the gym. Joanne Thomas, , has shed st lbs after struggling to lt her bulky frame off the floor at a parent and toddler group left her so humiliated she knew enough was enough. The mum-of-two, who weighed st lbs and was a size  at her biggest, started to pile on the pounds during her second pregnancy with son Noah Grant. Joanne told herself she didnt need to worry about her weight while pregnant, bingeing on daily microwave meals, takeaways and six pieces of toast lathered with marmite. Determined to turn her le around for her family, Joanne joined Slimming World in April last year and has since dropped four dress sizes.   Now a svelte st lb, Joanne feels a million dollars and said her partner Stephen Grants jaw hit the floor at his th birthday party when she strutted in wearing a fitted jumpsuit. Joanne, from Thatcham, Berkshire, said: Its like Im a new woman, I feel like a million dollars. Im much more confident and better in myself. Its nice to go out and feel that people arent looking at you, or looking at you for the right reasons. People say whats your trick  but there isnt a magic wand - its about how much you want it.   You have to have amazing willpower. Stephens th was a massive aim for me. I didnt want him to think oh, I have a fat girlfriend that used to be thinner. But it wasnt really for him, it was the milestone I set for myself. He kept telling me I was doing great and was very reassuring and supportive. Hes amazed at how Ive stuck to it and been so focused. We went out for his th and I was wearing a jumpsuit. I came down to the hotel bar and his jaw nearly fit the floor. He said he was a lucky man and I looked stunning and he was really proud of me.  As of this week I can go into any shop now get a size  off the shelf and it fits perfectly. Its a huge dference. The mum-of-two admitted she used to gorge on takeaways and convenience foods during her -hour shts as a care assistant since starting their relationship in . After having son Noah Grant in March  Joanne said she soon felt embarrassed and inadequate when she struggled getting up from the floor at parent and child groups. It wasnt until after shed had Noah that the toll of her eating for two mentality was revealed as she spiralled to st lbs and spent months squeezed into maternity wear. Joanne claims one of the key turning points in her weight loss journey was when she had to ask other mums to hold Noah while she struggled to get onto the floor or stand up again because of her size.  A dficult pregnancy meant she was housebound towards the end and found herself eating out of boredom. Joanne said: When Noah was around three months old I took him to a music class. Wed have to sit on the floor and someone would have to hold him while I struggled to get up, I felt embarrassed and inadequate. I wanted to be able to get around like the other mums could and felt I needed to be thinner to give Noah the best childhood he could. Now I just tuck him under my arms and get up off the floor easily. Before Noah wed eat rubbish at home. Id be working  hours shts at the hospital and eating lots of takeaway, but I was only around a stone and a half heavier than I am now.   During pregnancy I thought oh, I dont have to worry about this for nine months, so Id eat six slices of toast with marmite for breakfast and the biggest cinnamon bun that youve ever seen. After having Noah, Joannes weight spiralled to  stone as shed suffered with pelvic pain and overeaten for months. Two months passed and trendy Joanne was still wearing her maternity clothes or struggling to fit into her size  leggings. Increasingly wary of her lack of energy and inability to play with her baby, Joanne ed to an old Slimming World class hoping to take back control. Joanne said: I wasnt always huge but I did pile on masses in that pregnancy. I remember going to my first midwe appointment and being mortied that I was already  st lbs. I had a horrendous pregnancy with swelling and a bad pelvis, and I was really inactive for the last trimester.  I was very immobile as well - obviously Id gone from working -hour shts three or four times a week, to basically being housebound. Everything spiralled, I wasnt mobile so Id sit and eat. I didnt have anything  to do, so Id sit and eat more. When Id had the baby and brought him home, I couldnt do anything. I was so fat and uncomfortable, I couldnt even get on the floor to play with him. When he was five weeks old I went back to Slimming World and I decided I wanted to lose weight more than anything. Despite previously trying Slimming World back in , her weight gain and embarrassment at being unable to move freely at the parent and baby group spurred her on to try the Thatcham group again.  Joanne said: I stuck to the plan religiously and now when I think to myself I want a cake I think I want the weight loss more. I wanted to be healthy and thinner and to be able to run around with my boys. I didnt want to be fat forever - I want to see my kids grow up. Noahs crawling now and Im running round like a lunatic half the time trying to move everything from his reach. I want to play on the park and get my fat bum down the slide - all the things I could never do.   After getting back into Slimming World, Joanne began to cook family dinners from scratch and has enjoyed watching the pounds slip off. She even enjoys fakeaways to replace her old favourite - fried chicken and chips. But the bubbly mum says she hasnt once stepped into a gym, crediting her slender shape to healthy eating and a short walk to the corner shop once a day.Joanne said: When I was pregnant I had horrendous heartburn so I lived on McDonalds milkshake.Now I fancy something like that or KFC, Id never go and buy one. Id just find a way of making a healthy one myself. I do all my cooking from fresh. Before, I couldnt stand to do that so we grabbed what we could get - takeaways and unhealthy foods. Now for breakfast I might have poached eggs with mushrooms or tomatoes, or Ill have a wholemeal bagel, bacon with no fat and cheese. Before Breakfast - Four pieces of toast with marmite and butterLunch - Cheese sandwich, salt and vinegar crisps, sausage rollDINNER - Large kebabSnacks - Slice of chocolate cake, Dairy Milk chocolate bar , McDonalds strawberry milkshakeTotal  ,  calories Now Breakfast- Poached eggs with mushrooms and tomatoesLUNCH - Smoked salmon and scrambled egg bagelDinner - Spaghetti Bolognese with rocketSnacks - None Total  ,  calories  For lunch Ill have a jacket potato because Im always out meeting other mums, or soups, omelettes. I dont avoid carbs either. At night well have anything from a chilli, spaghetti bolognese, chicken kebabs, roast dinners - proper food. I think the thing with Slimming World is that it isnt a fad diet. It teaches you to live the rest of your le eating healthy, balanced meals. Its family food as well, we all sit down and enjoy an evening meal together now. I dont do any exercise or classes, we might walk to the shop once a day to get some milk but I dont do anything . No gym classes, no aerobics - Im definitely not a runner.

After  years, have we finally taken the Duchess of Cornwall to our hearts ShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAnalysisthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news offline video watch-charles-camillas-first-public-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt was the moment Prince Charles and his long-term lover finally confirmed their romance to the world. The woman who had been so long kept in the shadows walked side by side with the man who would one day be king. The th anniversary of arguably one of the most signicant moments in recent royal history passed tonight . It is unlikely to have been marked with any fanfare, although one may wonderthe couple enjoyed a private moment of reflection on how far they’ve come. On that night in , when the Prince of Wales stepped out in public for the first time with his mistress Camilla Parker Bowles, it was the culmination of a sensitive project called Operation Ritz.   In front of  of the world’s press photographers, who had been invited and assembled outside the London Ritz hotel, Charles and Camilla were together. Across the Mirror’s front page the next day were emblazoned the words “At Last”, with other national newspapers declaring “It’s official, we’re a couple” and simply “Together”. For years, Camilla had been pilloried as a home wrecker after the public breakdown of Charles’s marriage to Diana. The princess had sensationally laid the blame at Camilla’s door in a  BBC interview, telling Martin Bashir: “Well, there were three of us in this marriage, so it was a bit crowded.” Polls found more than a third of Brits thought Charles should give up the crown in favour of handing it straight to his son William while a third disliked Camilla.   And yet, as she left her sister Annabel Elliot’s th birthday party, the trajectory was set to bring her into the family known as “The Firm” and change the British public’s feelings against her. Editor-in-chief of Majesty Magazine Ingrid Seward said that moment had taken “many hours of careful discussion behind palace walls”. The execution of such a carefully planned PR campaign was masterminded by Charles’s spin doctor, Mark Bolland. Charles, then , and Camilla had gone to great s to avoid being seen – or shyphotographed together. Their public declaration is a feat many say in today’s world of smartphones would almost certainly be impossible. Ingrid said: “The moment will go down in history. It was something that could never be pulled off in today’s world. It was long thought pictures would be captured of the couple, perhaps at a friend’s estate in an unguarded moment, the appetite for them to confirm the shyrelationship was at fever pitch. “Public opinion had been very hostile, and when Princess Diana died in , a year after Charles’s orce was finalised, everything that had been planned for Camilla had to be put on hold. “It was a finely balanced situation and Prince Charles always said it would be a slow burner. He often told Camilla that they would have to be patient.” The moment may have had important ramications for their future public le together, but it was over in seconds.  Charles emerged first, just ahead of Camilla, and walked down the steps of the hotel into a barrage of flashlights. At the foot of the steps, a beaming prince momentarily lost sight of Camilla, glancing to either side before guiding her with his arm towards the kerbside rear-passenger door of their Vauxhall Omega. He walked casually to the opposite door, smiling briefly to the assembled media before being driven away. In the years that followed, Mr Bolland, then the prince’s deputy private shysecretary, worked to normalise their relationship in the eyes of the public – a campaign known as Operation PB behind closed doors at St James’s Palace. It was an uphill battle... Sources say the young Camilla Shand was dying for the Prince to propose when they dated in the s, but he was playing the field.  When he left for military duty, she accepted another offer and married boyfriend Andrew Parker Bowles. Over the next  years, Charles and Camilla would stray from their marriages, shocking everyone with their  “Camillagate” phone sex leak. Charles made intimate references to wishing he “lived in her knickers” and a transcript of a bedtime conversation between them was published just a month after Charles and Diana announced their official split. But in  the Queen recognised the relationship by attending a birthday lunch for King Constantine with Camilla present. In June , the prince and Camilla shared their first public kiss at a party thrown to support the National shyOsteoporosis Society. They wed in April  at the Guildhall in Windsor, with Camilla becoming the Duchess of Cornwall. It is said she finally realised she would be welcome into the public’s hearts when the Queen made a touching speech to coincide with the date of the Grand National where she had a horse running. She began by saying she had two important announcements to make – the first was that her horse Hedgehunter had won the race at Aintree. And she was delighted to be welcoming her son and his bride to the “winners” enclosure.  She added: “They have overcome Becher’s Brook and The Chair and all kinds of other terrible obstacles. They’ve come through and I’m very proud and wish them well. My son is home and dry with the woman he loves.” Ingrid added: “In this moment Camilla knew the path would surely be smoother. For the Queen to publicly give her approval in such a way really did mark the beginning of her royal le for certain. “Since then she has been magnicent in every facet of her le and is one of the darlings of the royal family.” Camilla developed her role through her charity work, including raising awareness of osteoporosis, promoting literacy, and supporting shysurvivors of sexual assaults and domestic abuse. Royal correspondents have often said she is “the most fun to work with”. She will legally become Queen Consort when Charles becomes king. State banquets, State Openings of Parliament, royal tours and joint shyengagements with the Queen have become the norm for Camilla –  years on from a brief but momentous appearance as she headed home from a party.Streets near Windsor Castle are to be protected from terror attacks involving vehicles with poundmillion barriers after temporary ones were installed in the Berkshire town in March  in response to the Westminster attacks.

story: NewsTeen barmaid almost blinded after thug stubbed out cigarette in her faceLily Loan, , was attacked by Declan Potter, , outside a club for no reason andthe injury had been any higher on her face she would have lost the sight in that eyeShareCommentsByMartin NaylorHayley Coyle:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsLily Loan, , says she was almost blinded "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenage barmaid was almost blinded in one eye after a thug stubbed out a cigarette on her face in a completely “unprovoked attack”. Lily Loan, , was on a night out with pals when Declan Potter approached her and asked her “what her problem was” before putting the cigarette out just millimetres from her eye. He also tried to punch her. Miss Loan said thatthe injury had been even a fraction higher, she would have been blinded. The -year-old was at Derby Crown Court to see Declan Potter jailed for the attack, which took place outside Sinfin Moor Social Club in Derby.Potter, , was sentenced to six months behind bars, reports the Derby .  Miss Loan said: “It was completely unprovoked. “He approached me in the smoking area and asked me what my problem was. “I said what are you on about  And he came towards me and stubbed the cigarette out in my face. “Had it been a couple of millimetres higher he would have blinded me in one eye.” Luc Chignall, prosecuting, said the attack happened in the smoking area outside the club, in Arleston Lane, during the early hours of February , last year. He said Miss Loan, who was  at the time, was talking to a friend when Potter approached her. Mr Chignall said: “They did not know each other, this was completely unprovoked. “There seems to have been some kind of argument or dispute.   “During it, he jabbed her in the eye with the cigarette and then follows it up with a couple of punches which he tries to land.” Mr Chignall said the police were called and Potter, of Macauley Street, Sinfin, left. He was arrested and at first denied anything had happened. But after being shown CCTV of the attack, he later pleaded guilty to assault occasioning actual bodily harm. In her victim personal statement, Miss Loan, who was supported by family and friends in court, said: “The injury was right under my eye in an obvious place and I had to disguise it at first using make up and by wearing sunglasses. I also had to relive the assault as so many people kept asking me what had happened to me. “I am more self-conscious, this has affected my confidence and I am more wary where I go out. “There is still a mark which I have to cover using make-up.”  Jailing Potter Judge Jonathan Bennett said: “This was an appalling piece of conduct. “It was unprovoked and shameful and there can be absolutely no justication for your behaviour that night. “I come to the view that the appropriate punishment is immediate custody.” Kevin Jones, for Potter, said his client was self-employed, but he did not say what his profession was. He said: “What happened was foolishness that seemed to get out of hand. “It was a shameful way to behave and he acknowledges that.”

story: NewsThree schoolboys found suicidal man about to jump off bridge - they grabbed him and didnt let goDevonte, , Sammy, , and Shawn, , are to be nationally recognised for their bravery and compassionShareCommentsByNarbeh MinassianSteve Robson:,  MAR Updated:,  APR News"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThree boys were coming home from school when they found themselves in the middle of a harrowing situation. A deeply troubled man was sitting on the edge of an overpass with a rope around his neck about to take his own le. Devonte Cafferkey, , Sammy Farah, , and Shawn Young, just  at the time, didnt panic. In fact, the incredible quick-thinking, heroism and compassion of the boys, who go to St Mary’s High School in Cheshunt, Hertfordshire, saved the mans le. They tried to keep him back from the edge, talk him around, and when he went to jump, they grabbed onto him and refused to let go. As Shawn then calmly rang for help, two other passers-by came to the boys aide and the man was rescued. The three children are now to be recognised nationally for their bravery at the A overpass in Waltham Cross, last September. Shawn’s mum, Carol, has been amazed at the boys’ maturity and said they have just got on with it since their le-saving efforts.  They were coming from school and loitering around, Shawn was telling them to hurry up, said the -year-old. If they had been messing around a bit longer, who knows what they would have come and met instead  I feel like they were meant to be there to help him. Shawn told me what happened when he came home. I let him finish the whole story and the whole way through I was smiling because there was nothing I could add to it. While trying to keep the man back and talk him out of suicide, he passed the boys his mobile phone saying  it rings, don’t answer it. The boys were helped by -year-old Joanne Stammers, who is registered disabled with Klippel–Treacutenaunay syndrome, a rare disability that makes her highly prone to blood clotting.  Despite her condition, which prevents her from working, Joanne took over from the boys and held onto the man for what feels like forever and was left with bruising all over her arms. Another man, James Higlett, did his part in saving the man’s le. All five will receive awards from the Royal Humane Society, a charity promoting le-saving intervention. Shawns mum Carol is immensely proud of the boys behaviour. She said: I am extremely proud of all three of them, they are all good boys and it’s nice that they are getting recognised for doing something good in the community. Quite often in the national news there are a lot of negative reports about young people so it is nice to have something positive. They are very young and I marvel at how they are all dealing with it.

title: seaworld orlandos orca kayla becomes
story: NewsSeaWorld Orlandos orca Kayla becomes third whale to die at park in two yearsThe -year-old killer whale died early on Monday morning after her health deteriorated over the weekendShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  JAN NewsKayla spent her whole le in captivity "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSeaWorld Orlandos orca Kayla had died after  years in captivity. The killer whale died early on Monday morning after her health deteriorated over the weekend and she began showing signs of discomfort, according to officials from the controversial park. It is not known what Kayla died of, and a post-mortem is expected to be carried out in the next few days. A post-mortem was also carried out on the parks infamous whale, Tilikum, who died in January  - but the park has not released any details of its findings or a cause of death. In a statement on Kaylas death, SeaWorld Orlando said: While today is a dficult day for all of us at SeaWorld, Kayla inspired generations of guests and employees to care and learn more about this amazing species.  Her veterinarians immediately began treatment based on a physical examination. Unfortunately, her condition worsened on Sunday. Although animal care specialists and veterinarians devoted around the clock attention to Kayla, she did not survive. Kayla was born in captivity at SeaWorld San Antonio in , before being moved to SeaWorld Ohio in  and then later Orlando in  - where she spent the rest of her le performing for visitors. Kayla is the third orca to die at a SeaWorld park in the last two years. Katasha died of lung disease at the San Diego park in August  and Tilikum also died in the Orlando park in January .  Tilikum hit headlines after being featured as the main orca in Blackfish - a Netflix documentary which investigated SeaWorlds practices and handling of the whales.He had battled some very serious health issues - including a complicated lung infection - before his death, SeaWorld said. However, the official cause of his passing is yet to be determined. Captured in Iceland in  aged just two, the whale sired  calves in the  years he was at the park in Orlando, Florida. Before this, he had resided at Sealand of the Pacic near Victoria, Canada. Trainer Dawn died in  after being grabbed by Tilikum and pulled into the water following a post-show routine.   The -year-old was reportedly scalped and dismembered by the whale, nicknamed Tilly, during the tragedy at the park. Tilikum, who had a familiar floppy fin, was linked to two other deaths while in captivity - those of Keltie Byrne and Daniel Dukes. On February , , Sealand trainer Keltie fell into a pool with three orcas. It is reported that Tilikum pulled the marine biology student to the bottom of the enclosure, where she drowned aged just . And in July , the whale was connected to the death of Daniel, , after he evaded security and entered the orca tank at SeaWorld after hours.

story: NewsUniversity professor demoted after telling students to speak only EnglishMegan Neely, who works at prestigious Duke University in the US, has been forced to apologise after complaints were made Chinese students were speaking their own languageShareCommentsByAndrew HaySam Rkaina:,  JAN NewsMegan Neely has apologised for her comments "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA university professor has been demoted after telling students to speak only English in faculty buildings. Megan Neely sent an email to students saying she had received complaints from two faculty members about graduate students speaking Chinese VERY LOUDLY in student lounge and study areas. I encourage you to commit to using English % of the time when you are in Hock or any other professional setting, Neely said in the email to students, a copy of which was provided by the university. Her much-criticised email was distributed widely on social media. Neely stepped down on Saturday as director of graduate studies for the universitys Master of Biostatistics Program but will continue her faculty teaching, Duke said in a statement.Mary Klotman, dean of Duke University School of Medicine, apologised to students for Neelys email and said the departmentwould review its biostatistics program. There is absolutely no restriction or limitation on the language you use to converse and communicate with each other,Klotman said in a letter on Saturday.  In her email, Neely said the two faculty members wanted to identy the students who had been speaking in Chinese so they could remember themthey ever interviewed for an internship or asked to work with them for a masters project. They were disappointed that these students were not taking the opportunity to improve their English and were being so impolite as to have a conversation that not everyone on the floor could understand, Neely said in the email.To international students, PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE keep these unintended consequences in mind when you choose to speak inChinese in the building, she added.

title: buy one get one free set sail with the tele on a luxury cruise to norway and the scottish isles departing from dundee
story: Tele readers will be able to enjoy the best sights Norway and Scotland have to offer when the paper sets sail on its very own cruise adventure.The exclusive Tele voyage on the majestic Magellan cruise ship  will depart on a nine-night tour around some of the most breath-taking scenery in the world.With up to , passengers, the glamorous ship will visit awe-inspiring fjords and some of Scotland’s stunning islands.A convenient departure from the Port of Dundee means you can look forward to leaving the hassles of airports behind and get straight into holiday mode.The journey evokes nostalgic memories of the days when The Tele#s parent company ran a famous shipping line in the s.There will be plenty of entertainment on board as well during the special trip # all organised by The Tele#s owners DC Thomson and ship operator Cruise and Maritime Voyages.Fresh delights will await every day as a dedicated team of expert chefs and attentive restaurant staff serve up delicious meals and a luxurious evening dining experience with up to five courses.Magellan, named after the great explorer Ferdinand Magellan, offers an incredible iety of activities within its ftframe, including a show lounge, pubs, coffee shops, casino and shopping galleria.The Tele Magellan voyage departs from Dundee on June  , and arrives back in Greenock  days later # after taking in sights including Flam, Bergen and Portree.While best known these days for its industry-leading publishing work, DC Thomson has a long and proud association with the sea.Following his success in business, William Thomson II looked to the seas and purchased a stake in a sailing ship.His involvement escalated over the years when he purchased more vessels.Eventually, with a fleet of , the Thomson family was responsible for one of the most invaluable shipping firms in the world and provided essential aid to South Africa during the Boer War.Andrew Thomson, chairman of DC Thomson, said: “It’s wonderful to see DC Thomson realigning with its heritage by ing to the seas.“When William Thomson established the Thomson Shipping Line in the th century I’m sure he didn’t contemplate that over  years later DC Thomson would be transporting passengers by ship around the Scottish Isles and Norway.“This kind of ersication of the business is a great fit for DC Thomson.”Craig Houston, head of enterprise for DC Thomson Media, said: “Working with Cruise  Maritime Voyages to bring this highly desirable sailing route to DC Thomson Travel customers has been a pleasure.“We’re excited to be offering such a special route with a trusted partner and we can’t wait to hear what our passengers say about this amazing trip.”

title: dundee united could launch ambitious move for ex aberdeen star peter pawlett
story: Dundee United could launch an ambitious move for wide man Peter Pawlett before the transfer window closes.The -year-old former Aberdeen star has been with MK Dons since the summer of  and, signicantly, it was United boss Robbie Neilson who signed him for the English outfit.His game time there this season has been limited but he has ed to the starting line-up in recent weeks and that could see the League Two side demand a fee for him.It was with the Dons up north the pacey winger made his name and, in  years at Pittodrie, he made over  appearances.His proven track record in the top flight and past association with the manager makes him an obvious target as the Terrors look to put together a squad that doesn’t just get back to the Premiership but does well there.If the former Scotland U  international does join up it would take the January arrivals at Tannadice to six.A busy month so far has seen Aidan Nesbitt, Cammy Smith, Morgaro Gomis, Ian Harkes and, on Wednesday, goalkeeper Ross Laidlaw all fixed up.And, including Pawlett, that number could rise by another two or even three by the time the window closes in a week.Meanwhile, gaffer Robbie has set his charges the challenge of finishing the month at the top of the Championship by getting all three points tonight at Ayr.United go into the clash at Somerset Park level on points with their second-place hosts, though Ayr have a game in hand over their rivals, and three off top-of-the-tree Ross County, who play on Saturday.Robbie said: “If we can end the January window up at the top of the league it would be great for us and still have a little bit of the transfer period to get a couple of players in as well.”

story: Callum McGregor has insisted that any criticism of Scott Sinclair is unwarranted. The -year-old netted his eighth goal in seven games in the - win over Hamilton Accies at the weekend to take his tally for the season to  - just one behind Celtics top scorer Odsonne Edouard. And McGregor has insisted that he has never been under any illusion as to just what Sinclair brings to the team. "He is on an excellent run," said the midfielder. "The thing with Scotty is that I keep hearing people saying that he is not playing well and yet he is scoring goals week in, week out for us. "I think he set his standard so high in that first season when he was almost unplayable at times. "There isnt a player in the world who doesnt take a dip at some point but he has always chipped in with goals and assists - I think last season he scored  goals for us. Its not bad, is it  "The last few games we are seeing him going past people, he is calling for the ball all the time and he is winning penalties and scoring goals so I am delighted for him. "As players we always know what he brings and how important he is to the team. But I am delighted for him because he definitely looks as though he is bang on form again and that is good news for us." Meanwhile, McGregor has insisted that he wont be asking for a rest after featuring in every one of Celtics games this season. Between club and country McGregor has played  matches but he is in no mood to down tools for a breather. "I feel good," he said. "I think you always want to play, especially when the team is winning and successful and you want to be a part of that. "It hasnt crossed my mind that I would go and say that I needed to take a rest. Physically I feel good. I dont have any injury problems and I love being out there. "Its a privilege to player here and Id be delighted to go and play every game now this seasonI could." Celtic host St Johnstone on Wednesday evening, the start of a run of games against the Perthshire side between the Scottish Cup, the league and a rearranged fixture. Taking three points would enable Celtic to stretch further ahead at the top of the table with McGregor keen to keep the winning home run going. "We always just take it every game at a time," he said. "It can be a bit odd when you are playing the same team so often in a short space of time. "But it happened last season against Motherwell and the manager shook things up a bit for every game. I think in the third game against them we won - so I think we will always look to try and keep it fresh. "In terms of Wednesday night it is just a chance now to keep this wee run of form going. Hopefully we can take all three points but we know that it will be a tough night for us. "St Johnstone will make it hard for us but its up to us to go and find a way past them."
