title: Call for Inverness to get a share of cash for shop conversions
story: CONCERNS have been raised that Inverness could be denied a share of funding to help the hardest-pressed local high streets turn empty shops into housing.Mike Smith, manager of the cityrsquos Business Improvement Districtfears a move by the Federation of Small Businessesto persuade the Scottish Government to split a pound million fund between the poorest-performing high streets only could see a relatively buoyant Inverness miss out.ldquoI donrsquot think thatrsquos fair, he said.ldquoAll high streets are under certain pressures. Retail is a commercial venture and we do not think that public funds should be given tosupport one retail sector against another.ldquoI think this pound million should be fairly split on a population basis and should be used in an equal way to improve the infrastructure.Mr Smith stressed that some local authorities will already be investing in this way and their successes ldquoshould not be held against them.He said the redevelopment of Academy Streetrsquos former Farmfoods supermarket was ldquoa good example of shops being turned into homes in the city with the local authorityrsquos support.The development there will include  one-bedroom and  two-bedroom flats as well as four retail and office units on the ground floor.A spokesman for FSB nationally said: ldquoIt is far too early to tell which high streets will benefit from this fund.ldquoWersquore making the case for each local authority to use this money in the places that it could make the most dference.FSB Highlands and Islands development manager David Richardson said: ldquoRather than spreading the money too thinly for it to have any impact, the FSB wants it to be focused on ersying our hardest-pressed high streets and is calling for local authorities to establish new co-investment funds to improve and convert existing properties. We must make more of what wersquove already got. Allied to this is the need for joined-up thinking amongst public bodies. Given that thriving high streets and village centres are inextricably linked to the health and wellbeing of their communities, it is important that all interested parties work in partnership.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister said she would be calling on colleagues to get round the table for some strategic planning to make sure the city gets a share of the funding.She believes the rate of shop closures in the Highland capital and the long waiting list for homes puts the city at the front of the queue.She said: ldquoIrsquom going to have a chat with the city centre manager, David Hass, and get people around the table to see how we can get our hands on that money.Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: Disused Daviot tourist site set for regeneration
story: A FORMER Culloden Academy pupil who has set up his own care business is to bring new le back to a former tourist office on the A just south of Inverness.Tim Cockinghopes to create up to  new jobs in the care sector and is looking for an operator to run a restaurant cafeacute type business from the former Visit Scotland office at Daviot.Formerly known as the Daviot Woods picnic site he is renaming it the lsquoNorth Gatewayrsquo.ldquoItrsquos right off the A and a perfect location for travellers passing through Inverness perhaps going to do the North Coast , said Mr Cocking who left Culloden when he was  with his family to live in Edinburgh.ldquoIrsquove seen the building when Irsquom visiting the north and itrsquos been looking rather sad and dilapidated and I thought there was something I could do with it.Mr Cockingrsquos Edinburgh-based company Brightcare has now applied to Highland Council for permission to change the use of the building to incorporate restaurant and retail facilities.ldquoThere once were public toilets there and itrsquos my intention to reinstate these once we have a thriving business on the site.His company Brightcare provides private home care for private clients looking for an alternative to residential care and already employs six people in the Highlands.ldquoWe have our HQ in Edinburgh and employ  people Scotland-wide and six of these jobs are in the Inverness area. But it is our intention to grow that business to about  jobs in the next few years.ldquoThe building at Daviot would also have an office for Brightcare. Itrsquos a well known building, bigger than we need for an office and there is space for both operations.ldquoI have already had expressions of interest from restaurant operators and a dog grooming business which would fit in well to because it is a popular area for people walking their dogs.Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: Inverness charity issues go orange plea for fundraising effort
story: INVERNESS charity Leorsquos Pride is encouraging people to lsquoGo orange for a dayrsquo as ambassadors in this yearrsquos Muscular Dystrophy UKevent on February .The national campaign has been running for three years and has so far made more than pound, by encouraging schools, workplaces and iniduals to wear orange for a day and make a donation to MDUK.Additionally those taking part can choose to wear sunglasses or even set up a mock-tail bar, in order to raise funds.Leorsquos Pride is a local organisation which was set up for Leo Flett, who is three-years-old and suffers from Muscular Dystrophy . Leorsquos mum Louise said: ldquoThe support we have had since starting almost a year ago is absolutely incredible and we continue to be touched by peoplersquos kindness and generosity.Mrs Flett said: ldquoWe are totally blown away by this yearrsquos response. We have been very lucky and honoured to have been asked to be ambassadors for the day this year by MDUK which means a lot to us considering wersquore still so new.The charity is raising money to continue their work finding new treatments and campaigning for better care and support for people with muscle-wasting conditions to ensure them the best possible quality of le.Muscular Dystrophy UK regional development manager, Dean Widd said: ldquoA huge thank you to everyone in Inverness looking to take part in the national Go Orange for a Day on February . We are delighted that over a dozen schools, clubs, academies and businesses have registered to take part in support of our Scottish family fund Leorsquos Pride.Mr Widd said: ldquoIt is thanks to the incredible efforts like this that we are able to continue to fund pioneering research into potential treatments for muscular dystrophy as well as supporting families. With more than , people in the UK living with muscular dystrophy and other muscle-wasting conditions, it is important to do whatever we can to make a dference.Leorsquos Pride is also organising an event in April called Pride  after last yearrsquos event which made over pound,.Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: Leading Inverness football figure to live on with launch of fundraising campaign
story: THE memory of a leading Inverness football figure will live on with the launch of a fundraising campaign to help renal patients and raise awareness of kidney failure.Sandyrsquos Army will be launched in memory of Sandy Corcoran, the founder of Inverness City Ladies, on what would have been his th birthday.Mr Corcoran, who died three days before Christmas, had lived with type one diabetes for many years and then developed kidney failure resulting in him undergoing long dialysis sessions in Raigmore Hospitalrsquos renal unit.His family, including we, Valerie, son Steven and daughter Ashley Mackinnon, plus five grandchildren, are now raising funds for the unit at a dinner dance featuring live music and comedians at the cityrsquos Kingsmillrsquos Hotel on April .At the stroke of midnight, Sandyrsquos Army will be launched heralding more fundraising events in the coming year.Mrs Mackinnon said just  tickets remain for the event after  were snapped up in three days.ldquoWe want the night to be a massive celebration and we want to remember what an unbelievable person he was, she said. ldquoIt is going to be a sensational tribute to him as a person helping others and he would have wanted it no other way. It will be a hard day but I feel that being with those who loved him it will make it easier.Although Mr Corcoran was diagnosed with diabetes  years ago, he managed his condition but then developed kidney failure five years ago.With the support of his family, he started home dialysis but when it became too dficult he had to swap to six-hour sessions three days a week in the renal unit.ldquoThe unit became like a family to us, Mrs Mackinnon recalled. ldquoThey were just incredible to my dad. I noticed he was never on his own. They work tirelessly  hours a day, seven days a week.He was due to have a kidney and pancreas transplant but then developed bone marrow failure resulting in him having blood transfusions which meant he could not have a transplant.Sadly, Mr Corcoran, who was also the manager of Inverness Precast, died on December . Over  people attended his funeral.ldquoHe faced everything with the most unbelievable courage. I never once heard dad complain, Mrs Mackinnon said.She added that the family want to give something back to the renal unit and, as well as the dinner, planned fundraisers include an ascent of Ben Nevis.ldquoThis is a way of helping others through his memory.Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: New bridge over the River Nairn is on track for summer
story: TEMPORARY weight restrictions on a busy rural road could be scrapped by the summer.Work to build a new crossing over the River Nairn to replace the ageing White Bridge is ldquoprogressing well and on track for completion by early summer, Highland Council has confirmed.The road bridge, which dates back to the th century and is category A listed, spans the river on the B route between Clephanton and Cawdor.It has been struggling to cope with heavy modern traffic and a weight limit of  tonnes has been in operation while a new bridge is built and the road realigned. The weight restriction has caused disruption for farmers, forestry vehicles and tour buses, which have been unable to use the existing bridge in the interim.The pound. million project is being handled by Dingwall-based RJ McLeod .Confirming that work is on track, Highland Council said that construction of the abutments for the new crossing beams was now complete and the beams were successfully hoisted into place this week.Now that the four beams are in place, contractor RJ McLeod will proceed with decking out between beams in preparation for concrete casting.Highland councillors in the Nairn and Cawdor ward, and Culloden and Ardersier wards ndash whose boundaries are spanned by the new crossing ndash have welcomed the progress being made.During the works the existing route has remained open to drivers, however all road users have been reminded about the -tonne weight restriction.Any vehicles which weigh more than this limit should use the ersion route, which goes via the A, A and B roads.Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: Parents criticise new school bus service across Inverness
story: SCHOOL bus services have been in chaos since a council contract changed hands at the start of the month it has been claimed.Parents say a move to double up dedicated school runs with services for the general public since transport giant Stagecoach took over the Highland Council schools contract from DE Coaches on January  has seen pupils regularly forced to endure late-running and dangerously overcrowded buses.Police have also confirmed they are investigating allegations that pupils were threatened with a weapon on board a bus between Kirkhill and Charleston Academy on January .Mum Carol Paterson, whose daughter travels from Croy to Culloden Academy, said the problems are known about across Inverness.ldquoThe children at Croy are waiting sometimes up to  minutes in freezing conditions because the buses are now regularly late, she said.ldquoAnd when they board the bus there are not enough seats.Jools Lawson, whose daughter attends Charleston Academy, said: ldquoKids are regularly having to stand on a jam-packed bus or being put off altogether and told to wait for another one.ldquoThe service is disgusting and Stagecoach brush our complaints under the carpet.Posts from a private Facebook group set up for parents of pupils using school buses and shown to the Inverness Courier make clear the extent of unhappiness since the changeover.Other alleged incidents include children being put off a bus beside a busy main road without a pavement and two incidents involving Inverness Royal Academy pupils ndash one where a bus did not turn up at home time and another where the bus was too small to accommodate them.Highland Council has issued two separate statements in response to concerns raised ndash one with regard to a public service operating en route to Inverness Gaelic Primary stating it is unlikely to involve ldquoroutes which the public are likely to want to use and another on the Charleston Academy-Kirkhill route stating ldquomeasures have been put in place to make improvements.Despite this an online petition has been launched calling for the reinstatement of dedicated school services.Signed by almost  people so far it states: ldquoWhen putting our children on a school bus it used to be the case that it was only school children on these buses, therefore anyone travelling was accounted for and any incidents easily dealt with and tracked.ldquoNow we have opened the floodgates to allowing our children to be exposed to anything on these buses.Councillor for Culloden and Ardersier, Glynis Campbell-Sinclair, said Highland Council needs to launch its own investigation into whether there is a serious problem with how buses taking pupils to and from schools operate.ldquoThey cannot jam pack children onto buses like pilchards and hope there is not going to be an accident - especially in this weather, she said.ldquoEvery parent that sends their child to school by bus is depending on the council to ensure that happens safely.ldquoIt is the councilrsquos responsibility as corporate parent to ensure these children get to school safely.A spokeswoman for Stagecoach North Scotland said: ldquoSince we started operating the additional school contracts on January  there have been some issues with capacity we have identied and are working to resolve.ldquoWe are working closely with Highland Council to resolve these problems by issuing school children with passes allocating them to specic buses to prevent the overloading problems we have seen.She added that in terms of the issues raised by Mrs Paterson an additional bus is now running to and from Croy.Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: Work starts on new outlets at Eastgate Shopping Centre
story: WORK has begun at the Eastgate Shopping Centre in Inverness to develop four food outlets.The units, suitable for restaurant or bar operators, are being created by the reconfiguration of two existing shops fronting Falcon Square.Burger King UK is the first operator to sign up while talks are ongoing with operators for the other units.In addition, a new kiosk will be created fronting the Falcon Square mall entrance. title: marian travels back to the hollow mountain
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsMy book about the project, Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain, was published to coincide with the th anniversary of its opening. Invited to join Cameron up at the Cruachan dam for the second of his two recent programmes, I was delighted to tramp the mighty mountain with Scotland’s Number one authority on outdoor pursuits.As an author and broadcaster, Cameron always has an eye on a good story, and so as well as asking me about the lack of health and safety regulations at the time the hydro project was being built, he also wanted to knowthere really was a murder during the construction. There was, as I told him, a body – but the body wasn’t identied, no arrests were made, no court case took place.It would be a shamethat construction period went down in history as an invasion of , workmen – #Tunnel Tigers# as they were dubbed – into one of Argyll#s most beautul settings and a possible murder.My book was intended to give the story of the local people whose lives were punctuated by this ambitious construction project. Quite rightly, those Tunnel Tigers had been lauded in a number of publications. The work that was done hollowing out Argyll’s highest mountain to provide electricity for the nation was amazing.The plan for Cruachan – as for the other major hydro projects of the post World War II era – was conceived by Tom Johnston, to whom I dedicated my book. Johnston was a politician who remained true to his ideals of bringing rural Scotland into the modern world. There was no power in the Highlands, and without power there could be no industry and no prosperity. The engineering genius was Sir Edward MacColl, whose biographer Norrie Fraser called him #a maker of modern Scotland#.Cruachan was the first reversible pumped-storage system in the world. During its years of construction from  to , eminent international engineers visited the project to see how the water was pumped between two reservoirs through reversible turbine generators. At off-peak hours, the water was – is # pumped back up to the reservoir you see high up in the corrie above Loch Awe, held back by a dam that is now so much a part of our landscape. The loch itself is the lower reservoir.I had imagined that the scale of such a project – using Scotland’s top engineering companies who shipped in workers from other parts of the UK and Europe – would have been a cause for resentment and protest by local people.That, of course, failed to take account of the vision of the folk of Dalmally, Lochawe, and Taynuilt. Although it took men with engineering experience to blast the  miles of tunnels, hollow out the mountain itself, and construct the dam, there was also a need for a support army. There were clerks and porters, joiners and caterers, folk willing to let out a room, a caravan, a house, serve in a pub where just occasionally it was necessary to keep a baseball bat behind the bar to maintain bonhomie. The project kick started careers, fortunes and marriages, and gave the area good roads and a tourist industry.If you haven’t visited the hollow mountain or walked Cruachan’s slopes, make  the year you do.[In bold please] Cruachan: The Hollow Mountain is available from the Argyll Book Centre in Lochgilphead and all good book shops, along with Marian Pallister#s other books of local interest.PICS:The Pass of Brander before work started. no_aCruachanLe before the project # the Loch Awe Hotel with steamers. no_aCruachanThe Queen opening the project in October . no_aCruachanWorking on the  miles of tunnels. no_aCruachanWorking on the road to the dam, overlooking Loch Awe. no_aCruachan

title: coleman and aliyev impress ardrishaig
story: Robert LaceyUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs the lights dimmed in Ardrishaig Hall on Saturday January , and the audience chatter subsided, two young men, dressed entirely in black, strode into view.Jâms Coleman sat at the splendid Yamaha grand piano that for all visiting musicians must be such a relief to see, while Jamal Aliyev carefully set the spike of his special Giovanni Gabrielli Cello , an instrument re-discovered after a -year absence from public performance.Then the music began and the dark first notes of Beethoven’s Cello and Piano Sonata op. no. in G minor filled the hall. It was written for Count Friedrich Wilhelm, supposedly simplied for amateurs to play. However, Jamal and Jâms being master musicians showed the power of this often disregarded piece, to be immense. One of the first works to make piano and cello equal musical partners, it is full of ingenious dialogue between the instruments. The structure is unusual, but with such expert performers it delighted the audience who were moved by every turn and twist of this deeply emotional work.Jâms, from North Wales, after remarking on the three ferry crossings required to get to Ardrishaig via Bute, introduced the next piece, Ernest Bloch’s work ‘From Jewish Le’. In a style close to Jamal’s heart and heritage, having been born in Baku Azerbaijan, its three elements, ‘Prayer’, ‘Supplication’ and ‘Jewish Song’, are full of the pathos and sorrow felt by the Jewish nation and also full of the signature augmented intervals and minor key tonality of much of middle eastern musics. How beautully these pieces demonstrated the lyrical qualities of the cello. Jamal’s bow searched for all possible nuances of tone and dynamic as his instrument sang from its lowest notes to a seductive soprano register.The concert continued after the interval with a second Beethoven work. The audience may have noticed a minor kerfuffle at the piano as many pages were rapidly turned before starting. Would it be the ‘Seven Variations’ for cello and piano or the ‘Twelve’, both based on themes from Mozart’s Magic Flute  The ‘Seven Variations’ won, being on the theme from the ‘Pamina’ and ‘Papageno’ duet entitled ‘In men, who know the feeling of love’. This work exhibits Beethoven’s practised ingenuity in the iation form and brought a lighter mood to the programme.Jâms Coleman introduced the final work, Frank Bridge’s Cello Sonata. He told of the four years of torment for the composer as he struggled to express his feelings about the First World War, finally finishing the composition in . The adagio in the piece caused the composer the most dficulty as he struggled with ambivalence about his own pacist views. Jâms and Jamal dealt with the challenges of this complex work which tracks huge changes in the world of music composition that were under way at that time. Again, the lyrical powers of the cello came to the fore as did the virtuosic requirements heaped on the pianist. Despite its undoubted innovations, this piece generously reaches out to its audience. Bridge uses the new musical freedoms only when justied, being happy toto more traditional tonal stability in the lyrical sections.Fulfilled, but not overburdened by the weightiness of the final piece, the audience applauded Jamal and Jâms back to the concert room to perform the ‘Swan’ from Saint-Saens ‘Carnival of the Animals’ as encore. This piece so beautully confirmed the excellence of Jamal’s playing and the superb quality of his quite special instrument.PIC:Jamal Aliyev and Jâms Coleman. no_aJamalandJam

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby
