title: a kintyre music club review
story: By David O McEwanA pair of internationally recognised musicians visited Campbeltown for Kintyre Music Club#s first concert of .Cellist Jamal Aliyev from Azerbaijan and pianist Jâms Coleman, from Anglesey in North Wales, presented four pieces, at the recent Lorne and Lowland Hall event.The programme featured works by Beethoven Bloch and Bridge.The G minor cello sonata by Beethoven unfolded in typical fashion, with lots of contrasts in mood and speed, and revealed the assured technical and expressive abilities of both performers.Similarly in the Variations by the same composer it was clear that both performers were working as equals rather than as soloist and accompanist.The Bridge Cello Sonata pushed the boundaries of traditional harmonies and structure to the limits but always drew back from total dissonance.Once again the total mastery of their instruments was revealed by the performers.Perhaps the most attractive part of the programme was the #Three pieces from Jewish Le# by Bloch.These captured the spirit and soul of Judaism so well.The Swan by Saint-Saëns concluded the evening as a well-received encore.Cellist Jamal Aliyev and pianist Jâms Coleman with David O McEwan turning the pages during the concert. _cmusicclub_Jamal_Aliyev

title: down memory lane january 25 2019
story: Stephen Laing, assisted by his cousin, Glasgow academic and author Willy Maley, has found details and photographs of his aunt Anne Maley , working in the Women’s Land Army at Glenbarr during the Second World War. Anne passed away in  and her nephew has been researching family history.Stephen, who has posted a set of pictures to the Facebook page ‘Old Campbeltown and Surrounding Area,’ said: ‘Willy is the brains in our family, he’s been a great help to me. I am compiling a family tree and history.‘I have no family link to Kintyre and it was great to find out that my aunt Anne was in this area, at Rosehill Farm, in the war working on one of the farms.’In response to Down Memory Lane’s interest, Willy said: ‘That would make my mammy very happy.’In a short story Anne Maley wrote, one paragraph stated: ‘I never had any fear of animals in the old days. After all I was a land girl during the war. I worked among coos wi’ dangerous looking horns, large Clydesdales with floundering feet, and also a temperamental sheep dug. I never felt threatened.’

title: commuters-yet-again-left-stranded-at-musselburgh-railway-station
story: Robert Keenan, who commutes daily to his IT job with the Church of Scotland in Edinburgh, said the .am train, en route to Edinburghs Haymarket, was full when it arrived at the , and, as far as he could see, no one was able to board it.The train was running with three carriages, as opposed to six, due to the other three carriages requiring maintenance.Mr Keenan, who lives in Musselburgh, said the next train departing Prestonpans at .am was "exceptionally busy" due to a knock-on effect of passengers being unable to board the earlier train, including at those at Wallyford. He said there were no buses laid on for passengers left at Musselburgh.He added: "Four years ago I could get a seat, now I cant even get on the train, and more houses are being built in the area."The route has been dogged with continuing problems such as such as serious overcrowding, frequent delays and cancellations, and problems with ticketing, including broken ticket machines.: ScotRail apologises for unacceptable serviceMr Keenan has now taken his concerns to politicians including the First Minister, Transport Minister and Musselburgh MSP Colin Beattie.He also wrote a letter to the Courier about the issue: read it here.A ScotRail spokesperson said: "Wersquore really sorry to customers who experienced disruption to their journey. We know that one of the biggest concerns is busy trains, and wersquore working hard to deliver the level of service our customers expect."He added that a replacement bus from Prestonpans to Edinburgh was put on, calling at each of the stations along the route to pick up any additional customers.

title: east-lothian-mp-why-i-voted-no-to-prime-ministers-brexit-deal
story: MPs gathered at Westminster yesterday evening to decide the fate of Prime Minister Theresa Mayrsquos EU deal.However, the majority of MPs, including Martin Whitfield, voted against it.Mr Whitfield, who is a strong supporter of a Peoplersquos Vote, told the Courier he had received more than , emails from constituents about the deal, with the overwhelming majority urging him to oppose it and give the public the final say on Brexit.Speaking after the historic Commons vote, which saw  MPs vote against the deal, compared to  voting in favour, Labours Mr Whitfield said: ldquoThe Prime Ministerrsquos deal was bad for East Lothian, bad for Scotland and bad for the UK.ldquoI had no hesitation in voting against it this evening and am glad it was rejected."I am confident that voting against the deal was in accordance with the wishes of the overwhelming majority of my constituents in East Lothian.ldquoMy primary concern now is to ensure we avoid the catastrophic danger posed by a no-deal Brexit, a situation I believe few in Parliament or the country as a whole want to see.ldquoI will work with colleagues to ensure we do not go down that path.ldquoBeyond that, we will see how events unfold over the coming hours and days.ldquoMy own view is that the only fair and democratic way forward is a Peoplersquos Vote to give the public the final say on Brexit.

title: traffic-lights-to-be-put-in-place-at-old-craighall-roundabout
story: The work will be carried out at Old Craighall Roundabout, at the the junction of the A and the City of Edinburgh Bypass A, with sliproads also being widened.The project gets under way on February  and will last for  weeks ndash the roundabout will remain open during the day during the construction phase but will be closed from pm to am each evening with ersions in place.Road operating company Amey says the work will benefit the , vehicles that use the roundabout each day by improving the flow of traffic.Michael Matheson MSP, transport secretary, said: ldquoWe are investing pound.m in the A A as part of Transport Scotlandrsquos strategic road safety programme for the south east.ldquoAmey will be signalising the roundabout and widening a number of slip roads and part of the carriageway.ldquoThis will contribute to improved road safety as priority at the roundabout will be clearer and traffic will be better able to negotiate key parts of the junction.ldquoI want to thank road users in advance for their patience as the works are completed.ldquoWhile there may be some disruption, this will result in a safer and more efficient Old Craighall Roundabout, with reduced hazards and better traffic flows for those travelling on the route.During the evening closures of the roundabout, traffic travelling eastbound on the A will be erted to exit at Millerhill Junction and will join the A. At the A Dalkeith Whitecraig Junction, traffic will join the northbound A and at the next junction will follow signage to join the A and the ersion will end.A westbound traffic will follow the same ersion route in the opposite direction. A traffic travelling towards the A will exit at the A Wallyford Junction and follow the same ersion route.The main A carriageway will remain open throughout the works, and is not affected by the night-time closures.Speed restrictions will be in place at the roundabout during the day.The work has been planned in consultation with Transport Scotland, Traffic Scotland, emergency services, local businesses, and City of Edinburgh, Midlothian and East Lothian councils.

title: quiz-how-comfortable-are-you-financially
story: Researchers asked , adults for the thingstheybelieve mean youre in a good place financially, - which includedhaving pound worth of disposable income to spend every single month.But not all inclusions on the list are material ndash as some adults think being comfortable with money simply means having the ability to make wise decisions when it comes to spending.Others think it is having a good knowledge of financial services on the market, such as pensions, ISArsquos and investments.However, the studyrevealed less than half of those polled would say they are financially comfortable ndash and of these,  per cent are over the age of .Kris Brewster, head of products for Skipton Building Society which commissioned the research, said: ldquoIt is easy to think that being in a good place with money means having a lot, but actually it is more about making sensible decisions when it comes to spending and saving.ldquoDoing your homework about the market, understanding what is happening to money when it is invested, and shopping around for good opportunities are all important regardless of the quantity of money you have.ldquoIn particular, deciding where to keep your money can be one of the most important decisions yoursquoll make, because when your money is in a good place, so are you.Other signs the poll said meant you werefinancially comfortable included getting through the average month without having to dip into savings, and not having to countdown the days until payday.Having a good credit score, knowing how to budget and owning more than one property also feature in the top .Those who are able to buy what they want without worrying, eat out without it having to be a special occasion and buy all the lsquoleading brandsrsquo are also considered to be in a fortunate position with their finances.Of those who are lucky enough to be happy with the state of their finances, more than half feel relaxed, and one quarter say a weight has been lted from their title: in-pictures-dunbar-school-of-dance-christmas-show-performers
story: Dunbar School of Dancing has run a Christmas show each year for the last  years.On each occasion, youngsters aged between three and  have wowed their audience, with money raised going to the Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity.This festive seasonrsquos performances, which took place over three days between December  and  at Dunbar Grammar School, collected a total of pound,..That takes the fundraising total over the last  years to more than pound,.Julie Friar, principal at the dance school, which is based in the townrsquos Hallhill Sports Centre, was delighted with the success of the event once again.She said: ldquoIrsquove been so impressed with how hard everyone has worked this year and was amazed at how fast the tickets sold.ldquoIrsquom so grateful to all the ex-pupils and parents who give up their time to help make the show possible, and Irsquom so proud of all my dancers.ldquoWersquove had a fantastic two weekends of rehearsals and shows and I hope everyone has enjoyed it as much as I have.Funds raised this year will go to a series of interactive projectors, which will provide distraction for children and young people on the wards and in waiting areas, the dental suite and anaesthetic treatment rooms.Each projector will display on walls and ceilings changeable and moving images ldquoto intrigue, excite, surprise and calm children in hospital.According to the charity: ldquoThe projectors will give young patients a practical way to control their immediate environment when all  is seemingly outside of their control. By helping to fund a projector you are helping children in the most clinical of environments engage, relax, have fun with others and distract from pain or worries.All images by Alex Hennessey, proprietor, The Ron Taylor Studio.

title: dunbar-stalker-told-to-stay-away-from-woman-he-repeatedly-filmed
story: David Page followed and filmed the woman for over five years after he had spotted her Labradoodle with his greyhound-cross while he was out on a walk.Page, , used a GoPro camera, a mobile phone and a long-lens camera to intimidate the woman and her family when they took their own dog out for walks in Dunbar.The terried victim was forced to change her dog walking routine and Pagersquos campaign of intimidation eventually came to a stop when he called in the police to complain about the womanrsquos husband shouting at him in the street.He called in police to look at the footage of the abuse he had captured but then incriminated himself after the officers spotted numerous recordings of the woman and her family on his phone.Page denied the allegations but was found guilty of causing fear and alarm to the woman and her family between January  and October  following a trial at Edinburgh Sherf Court last July.He was also found guilty of a separate charge of using abusive language towards employees at East Lothian Council during a phone call on October , .Sherf Alistair Noble had issued Page with a four-year non-harassment order banning him from approaching the woman and deferred full sentence to last Friday.But Page, of Castle Street, missed the hearing after Sherf Alistair Noble was told he had missed his train and would be attending court late.Sherf Noble decided to deal with the case in his absence and deferred sentence for a further six months for Page to adhere to the non-harassment order and be of good behaviour.Page was found guilty of engaging in a course of conduct that caused fear and alarm by repeatedly watching, following and filming the woman and members of her family in Dunbar between January , , and October , , following a summary trial at Edinburgh Sherf Court last July.

title: aberlady-post-office-to-close
story: The High Street facility, which has been run by Ross and Louise Searle for more than  years, is set to close on March , after a bid for a pharmacy to operate alongside the Post Office service was rejected.The Post Office has said it is ldquoinvestigating options about how to retain a Post Office service in the village.Mr and Mrs Searle thanked customers for their support and told the Courier it had been a dficult decision.They said: ldquoThis has been an incredibly dficult and emotional decision for us after  years, as it was always our hope that the Post Office would remain long after our retirement.ldquoFor a number of years, we have been researching sustainable options for the Post Office to continue.ldquoMany of you will know that over three years ago we were approached by Dears Pharmacy with a proposal of operating a pharmacy in the shop premises and running the Post Office alongside.ldquoThis presented an ideal transition ndash Aberlady would have gained a pharmacy and retained the Post Office, a win-win scenario!But with pharmacies in Gullane and Haddington, and high vehicle ownership levels in Aberlady, as well as good transport links, the Dears Pharmacy plan was turned down by Lothian Health Board last May.Despite local support for the idea, the Pharmacy Practices Committeesaid at the time that they felt there were no lsquogapsrsquo in adequacy of pharmaceutical services in the area, and therefore a new one was not needed.This decision was appealed by Gullane Area Community Council but was turned down for a second time last August.Mr and Mrs Searle said ldquono viable alternative to ensure the continuation of the Post Office service has materialised since the decision was taken and they were ldquoleft with no other option than to close.The couple, who live in the village, said: ldquoWe are just going to retire and consider our options. I [Ross] am  and my we will be  this year ndash we are due a break, I would say.James Barbour, co-opted member of the community council for Aberlady, described the news as ldquovery sad to hear.He said: ldquoI have lived in Aberlady for  years and I know first-hand what an important and valued service the Post Office provides.ldquoLocal people will be devastated to see the Post Office close, as it is a central hub in village le.ldquoI know how hard the current team in the Post Office have worked, and I hope, even at this late stage, that the Royal Mail and Post Office Ltd will make it possible for rural Post Offices like ours to continue to provide a vital service which is economically viable.Councillor Jeremy Findlay, North Berwick Coastal ward member, said: ldquoIt is, of course, a huge loss of amenity to Aberlady and the surrounding area.ldquoIn my opinion, it is another example of the Post Office not supporting local rural communities.ldquoIt is also a great shame that the Pharmacy Practices Committee did not support the application for a chemist in the Post Office. That would not only have saved the Post Office but enhanced the village.Iain Gray, MSP for East Lothian, described the news as ldquoa serious blow for the village.He added: ldquoI supported the Dears Pharmacy application as a way to try and help ensure the Post Officersquos future and was bitterly disappointed that it was unsuccessful.ldquoI will contact Post Office Ltd to ask it to explore other options for retaining some level of post office provision in Aberlady.A Post Office spokesman confirmed the upcoming closure.He said: ldquoFollowing the resignation of the postmaster and the withdrawal of premises for Post Office use, Aberlady Post Office will close temporarily on Saturday, March .ldquoWe would like to reassure customers that we are committed to maintaining vital Post Office services for the local community ndash including banking services like cash withdrawals from high street bank accounts, bill payments and, of course, a wide range of postal services.ldquoWe are currently investigating the options available which will enable us to provide a Post Office service to the local community in the future.

title: new-visitor-centre-and-beer-as-belhaven-brewery-celebrates-its-300th
story: A number of events are planned to mark Belhaven Brewery reaching the historic milestone this year.Plans include a pale ale beer called , a weekend music festival at the brewery and the opportunity for customers to win tickets to New York Tartan Week .The brewery, which is owned by Greene King, plans to have a new pound, visitor centre complete by the middle of the summer.Matt Starbuck, managing director, was looking forward to the celebrations and toasting the efforts of John Johnstone, who founded the brewery.He said: ldquoJohn Johnstone would no doubt be delighted to see his beloved brewery today, not only the oldest working brewery in Scotland and the home of Scottish brewing but a thriving innovative business and a great Scottish success story abroad. With  per cent of all Belhaven beer now enjoyed overseas and a market leading position at home, Belhaven has plenty to celebrate.ldquoWe are continuing to invest in Belhaven with a new visitor centre opening this year bringing tourism to Dunbar.Greene King, which acquired Belhaven in , is hosting  days of parties in its pubs and Belhaven-themed parties as far afield as America and Russia.The  modern pale ale launched to celebrate the anniversary of lsquoBelhavenrsquo, which means lsquobeautul bayrsquo, is . percent ABV and has a citrus and tropical fruit character and will be available on cask, keg and in ml bottles throughout this year.Meanwhile, the th birthday will also be marked with a reception at the Scottish Parliament next month, while an Early Day Motion at Westminster will hear about the breweryrsquos long history.Iain Gray, MSP for East Lothian, said: ldquoBelhaven Brewery is an important local employer as well as an internationally-renowned brand.ldquoThe breweryrsquos th anniversary is a signicant milestone and Irsquom very happy to be hosting a Parliamentary reception on behalf of Belhaven to join the celebrations.

title: prominent-peace-campaigner-to-visit-county
story: Former priest Bruce Kent, vice-president of Pax Christi - the international Catholic movement for peace - will speak about its work and introduce Pax Christi Scotland at an event at Our Lady of Loretto Church, Musselburgh tomorrow .Vice-president of Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, he was the organisations chairman - and -, and general secretary, -. During these years, he led CND through its most crucial phase ndash the struggle against cruise missiles ndash and steered it through tumultuous times. He continues to champion a range of Christian and humanitarian causes.The event will get underway with a Mass for Peace and Reconciliation at am, followed by Exposition and Rosary.From .am there will be coffee and registration before Mr Kent speaks about Pax Christi at am. This will be followed by a soup and salad lunch. Closing prayers will take place at .pm.There is no charge but a donation towards the lunch would be appreciated with any surplus after meeting costs going to the Scottish Catholic International Aid Fund .The work of Pax Christi - the Peace of Christ - is based on the gospel and inspired by faith. Its vision is of a world where people can live in peace and without fear of violence in any form. It is rooted in Catholic christianity but is open to all who share its values and work.The movement supports teachers, chaplains and youth workers in promoting a culture of peace in schools and amongst young people. It develops solidarity between people who are working non-violently for justice and peace. This is done through joint actions for peace in Israel-Palestine, events to encourage international efforts to abolish nuclear weapons and by celebrating the le and witness of peacemakers.Pax Christi promotes an understanding of sustainable security where human needs are met and the environment is protected, rather than seeking security through weapons and warfare. It campaigns against military spending, the arms trade and nuclear weapons.Mr Kent will also speak at St Martins RC Church, Tranent, after am Mass on Sunday, and St Gabriels RC Church Hall, Prestonpans, after .am Mass the same day.

title: family-run-north-berwick-business-celebrates-turning-50
story: Turnbullrsquos Home Hardware has been on High Street for half a century.Lawrence Turnbull was a partner at the business on  High Street for a number of years before taking it over in January .His son David joined the business in  and is still at the helm, with a second store on Dunbar High Street opening four years later.David told the Courier: ldquoI am incredibly lucky because I more recently, the vast amount and ever-increasing number of online shoppers.Lawrence passed away in , shortly before the Dunbar store underwent a sizeable refurbishment.The business then joined the Home Hardware buying group, something David, who still lives in North Berwick, felt had made a massive dference.He said: ldquoTo mark the occasion, we are giving  per cent off everything for one week from Saturdayin both stores to celebrate our -year anniversary and thank everyone for supporting us through the years.Now,  people are employed across the two stores, including Davidrsquos son and daughter Harvey, , and Lois, , who attend North Berwick High School.Ward councillor Jim Goodfellow congratulated the business on reaching the impressive milestone.He said: ldquoThe Turnbull family title: man-hauled-woman-back-into-car-as-she-was-trying-to-get-out
story: John McDonald, , seized the woman by the hair and pushed her face into the steering wheel of the car that the pair were travelling in last January.McDonald then placed his hands around the womanrsquos neck and pulled her back into the car as she tried to get out at Buccleuch Street in Edinburgh.He then went on to brandish a chair at a man and challenged him to fight during the incident on January  last year.McDonald, of Caponhall Drive, appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where he admitted the two charges.A not guilty plea to assaulting the woman by punching her to the face was accepted by the Crown.Sherf Alison Stirling decided to defer sentence on McDonald to February  for the preparation of a social work report and for a restriction of liberty order assessment to be carried out.

title: bid-to-create-additional-870-new-tenancies-in-east-lothian-and-more-affordable-housing
story: The local authority has created a blueprint to cut homeless numbers as part of a government-funded project to promote rapid rehousing across Scotland.However, the money required to get the plan up and running is more than a third of the entire fund set aside by the Scottish Government.Included in East Lothian Councilrsquos ambitious five-year plan are  more new tenancies than already planned, an additional  affordable housing units, and a move to turn  temporary units into permanent accommodation.Presenting their draft plan to the local authorityrsquos cabinet meeting for approval on Tuesday, housing chiefs said it was imperative they received the full pound.million they were bidding fortheir plans were to succeed.Their proposals would see new tenancies used to help reduce the maximum number of days spent in bed and breakfasts for all households to just seven days ndash and reduce theof stay in temporary accommodation to a maximum of nine months.Councillor Norman Hampshire acknowledged that the entire Scottish Government fund available to all local authorities to bid for was just pound million.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoOf the pound million available across the whole of Scotland we are looking for pound million.Cabinet approved the draft plan for a lsquorapid rehousingrsquo approach to transform the use of temporary accommodation and improve outcomes for homeless households in East Lothian by March  as an important step towards tackling homelessness in the county.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesperson for housing and community wellbeing, said: ldquoThe draft plan aims to make a meaningful, although realistic impact by , in respect of addressing homelessness and improving the lives of some of our most vulnerable people across the county.ldquoWe look forward to the governmentrsquos assessment of our long-term plans and clarity on available funding from central government to support the transition to rapid rehousing.The plan recognises that some vulnerable households with multiple needs beyond housing may require additional support to sustain a tenancy.East Lothian Council says it has already made good progress in tackling homelessness in recent years, with a  per cent success rate in preventing homelessness.According to the council, there has been a  per cent reduction in homelessness presentations since  as a result of early intervention work.The supply of affordable housing is key to reducing homelessness, the local authority maintains, and it says , new affordable homes have been delivered in East Lothian since , of which  are new council homes for social rent.A further , new affordable homes are to be delivered over the next five years through the Draft Strategic Housing Investment Plan, supported by new housing land supply set out in the newly adopted East Lothian Local Development Plan.

title: landslip-forces-closure-of-section-of-popular-john-muir-way-path
story: The John Muir Way, which links Dunbar to Helensburgh on Scotlandrsquos west coast, was opened in April .However, a section of it in Dunbar has been closed following the landslip, which is believed to have been caused by a burst pipe, with East Lothian Council now looking to carry out repairs.The section of the walk affected is from the townrsquos swimming pool to the war memorial, with walkers urged instead to head along Bayswell Park, rather than following the clftop trail.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed they were aware of the issue.She said: "Specialist engineers will be coming out to make an assessment and to see what can be done."They will then give us an idea of costings and whether it could be done sooner or later."Until the engineers carry out their assessment, there is no timescale on when the path could be re-opened.

title: plan-to-ban-lorries-from-section-of-a1-in-high-winds
story: Amey, which maintains the road network for Transport Scotland, has confirmed it is drawing up plans to introduceweather-related ersions for HGVs and high-sided vehicles between Dunbar and Haddington.The move follows a string of incidents in which lorries have been blown over as they cross the exposed Tyne Bridge, near East Linton, in high winds.Chief Inspector Steven Duncan, police commander for East Lothian, said he raised concerns after two such incidents last year.The section of the A has seen several incidents during bad weather when lorries have been blown on to their sides, leading to the route being closed and ersions introduced from Thistly Cross Roundabout at Dunbar to Haddington.Under the new proposals, that ersion, which uses the old A and the A, would be automatically brought into force when winds were recorded at above mph.It would take lorries on a near-parallel single-carriage route which is the sameas the .-mile section of A they are being erted from.The chief inspector told a meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos Police and Fire Community Safety Committee he had made tackling the dangers on the route a priority.He said: ldquoThere is a wind management plan in place. I have been concerned that two vehicles were blown over last year at the Tyne Bridge.ldquoWe have identied a nice, easy ersion to implement and are looking to have a plan in place to drive that forward.Transport Scotland said it had asked Amey to look into the proposals, which could see permanentsigns in place to advise lorry drivers when they should use the ersion.A spokesperson for Amey said: ldquoThe Tyne Wind Management Plan is being developed following a number of incidents of high-sided vehicles being blown over near to the Tyne Bridge. The development of this plan has been prioritised after discussion with police.ldquoAs a vulnerable location, the plan proposes implementing a ersion for HGVs and other high-sided vehicles when wind gusts are in excess of mph.ldquoThe route being used is a standard agreed ersion, using the A and the old A, which runs parallel to the A expressway.Last year, an HGV lorry driver was disqualied from driving for two years and fined pound, after he ignored a ban on high-sided vehicles crossing the Forth Road Bridge during gales and his vehicle was blown over, blocking it for  hours.

title: plans-to-build-houses-near-to-prestonpans-railway-station
story: LAR Housing Trust is aiming to create the new properties, which could be in place by spring next year, in a similar style to their recently-completed development in nearby Cockenzie.The development, which is being considered by East Lothian Council, would be created on the site of the former Lothian Coated Fabrics building and next to the eastbound  at the neighbouring railway station.LAR Housing Trust, which is an affordable housing provider, plans to create affordable housing on the site, which it will operate as  per cent affordable mid-market rent.Plans with the local title: wallyford-primary-school-open-day-hailed-a-resounding-success
story: Alister Hadden praised the parent council, which organised the event on Saturday, as everyone enjoyed a trip down memory lane.School photographs from the s to the present day were on display at the Salters Road school as staff and pupils prepare to move into a new pound. million facility being built to cope with the influx of new housing in the area.Mr Hadden said that visitors of all ages queued for the opening of the school doors at .am, adding: ldquoThere was a constant steady flow of people and families, along with former teachers, to see the vast amount of photos that were on display.The photos also featured the former Crookston School, which closed in  .Mr Hadden, a former Crookston pupil, added: ldquoOn display were also trophies with many of the former pupilsrsquo names on them.ldquoPeople got the opportunity to take a trip around the school to see their old classroom, in some cases for the first time in  years. Visitors also enjoyed coffee, soft drinks, cake and biscuits served by members of the parent council.ldquoThe open day gave dozens of people the opportunity to meet classmates they had not seen for numerous years.ldquoThey all thoroughly enjoyed catching up with each other and many iniduals took along their own photos of their memories at Wallyford over the decades.The open day was also supported by local councillors and keen photographer Angus Bathgate, from Wallyford, who caught the event on camera for posterity.Mr Hadden said: ldquoAll the organisers and those who contributed with memorabilia are to be congratulated for all their hard work, time and effort in bringing this event together.ldquoThanks also to everyone who came and supported this Wallyford Primary School open day, making it such a memorable, successful occasion before its doors close.Pauline Clark, parent council representative, said: ldquoWhat a day it was. There were so many stories and so many happy people. It was a great success.Ward councillor Kenny McLeod added: ldquoI attended P at Wallyford Primary School as I stayed on Salters Road before moving to Tranent.ldquoI played in the grounds of the school as I grew up and kept being chased by the janitor whose house looked on to the school. The children and teachers of Wallyford Primary will be super excited and looking forward to the attending the new school.The existing school will soon close and move to the new building, which is nearing completion on the outskirts of the village on Futurersquos Way at the St Clements Wells development.The Wallyford school project has received a pound. million grant from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Schools for the Future scheme.The new school comes amid the construction of , new houses in the Wallyford area, while the council is minded to grant planning permission for another  homes at Dolphingstone to the east of the existing site, subject to conclusion of the relevant legal agreements.

title: chance-to-get-a-tour-of-dunbar-grammar-schools-new-extension

the event, which enforces the importance of the school as part of our community.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, East Lothian Councilrsquos cabinet spokeswoman for education, said: ldquoPupils and staff were title: fundraisers-set-to-climb-mount-kilimanjaro-in-memory-of-vera-cameron
story: Nine men and women jet off to Tanzania todayas they bid to raise thousands of pounds for Cancer Research UK in memory of Macmerryrsquos Vera Cameron.Among the fundraisers getting ready to climb Mount Kilimanjaro are her husband Dougie and daughter Laura-Jane.Dougie said: ldquoWersquove spoken about doing Kilimanjaro for years so wersquore really excited to finally be able to take on the challenge. Wersquore so grateful for everyonersquos support over the years and helping us raise such a fantastic amount for Cancer Research in Verarsquos memory ndash wersquore hoping to smash the pound, mark this year. I would also like to thank the team for taking part year after year, covering costs themselves and giving up their weekends to train.Dougie, who is site attendant at Kinwegar Recycling Centre, by Wallyford, will be joined by seven colleagues from East Lothian Council, where Vera worked as senior administrator in transportation at the local authority.Ray Montgomery , Paul Ritchie , Lorraine Faulds , William Kelley , Stuart Baxter , Rachael Cormackand Vanessa Sanalare also taking on the challenge. The team will attempt to reach the summit and descend the near-,-metre peak in just seven days. As well as the climb and adjusting to the altitude, the fundraisers will also have to deal with extreme temperatures, ranging from degC to -degC.Vera was  when she died from cancer in August . She attended the villagersquos primary school before studying at Ross High School, Tranent, and later joined East Lothian District Council.Following her death, fundraisers have been held each year in aid of Maggiersquos Centres, Macmillan Cancer Support and Cancer Research UK.In previous years, fundraisers have completed other gruelling challenges, including the West Highland Way, which stretches from Milngavie to Fort William , and climbed the highest peaks in Scotland, England and Wales ndash Ben Nevis, Scafell Pike and Snowdon.Along the way, they have raised pound,, with pound, now the target.Donate at justgiving fundraising vera-kilimanjaro

title: union-calls-east-lothian-councils-severe-weather-policy-disgraceful
story: East Lothian Council reviewed its adverse weather policy following criticism of its advice in the wake of last yearrsquos lsquoBeast from the Eastrsquo snow storm.However, its new policy insists the council ndash which has , employees ndash will continue to dock the pay of workers who cannot get to workstorms hit.And it suggests those living in rural areas ldquomay wish to consider holding back some of their annual leave for events such as adverse weather.Councillor Jeremy Findlay , North Berwick Coastal ward, told a meeting of the councilrsquos cabinet on Tuesday: ldquoI have a moral problem with someone who lives in the rural county where roads are under two feet of snow being adversely affected when they are being told by police they should not travel and, as a result, their wages will be docked.While Raising his concerns about the revised policy, Mr Findlay said: ldquoI have a moral problem with someone who lives in the rural county where roads are under two feet of snow being adversely affected when they are being told by police they should not travel and as a result their wages will be docked.Gillian McKay, Unite regional industrial officer, said: ldquoThe decision by East Lothian Council is disgraceful.ldquoThe Scottish Government has issued guidance on this for all employers advising there should not be any compromise on the health, safety and wellbeing of workers.ldquoEvery allowance should be made for workers who cannot make work due to severe weather conditions. This includes working from home and flexible working practices to ensure that nobody should lose pay or holidays.ldquoThe move by East Lothian appears to be nothing other than an exercise in saving money and will not go unchallenged.At Tuesdayrsquos meeting in Haddington, the councilrsquos chief executive Angela Leitch told councillors thatstaff could not fulfil their contract, the council ldquocould not pay them.Anger over the way the council handled last yearrsquos severe snow storms led councillors to overturn a long-standing policy on absences and agree to pay workers who had been unable to get into work.Many workers were stunned to be told that, while police were warning people to stay at home, the council was continuing with its established policy advising them they would have to take time in lieu or unpaid leave to cover the time they were unable to work.While other local authorities, including City of Edinburgh Council, took to social media to assure staff they would be paidthey were unable to work during the Wednesday and Thursday of the red weather warnings last March, East Lothian Council repeated its advice that workers should report to workit was ldquosafe to do so, or attend the nearest council office or suitable premises, or work from home or other suitable locations.Following a review, wages were reinstated for those who missed work during red weather warnings and the policy was reviewed.Councillor Willie Innes , council leader, said he expected that, should another Beast from the East hit the county, councillors would once again step in to ensure wages were not docked.He said: ldquoIt is impossible to have a policy that pleases everyone. Last year, members took the decision to pay staff ndash I would hopeit happened again we would consider making similar commitments.South of Scotland list MSP Michelle Ballantynecondemned the policy, saying: ldquoIt is completely unacceptable for East Lothian Council to tell their employees to save their holiday time in case of bad weather. It beggars belief that any employer would be this unreasonable. I will be writing to Willie Innes about how deeply unfair his cabinet have been to hardworking council staff.A statement issued on Wednesday by Ms Leitch, the councilrsquos chief executive, said: ldquoThe policy has been refreshed following last yearrsquos severe wintry weather.ldquoThe updated policy reflects feedback following staff consultation, and is consistent with the approach taken by many other public sector organisations.ldquoIt reflects the councilrsquos commitment to protecting the health and safety of all employees, while minimising disruption and maintaining key public services where possible.ldquoIt recognises that employees may periodically face dficulties in attending work during periods of severe weather, or some other adverse event. The policy makes it clear that staff should only travelit is safe to do so.ldquoThe updated policy contains additional advice for staff on what to do in such unusual circumstances.ldquoThe key aspect of the updated policy is to stress the importance of Business Continuity Plans for each council service which advise on what employees should do in any adverse event ndash including potential alternative working arrangements for employeesthey canrsquot get to their normal place of work.ldquoThis includes working remotely or being deployed near to where they live as an alternative.

title: tims-tales-through-the-keyhole
story: RECENTLY a friend and fellow storyteller with his family took me and my family on a simple but stunning walk along the shoreline of Dunbar. It was a cold day but my friend, who is skilled in bushcraft, had brought his portable fire pit with him.We searched for drtwood and sat by the fire, roasting marshmallows and warming our hands. It was a short walk but dramatic rock formations loomed above us, making it feel like a real adventure. The kids climbed them and explored the rocky beach, where once there had been an open-air bathing pool.On our , we went through a small tunnel-like arch. I stopped for a moment, suddenly taken by the view. The ruins of Dunbar Castle were beautully framed by the archway. Locals call this archway the keyhole and I reflected that the term is a perfect name.When we look through a keyhole, our vision is narrowly focussed. Such was the effect here. It cast a visual spotlight on what is left of what was once a mighty fortress.The kids trundled on before me, noticing smaller wonders: a frozen worm on the path, a sea shell and interesting-looking stones. But I stood for some moments, taking in the view beyond and thinking of what stories those old stones of the castle could tell.Many people pass this way every day, both locals and visitors. Itrsquos a section of the John Muir Way. I have often been with my family to Dunbar Leisure Pool and the harbour and town. But somehow I had missed this short but spectacular nearby walk until this day.Dunbar Castle is now but a fallen-down ruin. Indeed, itrsquos dficult to imagine what it once was. But the weathered sandstone castles on the shoreline built by nature still stand defiant, somehow reminding us of their greater permanence in the face of human transience. But as I stood looking at the ruins, the keyhole focussed my thoughts as well as my vision.History is also viewed through a keyhole, a very narrow one. The lives and events of the castle were lived in most part unrecorded by it. The spotlight of history has illuminated only brief moments, and even then the characters have been only those deemed lsquoimportantrsquo.There are moments where the view through the narrow keyhole of history has included insights to untold stories. The bravery of Black Agnes, as she defied the siege in , is one of those. With her husband away, she was in charge of this important fortress during war with England. She refused to give up the castle, even in the face of bombardment and attempts to starve her small garrison into submission. Her mocking of her besiegers by dusting down the battlements with her maids after a bombardment is an image seared in legend.But itrsquos a chink of light on a huge untold story we are led to believe by historyrsquos silence that women were insignicant players in events. For sure they were oppressed and put down by a system that centred on male power, but they are half of humanity and at least half the story.As the actions of Black Agnes reveal, even with such constraints put on them, women were there, part of events and often refusing to accept their assigned role.The le of Mary Queen of Scots has always been for me an example of this. Yes, she was privileged and powerful by birth, but because of this history took notice of her.Despite all the political and religious challenges she faced, it was her womanhood which men deemed her main failing. And so she was judged by dferent standards. Had she behaved with the morals of her father she would not have lasted five minutes in power. But no one raised an eyebrow because he was a man.But more than this, even though Mary was the monarch, her royal authority was deemed diluted and even less legitimate merely because she was a woman.So she understood she needed to find a husband to bring her royal authority to full strength in a country full of powerful and bullying misogynist men.She chose the dashing young Darnley, and the fact that he turned out to be dross was not, in my opinion, Maryrsquos fault. How easy it is to blame a woman for a manrsquos failings. She was taken in by him it was he who was the failure, not her.Thatrsquos what Irsquove always maintained, despite the protestations of my tutors at university. And her third husband Bothwell, well he was a disappointment as well.It is the stones of Dunbar,they could speak, who could tell us of the truth of his forced union with Mary. She had been taken there by him in April . The circumstances of this still remain debated. Was she abducted by him as later claimed, or did she go willingly It was also claimed she was raped and forced to marry Bothwell soon afterwards to save her honour . This idea has been disputed by some because Mary is said to have miscarried with twins while imprisoned at Lochleven Castle some months after, suggesting a relationship with Bothwell even before Darnleyrsquos murder. So a woman cannot be abused by a man she has had a relationship with  Really If they could talk, the stones of Dunbar would whisper the truths of those events in , and the despair and desperation of a strong and clever woman whose destiny was stolen mainly because of her sex.These were my thoughts as I stood looking through the keyhole towards Dunbar Castle. Suddenly, my daughter Manja broke my trance by wiggling the frozen worm in front of me. I smiled and thought to myself that thankfully times have changed since the days when the castle was a fortress.But sometimes, I fear, not as much as we think they have.

title: new-fidra-gin-hoping-for-east-lothian-base
story: Fidra Gin is the brainchild of Emma Bouglet and Jo Brydie and is currently based at Ballencrieff and Aviemore.The duo came together to create the juniper berry-based drink and have already enjoyed immediate success, with the product already available in a number of Edinburgh restaurants.Now they are hoping to make it  per cent based in the county, with plans under way to find suitable premises.Emma said: ldquoWe pick all the botanicals in East Lothian and, at the moment, we use a still in Aviemore.ldquoA friend has lent us his still for the time being so we can get enough momentum behind us and bring the whole operation to East Lothian.ldquoWe have potentially secured a premise in East Lothian. We are hoping to purchase a couple of stills so the whole operation is based in East Lothian.ldquoWe have had health and safety out and given it the go-ahead but there are a few bits and pieces to be sorted.The duo aim to have the new distillery open before the end of the year.Before Christmas, Emma and Jo, , were in the process of getting more than  bottles ready.Emma was delighted to say that had proven a great success, with the bottles selling out within a matter of hours after they were launched.Since then, more than  bottles have been produced and sold.Emma said their Scottish dry gin was ldquovery botanical and added: ldquoIt is quite a smooth gin, with a hint of sea buckthorn.The move into the gin business is something of a departure from their day jobs, with the duo aiming to make it their full-time business.Emma used to work as an investment banker before switching to becoming a childminder, while Jo runs her freelance podiatry from Longniddry, occasionally working in the local clinic, and before then she worked at Musselburgh Racecourse.Emma, , said: ldquoMe and Jo have known each other for years. Our kids are very good friends and my husband ndash who owns a wine company in Fe ndash knew Jo from her time at the racecourse.

title: traffic-island-plan-on-tranent-road-where-woman-was-knocked-down
story: East Lothian Council is considering introducing the safety measure on Edinburgh Road.Last month, an elderly woman was struck by a car in the area and was taken to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh with shoulder injuries.The crossing would be near the bus stop used by people travelling from Tranent into Edinburgh.The idea of a traffic island was highlighted at the townrsquos community council meeting last Tuesday.Councillor Kenny McLeod, who lives nearby, was hopeful a solution could be reached. He said: ldquoIt is people getting the bus to Edinburgh. You get a lot of people crossing the road from the Bankpark side ndash that is where there is a problem.Mr McLeod also noted that traffic islands had been introduced further along the street, near Stair Park and Polson Gardens, for people to cross.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe were aware of interest in a possible traffic island at this location prior to the incident.ldquoThe process for the introduction of such a measure is to assess the road layout , possible usage and whether other crossing points are nearby.ldquoAt this stage transportation officials are investigating the suitability of a new traffic island at this location but not at planning stages.

title: well-known-late-haddington-resident-to-be-honoured-with-street-name
story: Vera Ingle ndash who passed away in  ndash was well-known in Haddington for her fundraising efforts for good causes.Now, East Lothian Council has confirmed that Vera Ingle Grove will make up part of the townrsquos new Letham Mains development.Her son Charles felt his mum was a very worthy choice.He said: ldquoWe are delighted, absolutely delighted.ldquoI had an indication it would be Vera Ingle Grove sometime ago and I know the idea was put forward by the community council, who have done a great job.ldquoThe response has been quite overwhelming and it has been lovely to see a lot of what has been said on social media.More than  new homes are being built on the townrsquos western edge as part of the development, which will also include a new primary school.Mr Ingle, a former Haddington councillor, said: ldquoThe reality is a lot of people knew my mother. She was a community person and that is quite important to a lot of people.ldquoSometimes we forget about community or scoff at it, but a lot of people still think it is important.ldquoShe to some extent exemplied the good qualities associated with that and the work she did within the town for local and national charities.Vera, who had six children,  grandchildren and four great-granddaughters, was most associated with raising funds for the poppy appeal.However, she also helped raise money for the day centre, Haddington Pipe Band, Red Cross and to fight multiple sclerosis among others.Previously, Mr Ingle said: ldquoThere is not a charity in the town, from the day centre to any other, that did not benefit from her.John Hamilton, treasurer of the community council, previously asked members of the public for key figures in Haddingtonrsquos history who could have streets named after them.He said: ldquoVera was one of lersquos endearing characters, known by many with her time in the Corn Exchange and her charity fundraising with her collection box out on the streets. Irsquom sure her family, friends and everyone  who knew her will be proud of this recognition.Ward councillor Tom Trotter was similarly pleased with the announcement.He said: ldquoIf we are going to be naming streets after people, real people who made a dference in the community, then she certainly did that on numerous occasions.ldquoShe was a bit of a character and it is fantastic that she will be recognised in this manner.ldquoI think it is only right we remember people from the past but also it is right to celebrate people that made a dference presently.Provost John McMillan added: ldquoMany people in Haddington will have fond memories of Vera and her extensive charity fundraising efforts and involvement in many of the townrsquos clubs and organisations.ldquoNaming new streets in recognition of former residents offers some continuity in the growing town and will hopefully inspire some of our newer residents to find out more of Haddingtonrsquos history and community le.

title: great-grandmother-who-ran-drem-post-office-pens-her-life-story
story: May Fairbairn, who was born in Orkney but went to school in Morham, decided to write the story of her le to ensure her great grandchildren knew all about her.The -year-old spent three months putting together Neeps, Horses and Parcels, which is available to buy at Kesleyrsquos bookshop, Haddington.She said: ldquoWhat inspired me was I had thought about doing it for about  years.ldquoI now have four great-grandchildren and I am .ldquoIt was to have something left for my great grandchildren.ldquoMy great grandmother ndash I would have loved to have known what she did. It has really taken off beyond what I ever thought it would.Mrs Fairbairnrsquos family are originally from Orkney however, they moved to the mainland when she was four with her father John Robson finding work in Midlothian and then moving to East Lothian.Despite her long time away from Orkney, Mrs Fairbairn, who ran the Post Office in Drem for more than  years, where she now stays, felt the islands and East Lothian were very much home.Away from the Post Office, she also taught at The Compass School in Haddington, and volunteered at the townrsquos Roodlands Hospital, as well as at Appin Equestrian Centre, near Drem, which is run by her daughter Anne.She said: ldquoI have a lot of self-belief in myself and a lot of determination, which I inherited from my father. I was just looking for the next opportunity.Already, the autobiography has proven popular with family members, including daughters Anne and Fiona.Throughout writing the book, May kept it a secret from her family but was pleased to say it had met with a positive reception.May added her family were ldquovery proud and said: ldquoThey have been very, very supportive and my grandson and everyone, they have all been behind me.ldquoThey thought it was a marvellous surprise to them all.However, it was after retiring from running the Post Office that May decided tolsquohomersquo and to visit Orkney.She said: ldquoWhen I go up there, I feel Orkney is home.ldquoThere is just something that tells me thatI had not been widowed, I would certainly be up running a bed and breakfast.

title: woman-left-shaken-after-being-flashed-at-by-three-youths-in-underpass
story: Police are appealing for witnesses following the incident at about .pm on the A underpass, near Meadowmill Sports Centre, which left the victim "very shaken".The woman was walking towards Prestonpans from the Tranent area when she came across a group of about  youths - both males and females - aged between  and  years old.As she continued to walk through the underpass, three youths approached her and exposedthemselves at her.The victim was uninjured and fled from the scene. Officers are now appealing for witnesses and anyone with information is asked to come forward.Inspector Kevin Sinclair from Dalkeith Police Station said: ldquoThis has been a frightening experience for the victim who was thankfully uninjured but understandably very shaken by the ordeal.ldquoThis sort of behaviour is completely unacceptable. I would ask anyone who witnessed the group of youths in this area last night, or the incident in the underpass, to come forward to help with our investigation.ldquoAnyone who may be able to identy those involved, or have any information to help us trace them, should call us as soon as possible.The first suspect is described as white, ft ins tall, about  years old, of medium build with blond hair that had curls at the front. He was wearing black tracksuit bottoms, trainers and a black hoodie.The second is described as a white male, of slim build, with dark brown hair and was wearing black jogging bottoms, a black scarf over his mouth and a black hoodiewith writing on the front, possibly lsquoNorth Face.rsquoThe third suspect is described as a white male, smaller and younger than the others involved, wearing grey jogging bottoms and a black hoodie.Anyone with information shouldcontact Police Scotland on , quoting incident number  of  January, or Crimestoppers anonymously on   .

title: may-faces-latest-commons-test-as-mps-bid-to-shape-brexit
story: Amid an ongoing revolt among backbenchers and her DUP allies, the Prime Minister has swung behind a motion amendment that would allow her to go back to Brussels and seek changes to the Irish border backstop.She will whip MPs to support the amendment tabled by  Committee chairman Sir Graham Brady, which states that Parliament would be willing to support the Withdrawal Agreement reached with the EUldquoalternative arrangements were found to avoid a hard border.The dramatic move is far from guaranteed to deliver a majority for the plan after it failed to win the support of the influential European Research Groupof Conservative Eurosceptics, who have not ruled out voting against it.There is also the small matter of the amendment being called by Commons Speaker John Bercow on Tuesday morning, although his hand may be swayed by the number of MPs backing it already.Tory grandee Sir Graham said he hoped House of Commons backing would give Mrs May ldquoenormous firepower when she s to Brussels to seek concessions on her Brexit deal.But the chairman of the ERG, Jacob Rees-Mogg, said its members, thought to number at least , will not support the scheme.Meanwhile, late on Monday evening it emerged a new Brexit plan had been put forward which is reportedly backed by members of both the Remain and Leave camps of the Conservative party.The plan ndash called the The Malthouse Compromise after Kit Malthouse, the MP who brought the parties together ndash would lead to Britain leaving the EU ldquoon time and with a ing government, former Brexit minster Steve Baker said.ldquoThe Malthouse Compromise after @kitmalthouse, who brought us togetherWe need to get out of the EU on time and with a ing government.This is how. #Brexit https:t.co mBvmdkXmdash Steve Baker MPJanuary , Said to be drawn up by Nicky Morgan and supported by others, the plan reportedly ldquoprovides for exit from the EU on time with a new backstop, which would be acceptable indefinitely, but which incentivises us all to reach a new future relationship.It would extend the transition period ndash the period where the UK would continue to follow EU rules and pay into its budget ndash from the end of  and into December  which would ldquoallow both parties to prepare properly for WTO terms, but also provide a period in which the parties could obviate this outcome by negotiating a mutually beneficial future relationship.Mrs May addressed MPs in Westminster on the eve of a day of high drama, when MPs will debate a range of rival amendments, including calls to block a no-deal departure or delay Brexit from its scheduled date of March .Conservative chairman Brandon Lewis, who confirmed the whipping after the meeting, said the Brady amendment would ldquoallow the Prime Minister to give a very clear message around what Parliament wants, where the party is.He said: ldquoI would hope the ERG, when they look at this and actually look through the detail of what this gives the PM tomorrow,it is about giving a message to Europe about what can go through Parliament in terms of dealing with the backstop issue and why that matters.Mr Lewis confirmed that the Government would whip against an amendment co-sponsored by one of its own MPs, Nick Boles, which seeks to extend the Article  period to avoid a no-deal Brexit.Despite the manoeuvring in Westminster, in Brussels the EU, officially at least, remained resolute that the Withdrawal Agreement would not be reopened.Chief EU negotiator Michel Barnierrsquos deputy Sabine Weyand warned there was a ldquohigh risk of the UK crashing out by accident, as it was ldquoquite a challenge to see how a majority could be constructed at Westminster.European Commission vice-president Jyrki Kateinen said there was ldquono reason to give any concessions to the UK and there was ldquonot much room for manoeuvre on the backstop.It would be ldquostupid for the EU to make concessions putting the remaining  members at a disadvantage simply to secure a deal, he said.Downing Street said the PM remains committed to quitting the EU on March  and will take her plan back to the Commons for a second ldquomeaningful vote as soon as possible after Tuesdayrsquos debate.The developments came as major supermarkets and fast-food chains warned that a no-deal Brexit would force up prices and reduce the choice and quality of produce for shoppers.In a joint letter, bosses of firms including Sainsbury, Asda, KFC and McDonaldrsquos said: ldquoWe anticipate signicant risks to maintaining the choice, quality and durability of food that our customers have come to expect in our stores, and there will be inevitable pressure on food prices from higher transport costs, currency devaluation and tarfs.

title: over-half-of-detained-boys-from-black-or-minority-ethnic-backgrounds-report
story: The percentage of BME detainees was the highest recorded since HM Inspectorate of Prisons began carrying out the analysis in .The % figure increased from % in the previous year.Researchers found that the proportion of boys who identied as being from a black or minority ethnic background ied depending on the establishment, from one in fiveat the Keppel Unit, to nearly three quartersat Feltham.The figures are detailed in a study on the perceptions of those aged between  and  who were held in YOIs or secure training centresin England and Wales from April  to March .Black and minority ethnic children accounted for % of the STC population, according to the paper.The percentage identying as being from a BME background ied between centres, from % at Oakhill to % at Medway.In , a landmark review by Labour MP David Lammy raised concerns that the proportion of black, Asian and minority ethnic youth prisoners had increased despite an overall fall in under-s in custody.Commenting on the latest findings, Mr Lammy said: ldquoThis is deeply alarming and now must be viewed as an urgent national crisis.ldquoWe are not only failing to make progress to address these racial inequalities things are getting signicantly worse.ldquoFrom childhood right through to courts and adult prisons, our justice system entrenches and exacerbates the ides in our society.Frances Crook, chief executive of the Howard League for Penal Reform, said: ldquoFor the first time, more than half of boys in prison identy as being from a black or minority ethnic background.ldquoSixteen months after the Lammy Review was published, it is disturbing that disproportionality it is growing.Between ndash and ndash, the number of children, including -year-olds, held in YOIs, STCs and secure childrenrsquos homes fell by %, from , to , according to HMIPrsquos report.The assessment, to be published on Tuesday, covers the experiences of boys in five male YOIs, plus a specialist unit for boys, and children, including a small number of girls, held in three STCs.The watchdog warned that too many youngsters feel unsafe while in custody, saying signs of improvement have yet to translate into a signicant sht in childrenrsquos perceptions of their treatment and conditions.HMIPrsquos analysis, based on a survey of  children detained in -, found just over a thirdof those held in STCs reported feeling unsafe at some point since arriving at the centre, while the figure was % for YOIs.In other findings:ndash More than half of childrenin STCs and % in YOIs reported that they had been physically restrained in their establishment.ndash Three in  STC respondentshad been victimised by other children by being shouted at through windows.ndash Children in STCs were more likely to report that staff treated them with respect .Publishing the report, Chief Inspector of Prisons Peter Clarke said: ldquoI trust that the details of this report will prove useful to those whose responsibility it is to provide safe, respectful and purposeful custody for children.ldquoAs we all know, the perceptions of children in custody, will, for them, be the reality of what is happening.ldquoThat is why we should not allow the recent improvement in inspection findings to give rise to complacency.A Ministry of Justice spokesman said: ldquoWe are fundamentally reforming youth custody to make it safer and more focused on rehabilitation and, as the Chief Inspector recognises, there have been encouraging signs of improvement in safety.ldquoAs part of our reforms, we are increasing frontline staff in public-sector YOIs by %, improving training for officers working with young people, and have recently announced a pound million investment in a new secure school at Medway.ldquoBut we recognise there is still more to do, including tackling disproportionality in the justice system, and a dedicated team is addressing this issue head-on.

title: oil-and-gas-domino-effect-fuels-surge-in-insolvencies-in-scotland
story: Official figures published yesterday show the number of business entering liquidation increased  per cent last year to a six year high of , from  in .Restructuring specialists said the increase reflected the lsquodomino effectrsquo of the oil and gas downturn on sectors such as hospitality combined with pressures on consumer spending.Read more: Jobs go as oil and gas downturn claims Aberdeen hotelWith uncertainty about Brexit weighing on confidence and prompting some firms to stockpile, the challenges facing firms may be set to intensy.Noting the number of corporate insolvencies in  was the highest since  and the fourth highest ever, Eileen Blackburn of French Duncan accountants warned: ldquoI think that many more Scottish firms will go bust until greater stability can be established in the Scottish economy.Ms Blackburn said the increase in insolvencies last year was a great concern noting that it occurred despite interest rates and unemployment sitting at or close to record lows.Read more:  redundant as plumber goes into liquidationShe noted the continuing impact of uncertainty over Brexit and the consequent fall in investment. This has been compounded by the sht in consumer spending online, which has weighed on high street retailers.Highlighting continuing confusion over the UKrsquos future relationship with Europe, she said firms with close economic ties to the EU or who rely heavily on European staff in areas such as hospitality, retail, and agriculture will be under pressure.Tim Cooper, chair of the R insolvency and restructuring trade body in Scotland, said while the increase in liquidations last year was concerning, the figures may not show the whole picture. They do not include firms entering administration or agreeing company voluntary arrangements with creditors.Read more: Hotel in Scottish village pushed into administration by oil sector woeldquoIn general, Rrsquos members in Scotland are reporting increased activity, across a iety of sectors, said Mr Cooper. ldquoThis indicates that market conditions are bubbling and problems are rising to the surface, with more business, creditors and iniduals turning to restructuring and insolvency professionals.Mr Cooper said some firms had been stockpiling materials in response to the uncertainty around how, when, and under what terms the UK will leave the European Union, adding to pressure on cash flow. Many investment decisions have been deferred.He noted that consumer confidence in Scotland had been firmly in negative territory all last year, during which the number of personal insolvencies increased by %, to ,, from , in .ldquoCompanies which are counting on consumer spending to at least match previous levels may well find themselves counting the costs of this approach, cautioned Mr Cooper.He added: ldquoIn the North East, the oil and gas sector downturn has had a noticeable lsquodomino effectrsquo, triggering insolvencies for businesses which rely on the extraction sector, especially in the hospitality sector.While the partial recovery in the crude price since late  has provided a boost for the oil and gas industry the impact of the downturn from  to  is still being felt.Earlier this month the Highland Hotel in Aberdeen closed with the loss of  jobs. Brian Milne, a restructuring partner with French Duncan said then that the business had been having problems for some time due to the downturn in the oil industry in the Granite City, which it was heavily dependent upon.The White Horse Inn, at Balmedie, north of Aberdeen went into administration last week.
