title: mackie s offers sweet take on burns night scran
story: Back by popular demand, Mackies of Scotland is relaunching its limited edition haggis and marmalade ice cream for Burns Night.The handcrafted speciality recipe – which has been made on the firms Westertown family farm – is available all weekend at Mackie’s . parlour in Aberdeen.The Burns Night treat will be available all weekendAt am this morning, piper Robert Reid from Deeside Caledonia Pipe Band piped the haggis ice cream in to the Marischal Square parlour.The ice cream has been made with Scotland’s famous Hall’s haggis, and has orange marmalade swirled through the mix.In celebration of Scotland’s Ploughman Poet, customers at . will be given free samples of the experimental dessert – and those who play a tune on the bagpipes will be able to enjoy any free scoop of their choice.Yvette Harrison, Parlour Manager at Mackie’s ., said: “While Marmalade is not a traditional accompaniment for Haggis – we added a ripple to help make this Scottish delicacy a little tastier when served cold in ice cream. And, of course a nip of whisky can also be drizzled over the top to raise a cone to the Bard.“Our haggis ice cream was such a hit last year that we just had to bring it back for Burns Night . Since last year’s limited edition batch, we’ve had people visit the parlour specically to try the flavour. So this weekend is the perfect opportunity for those who didn’t get the chance the first time round to satisfy their curiosity – and their taste buds.”Mackie’s is encouraging the public to share their thoughts on the creation with the hashtag #taemackiesicecream.Yvette added: “We love experimenting with our flavours at Mackie’s, and in celebration of Burns we’re challenging everyone to step outside their comfort zone, and try a scoop of our latest creation."data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Brian McKandie"  Pensioners injuries were "worst" Detective had ever seenviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Singer, radio and television presenter Aled Jones MBE will perform a live set at the event"  Charity to mark th anniversary with celebratory Ball viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: north east dog unit celebrates 60th anniversary
story: The North East Dog Unit in Aberdeen has celebrated its th anniversary by bringing together its latest recruits and the unit#s first ever handler.PC Sandy Reid and his dog PD Rennie were the founding members of the police dog unit in Aberdeen, and were first deployed in .Mr Reid, , visited the Dog Unit todayto gt Rennie’s original collar and name tag, and met with current members of the dog unit including recent recruits PC Laura Fairbairn and PD Ava to mark this signicant milestone.Sandy joined Aberdeen City Police in  when he was  years old. He worked ‘On the Beat’ for a few years and was then asked to set up the first dog unit in the area. He and Rennie were the sole members of the unit to start with but Sandy gradually built up a team of handlers and dogs.After setting up the dog unit Sandy went on to set up the Underwater Diving Unit for the Force and also the Specialist Policing Unit based at Aberdeen Airport. Sandy retired as a Sergeant in Bucksburn in .Speaking about the celebration Instructor PC Steve Warden said: “We are delighted to have Sandy back in the unit today to help us celebrate  years of the North East Dog Unit. Since founding the unit, there have been hundreds of dogs and handlers who have all worked hard to help keep people safe here in the North East. We are a very special unit and we assist operational colleagues on all manner of calls from locating missing people, searching for items such as weapons, evidence and drugs and helping control volatile or aggressive situations. “Despite the many changes in policing in the North East over the last  years, it is great that the dog unit has remained and developed. We have a very strong team with a mix of experience but with the same dedication to the unit and the job. We hope that the North East Dog Unit enjoys many more decades of work.” As part of the celebration, Mr Reid has donated Rennie’s original collar and dog tag which is engraved stating that Rennie was owned by the Chief Constable of Aberdeen City Police and has been framed as a lasting memento.Retired officer, Sandy Reid added: “I have kept in touch with the Unit since I retired more than  years ago and it was great to celebrate this milestone with them today. The current dog handlers face much of the same challenges I did. It is a ied and exciting job to have but the most special element is the unique bond which develops from working and training with your dog.”PC Laura Fairbairn has been a police officer for  years and recently completed her dog handler training at the Scottish Police Dog Training Centre. PD Ava is a two year old German Shepherd who was bred in the Czech Republic and sourced by the national dog unit last summer. Ava and Laura were paired up during Laura’s initial training and have been putting into practice what they have learned during their training.Speaking about her new role PC Fairbairn said: “I’m really pleased and excited to be part of the dog unit. It’s a unique team and very dferent to the roles I’ve held within the police so far. Ava and I are getting on great. She’s a really good dog and we’ve bonded really well. She’s a general purpose dog so we get called to tracking and tracing calls at the moment."Once we’ve developed our experience and expertise I’ll take on a second specialist dog such as a drugs or explosives dog. At the moment I’m just enjoying getting used to working in the unit and looking after and working with Ava."data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"BEAR Scotland"  Overnight resurfacing work to start on A viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: top quality entries set to take part in the royal northern spring show
story: Entries are up on the year for next month#s annual multi-breed show and sale of pedigree bulls staged alongside the Royal Northern Spring Show at Thainstone.The sale, to be held on Wednesday, February , has attracted  entries from breeders across the north and north-east, and will include Aberdeen-Angus, Charolais, Limousins, Simmentals, Salers, Herefords, Beef Shorthorns and one British Blue.Last year’s sale saw a top price and a new centre record of ,gns paid for a Simmental bull from the MacPherson family at Blackford, Croy. This was Blackford Hero, by the ,gns Kilbride Farm Double Action, which sold across the water to a breeder in Northern Ireland. The MacPhersons have entered two Simmental bulls for next month’s sale, one of which was bought as a calf at foot from the Deerhurst dispersal and is by the ,gns Blackford Findhorn. The other bull from Blackford is one of the first sons of Blackford Galaxy.At the same sale last year, Charolais bulls produced the second lead price of gns for one from Charles McCombie and family of Auchincrieve, Rothiemay, near Huntly. The same home has entered three Charolais bulls this year, as well as one Aberdeen-Angus bull.Top price in the Aberdeen-Angus section at ’s sale was gns paid for a bull from father and son team, Neil and Mark Wattie, Mains of Tonley, near Alford. Tonley has entered three Aberdeen-Angus bulls for this year’s sale.Among the Limousins last year, the overall champion in the pre-sale show from Harry and Lynwen Emslie, Kinknockie, Mintlaw, topped at gns. Reserve was another Limousin from Andrew Gammie, Drumforber, Laurencekirk, which made gns. In all, this year’s bull entries stand at  Aberdeen-Angus,  Charolais,  Limousins,  Simmentals, eight Salers, two Herefords, two Beef Shorthorns and one British Blue. Two pedigree Limousin females have also been entered for the sale. John Angus, Head of Livestock for Aberdeen and Northern Marts, said: “We have a strong entry of quality bulls forward again this year and prices paid in the past for bulls demonstrates the standard of stock brought forward."This sale is a great opportunity for breeders to acquire top class bulls from established breeders in the area.”data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Singer, radio and television presenter Aled Jones MBE will perform a live set at the event"  Charity to mark th anniversary with celebratory BallviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Performance and Events Development Coordinator Carla Angus with instigator and leader of the exhibition Stuart Noble and one of the giant whales on display"  Wonderous Whales and Sails at museum viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"

title: women urged to go for smear after uptake reaches all time low
story: A north east MSP is encouraging women to go for their smear test to help reduce their risk of cervical cancer after it was revealed uptake is at an all time low.It comes as the charity Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust aims to raise awareness during Cervical Cancer Prevention Week.More than , women are diagnosed with cervical cancer every year in the UK.Cervical screeningare the best protection against the disease, followed by the HPV vaccine offered in schools.Figures have revealed that last year, cervical screening uptake in Scotland fell from .% to .% meaning that more than one in four eligible women missed their screen test.This week Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust has published new research which has found young women who delay or don’t go for cervical screening feel scared , vulnerableand embarrassedat the thought of going.A worrying two thirdssay they would not feel in control at the prospect of a test.Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin said: “I am delighted to be working with Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust this Cervical Cancer Prevention Week.“Cervical screening prevents up to % of cervical cancers developing, so it is worrying to hear that so many women are not attending this test when invited, particularly due to embarrassment.“It’s a small test which can make a huge dference so I would urge women to encourage daughters, nieces, other family and friends who are eligible for the test to do so.”Robert Music, Chief Executive of Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust said: “We are delighted to have Gillian Martin’s support to help raise awareness about the importance of cervical screening.Smear tests provide the best protection against cervical cancer yet we know they aren’t always easy.“We want women to feel comfortable talking to their nurse and asking questions. It’s not making a fuss and there are many ways to make the test easier. Please don’t let your fears stop you booking a test.” data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Mackies . staff Craig Marsden, Bonaria Fanara, Yvette Harrison, Zuzanna Gliwinska and Fiona Gillick"  Ice cream parlour to ‘Go Orange’ for charityviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt""  Two taken to hospital after crash viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: workshop to develop artwork ideas for new kintore rail station
story: A day of workshops to develop ideas for potential future artwork at the new Kintore Rail Station will take place on Saturday .People living in the town and surrounding communities are invited to take part in the event, which will run from .am to .pm in Kintore Church Hall.Anyone who wants to be involved, but without taking part in the workshop sessions, is welcome to simply drop-in throughout the day.Studio Niro, a multidisciplinary design practice, is organising the event in collaboration with Aberdeenshire Council. The workshops will involve colour mixing and print making to create a library of Kintore colours and shapes which will then be used to develop artwork.The sessions will take place from .am-pm and from -.pm and members of the community are asked to bring along a camera and any old photos of Kintore they may have. Free tickets can be booked at www.krsartwork.eventbrite or by calling   . The new railway station is part of the wider Aberdeen to Inverness Improvement Project .A representative from Network Rail will be available during the day to provide information on the project and forthcoming related works in .The workshops also provide the opportunity to re-unite for the first time in at least fty years two benches installed at the original Kintore Station, which was closed in the late s.Prior to their restoration, both benches will be on display for members of public to see. title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeTuesday  Jan  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Tuesday  Jan  : AM

title: oic makes urgent call for ferry funding
story: Orkney Islands Council is again calling on the Scottish Government to honour a commitment to provide fully fair funding for the county’s inter-island ferry service — or it will hand the service back to the government to run.The council is warning it cannot afford to run the service during the year ahead unless the government covers the full cost involved — this amounts to £. million. OIC Leader James Stockan has notied Ministers that the council will hand over responsibility for running the service to Transport Scotland, unless sufficient funding is provided.A year ago, a similar level of support was secured, after a y campaign by OIC for fair funding. Of this, £. million was allocated to fully fund Orkney’s internal ferry service during the current financial year, with £ million awarded to Shetland Islands Council for its ferry operations.“But this time there is no specic amount allocated to Orkney or Shetland. The government recognises that it will cost £. million to operate our ageing fleet of ferries during - — and that is what we are asking the government to provide.”OIC is also looking to the government to fund the replacement of the current inter-island fleet. The council has been working with the government on this for a number of years and is currently developing a business case setting out the service levels local communities require, and the engineering options needed to achieve these.Councillor Stockan added: “We would object in the strongest possible termswe end up with a reduction in our ferries funding. This would place a wholly disproportionate and unfair burden on the smallest council in Scotland and would mean us having to make cuts to other vital services.“The ferries are a leline for remote and fragile communities across our islands. Orkney has the oldest fleet and the highest fares in the country — an inequality we cannot address without proper financial support from the Scottish Government.We are calling on the government to take an honourable approach to fulfilling the will of the Scottish Parliament that we should receive fair and equitable funding for our inter-island ferry service. The principle of transferring Orkney’s internal ferry service to the Scottish Government, at no net detriment to OIC, has already been approved by the council. That is a route we will have to take unless we are provided with the funds to run the service over the year ahead.”For the full story, pick up a copy of The Orcadian, this Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Bid to get folk behind Dingwall improvement project
story: BUSINESSES keen to help regenerate Ross-shirersquos county town are being asked to show their support by getting surveys paving the way for a new development project lodged within days.The Dingwall Means Business group is behind plans for a business improvement districtwhich could mirror the success of a similar scheme in Inverness.BID manager George Murray said the group was now ldquowell into its year of listening and talking to all businesses in and around Dingwall to promote a lsquoyesrsquo for BID for the town.He said: ldquoNearly  surveys have gone out and we are still looking for a few more to be ed. The success of the Dingwall BID depends upon our local businessesrsquo support.ldquoWe are working hard to gather information from all the businesses in Dingwall and we need to hear from everyone. This is your chance to have your say and add to the overall business plan. Then all you have to do is vote yes in the ballot and we can make these projects happen.ldquoWe really want to make sure that nobody is missed and that everyone gets their opportunity to vote because this could be a monumental time in our townrsquos history. This could become the year when Dingwall businesses take control over the townrsquos economic future.Mr Murray said: ldquoWe are aware that there must be a decenton their investment. I believe Highland Council currently collect a wee bit more than pound million per annum from non-domestic ratepayers and Irsquove calculated that the levy would need to be between . to three per cent.ldquoThis would allow us to invoice the council for approximately pound,. Itrsquos also possible we would be able to almost match fund this figure from other sources. This would be an amazing amount banked in Dingwall to be spent on Dingwall. This is how we would fund the five-year plan ready to start after a yes vote.He wants remaining surveys, seeking feedback from businesses to a number of questions, ed by Friday, February .Survey results will then be collated with a five-year business plan set to be drafted by the end of March. A yes no vote on BID would then be held in May.Gordon McIntosh, practice manager of Munro  Noble, is a director of BID Inverness and believes the scheme can pay idends for Dingwall too.He said ldquocoach ambassadors had brought more tourists into the city, increasing spend. It meant local businesses were stakeholders in any centre development plans and have the ability to lobby the council over issues of interest. The scheme also paved the way for successful events such as classic car shows, Easter egg hunts and bar and business awards.He said: ldquoWith representatives from a cross section of businesses on the board the strong advocacy we have provided has achieved some notable results. These results have been for the betterment of our business and social community. A healthier, connected community drives profit opportunities.Tuesday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Blind Strathpeffer mum set to see her first book published
story: A STRATHPEFFER mum struck blind by diabetes has written a childrenrsquos book after being snapped up by a London publisher.Emily Grayrsquos paperback, Priscilla the Pig, was inspired by her mother Heatherrsquos childhood stories at Woodlands Farm in Dingwall.The -year-old University of Highlands and Islands literature student lost her sight after being diagnosed with Type  diabetes. ldquoIt came as a shock because there was no family history of diabetes, she said.Ultimately she could no longer walk around without help ndash a massive shock to the system.Forced to drop her music studies degree course at Edinburghrsquos Napier University, she admitted the experience was ldquohorric.Getting help from Sight Action ldquowas a massive help. Guide dog April came into her le and the following year she gave birth to her first child, Harris.During pregnancy she mused over her own childhood settled into writing her first story using a voiceover computer programme. Itrsquos illustrated by self-taught Nairn artist Sarah Jane Cumberford.The full-time mum has a lot on her plate and now relies on her main sense of hearing.She said: ldquoLuckily Irsquove got a very noisy little boy. Itrsquos easy to keep track of him. I can generally tellhersquos getting up to no good.A former pupil of Strathpeffer Primary and Dingwall Academy, she said: ldquoIrsquom on a mission to show people that itrsquos not the end of the world and you can still achieve anything you want. ldquoEmilyrsquos book is published by Olympia Publisherson Thursday under her pen name, Madeline Rose.Tuesday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Business masterclass aims to put Highland entrepreneurs ahead
story: ENTREPRENEURS will learn how to create and sustain a competitive advantage at an event in Inverness next month.Professor Eleanor Shaw, executive director of the Hunter Centre for Entrepreneurship and vice dean of Strathclyde Business School, will deliver a masterclass on February  and  at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness.The event, which includes a networking dinner, is organised by Highlands and Islands Enterpriseas part of its entrepreneurship programme.Prof Shaw said: ldquoBy creating a competitive advantage, businesses can set a buffer between them and their competitors in turn creating a more secure place in the market.ldquoThe way in which we approach executive education at the University of Strathclyde is dferent ndash we put the focus on the participant in the room, looking at their needs and providing access to toolkits and learning so after the masterclass they can start working with colleagues and honing their value proposition straight away.ldquoEverything we do has been road tested by working with entrepreneurs and wersquove learned that creating a competitive advantage can help a business in many ways.ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to working with Highlands and Islands entrepreneurs, sharing our learnings and making new connections in the region.Louise MacDonald, senior entrepreneurship manager at HIE, said: ldquoCreating and sustaining a competitive advantage can be dficult in todayrsquos ever-changing and dynamic environment.ldquoBusinesses need to think strategically and be able to analyse their proposition to find ways to enhance impact, value and performance.ldquoThe masterclass will teach entrepreneurs from across the region the tools and techniques to stay ahead of the game.For more information, email entrepreneurship@hient or visit www.hie masterclassesTuesday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Conon Bridge school travel plan set for an upgrade
story: PARENTS of children in a village that has witnessed a surge in housebuilding are being asked to have their say on a new school travel plan.The appeal centres on Ben Wyvis Primary in Conon Bridge. A survey has been issued seeking information on issues such as what factors influence parentsrsquo decisions on whether to let their children walk or cycle to school and how much they value safer crossings, vehicle speed-reduction measures and improved road safety education as well as information on the benefits of walking and cycling.The survey includes questions about the distance pupils attending Ben Wyvis Primary live from the school and the modes of transport they use to get there.It also seeks views on measures that could reduce congestion at the school gate. These include involvement in voluntary cycle training and a car sharing scheme.Itrsquos part of a wider effort across the Highlands to work on safer routes to school, reduce unnecessary car use and encourage healthier alternatives where possible, such as walking and cycling.The survey, supported by the parent council, can be found online and completed at www.surveymonkey r BenWyvisPSTuesday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross filmmaker turned author gets to art of matter in new novel
story: Tain-based Mike Herd had plenty of time to ponder plots when he worked as a cameraman on more than  films, many requiring endless patience to capture unforgettable footage.His latest novel, The Medusa Shield, is a ldquomystical fantasy set in the fictitious village of Rockburn on the eastern seaboard of the Black Isle. Set in , it sees protagonist Scott and his father James take the car ferry across the Beauly Firth to Inverness as they watch men working on the Kessock Bridge.Scott agrees to attend a farm roup with his father and feels he is being watched by a yellow eye from a dirty painting hanging amongst the lots. Unknown to his father, he successfully bids for it and his le starts to alter in remarkable ways.The action swings between Aberdeen and Florence as Scott embarks on a journey of discovery.Mr Herd, who describes himself as ldquo going on , said time spent alone working on so many films served him.He said: ldquoBy the nature of film work there wasnrsquot a typical day because all trips y. The most memorable film that I have worked on must be Swamp Tigers in the Bangladeshi Sundarbans.ldquoUsing a converted river ferry boat as a mobile base, a typical day would be, rising at four and travelling in the dark to a hide built on stilts embedded in a channel.ldquoI would stay there on my own usually for twelve hours and I did that for months. Being in a hide that long gives you plenty of time to think.ldquoLying awake in bed in the morning, plot ideas and characters nag at me and I have to get up to write about them.ldquoI am a hopeless two-fingered typist which is very frustrating because they canrsquot keep up with whatrsquos going through my head. That aside It does surprise me how easy it is for me to write, I donrsquot know where that comes from. I try to write at least a thousand words a day but quite often Irsquoll hit a brick wall.ldquoI donrsquot worry about that because I know that I will get the inspiration to carry on later.ldquoI try to write about what I know, itrsquos much more convincing and I use locations Irsquove been to. For example, in The Medusa Shield, Scott goes full moon night fishing off the Black Isle coast in a Zulu boat. While I was in India the fishermen on the east coast do that every month.The Medusa Shield is available from Amazon Kindle, Kobo and other digital publishers.Tuesday  Jan  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. story: COUPLES looking to tie the knot amidst naturersquos splendour will soon have a quirky new wedding venue to consider thanks to a major feat of engineering currently taking place within an Easter Ross woodland.The building currently under construction in Mags Wood near Evanton will also provide an ideal location for yoga sessions for those keen to get back to nature as well as ceilidhs and other community celebrations.Being carried out under the auspices of Evanton Community Woods, the building project may well result in the UKrsquos biggest freestanding reciprocal roofed structure, a simple, strong self-supporting technique perfect for round buildings.Simon Harry, education co-ordinator at Evanton Community Woods, explained how he had been aware of the need for another building within the woodland to provide the many groups already visiting the area more space within which to carry out their activities.He said: ldquoWe aim to run workshops such as green woodworking and outdoor learning from the space along as well as offering it to local groups such as guides and scouts to use for overnight expeditions.ldquoWe have also held a number of weddings in the woods and this would be a perfect location once completed.ldquoThe main driver for the project is that we are also training folk in the unique skills of log building, to share the skills. We have worked with local volunteers, school groups, young offenders, dementia groups, local walking groups and adult learners.In tune with the sustainable development ethos of the group, logs for Mags Wood build have been sourced locally and dragged to the site by Tarzan, a French-bred horse trained for forestry operations ndash and something of a visitor attraction in himself, hugely popular with the school groups who visit the site from time to time.The building project has been able to call on the expertise of local log building expert Henry Fosbrooke, project co-ordinator David Smith and a local volunteer, Don Fraser, who previously worked on the new Queensferry next to the Forth Road Bridge.Mr Harry said that such expertise ldquohas meant that all the measurements done are near perfect.The project has been funded by the Forestry Commission through a community grant amongst ious other sources.Mr Harry said: ldquoThis will be something special for the area and is involving many iniduals and groups in its building ndash truly a community project and something that will last a very, very long time.He is still hoping to find a supplier willing to help with the timber roof cladding required to complete the project, hopefully by the end of March. title: Life saving Ross shire Womens Aid centre issues action plan after mixed report
story: The Dingwall-based Ross-shire Womenrsquos Aid centre has received a mixed inspection report from the Care Commission watchdog.While the quality of care and support provided to abused women and their children was judged good, the quality of management and leadership was rated ldquoadequate.One woman told inspectors that the service was a le-saver and she wished it would receive more funding.However there were times when staff felt inadequately supported by management, said the report following the unannounced inspection. title: something has to give if brexit is going to be delivered brian monteith
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Yvette Cooper#s amendment will not make an agreement on the backstop any more likely, writes Brian Monteith Another week and another Westminster clfhanger. This time it is whether or not the government’s motion on its Plan B for Brexit, up for discussion tomorrow, will be successfully altered by an amendment lodged by Labour Remainer Yvette Cooper. If passed the effect will be to give Parliament the power to bring forward a proposal to extend Article  for possibly three months – even until the end of this year.Whatever the outcome, the fact is thatthe UK is to leave the EU with a transitional arrangement then something needs to give for Theresa May’s Withdrawal Agreement to become acceptable or it will not be passed. With Parliament having invoked Article  of the Lisbon Treaty and passed the Withdrawal Act the existing law is simple. If there is no alternative procedure made law then the United Kingdom leaves at pm on  March and immediately becomes a sovereign country again, trading under World Trade Organisation rules rather than EU regulations on a supposed temporary basis.Last week was notable for a number of statements from all sides seeking to find agreement that might deliver the referendum result – even before Her Majesty suggested the importance of establishing common ground. First Brexiteers such as Jacob Rees-Mogg, Iain Duncan Smith and Boris Johnson, who have been appealing for the Prime Minister and her Cabinet to stick to past commitments, indicated they could be willing to support her Withdrawal Agreementshe can get the EU to time-limit or even delete the ‘backstop’. Given there is a great deal more wrong with the Prime Minister’s proposal than just the backstop this was a generous concession. Their real concern is that without finding some consensus Brexit will never happen. Yet, as the Irish Deputy Prime Minister, Simon Coveney, demonstrated on the Andrew Marr Show yesterday, a compromise on the backstop will not come from the Irish Republic. To win such a prize would therefore require the EU having to hang out Ireland – either by agreeing to previously dismissed technical solutions it has insisted are unworkable or by moving the ‘border’ to the continental mainland such as the ports of Calais and Zeebrugge . Irish politicians have every right to be worried about being hung out to dry following statements from the EU’s chief spokesman Margaritis Schinas and then its chief negotiator Michel Barnier. Schinas caught the Irish by surprise and set hares running by stating at a media briefing there would indeed be a “hard border” between the Republic and the UKno transition arrangement could be agreed. This was completely at odds with what EU Commission President Jean Claude Junker had said when last visiting Dublin. Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar was then reported as suggesting a risk that the EU might choose to locate border checks away from the Irish border and to the French and Dutch ports, thus treating the UK and Ireland as a single block. For those believing it could never happen the example of Ireland and the UK being outside the Schengen Area and therefore sharing joint security and passport checks provides a dose of reality.Varadkar was not finished, for when pressed on the border issue later in Davos he claimed Irish police or even the army would have to man any hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic. If the comment was designed to panic the UK government into concessions it was a misjudgment for the response was, as it has consistently been, that the UK would not install or operate any physical border infrastructure or controls. It is only the EU and Irish politicians who are now talking about physical infrastructure. What they misunderstandis not that Brexit-supporting Unionists say there will be no border, they say there is indeed a border already for many thingsbut it is essentially invisible and should remain so.If the UK ends up trading under WTO rules, using the past experience and already existing technology means we shall be able to work invisibly for trade, even including animals and foodstuffs, by managing any checks before and after the border – just as already happens in other parts of Europe. That Varadkar, Coveney, Barnier – and British politicians who support remain – cannot admit to recognising solutions exist, when an endless number of papers and articles have been produced showing how an invisible trade border can work, suggests they either choose to remain ignorant or are intentionally mendacious.What is also missed is that existing EU regulations are not impervious to fraud and deceit and cannot be bettered. Such arrogance and complacency was exposed as dangerously naïve during the  Irish horsemeat scandal, when some Irish-made burgers were found to have up to  per cent horsemeat in them when labelled as pure beef.The problem with Cooper’s amendment remains that delaying the departure date for Brexit will not in itself make arriving at an agreement on the border or other obstacles any more likely. MPs shall simply be taking the pressure off both themselves and the EU and end up with nothing much happening for the next three months – ing to a flurry of brinkmanship and suggested compromises as the clock ticks down again to pm on say,  June or even the end of December. We thus have two paradoxes. The first is how the backstop insisted upon by EU and Irish politicians to avoid an imagined hard border is now proving to be the most likely cause of the UK leaving the EU without a transition agreement – so a hard border is delivered. The second is that the approach of the last few days and hours of time left for negotiation – before the UK concedes there will be no agreement and WTO trading rules must be put in place as the expected outcome – is what is resulting in a drive by all parties to find a solution. Take the imperative of the clock ticking down removes the pressure to find a solution.Yvette Cooper’s amendment needs to be rejected and the focus of politicians on all sides shouldto improving the Withdrawal Agreement so that it becomes acceptable to all parties – or acknowledging it will indeed be a very bad deal the UK cannot work with and instead move to improve the circumstances for leaving the EU without a transition agreement.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: block london tube to secure indyref2 suggests former snp mp
story: A rush hour blockade of London Underground stations could be staged as part of a "civil disobedience" campaign to push for a second independence referendum, a former SNP MP has said.George Kerevan, the former East Lothian MP, even says Holyrood could be declare itself a "sovereign assembly"another independence majority is secured,in a blog for the Bella Caledonia website.Westminster has control over the constitution in the UK and Theresa May has already rejected calls for Nicola Sturgeons calls for a section  order to hold a fresh vote on the leaving the UK in light of Brexit. "It is certain – in the current Brexit crisis – that the Tory government in London will refuse to agree a fresh referendum and veto a new Section  Order," he states."This refusal must be met by a phased escalation of public civil disobedience and Westminster parliamentary obstruction by SNP MPs. The SNP government at Holyrood should rally public support by challenging Treasury control over the Scottish budget e.g. by breaking Treasury spending rules to subvert the welfare cap.": What’s gone wrong at the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow Nicola Sturgeon has pledged to set out her timetable for a second referendum in the coming weeks. title: brexit uk and eu on collision course over irish border ahead of crucial vote
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Brussels and the UK are again on a collision course over the Irish border after Theresa May called on her MPs to support a demand to change her own Brexit deal.The Prime Minister said the government will support an amendment set to be voted on tomorrow that calls for the controversial Irish border ‘backstop’ provision to replaced with “alternative measures”.With the EU insisting that the withdrawal agreement cannot be changed, it sets Mrs May up for a decisive final clash with Brussels to avoid a no-deal Brexit.But the Prime Minister bid to save her deal could be undermined by Brexiteers in her own party, who warned they would not vote for the backstop amendment, claiming it was too vague.MPs will vote tomorrow on backbench proposals for a Brexit ‘Plan B’, including an amendment supported by the chairman of powerful Tory  Committee, Sir Graham Brady.After the Prime Minister took questions at a meeting of Tory MPs on Monday evening, party chairman Brandon Lewis said a majority vote in favour of the Brady amendment would “give a very clear message” to Brussels that the backstop - which will keep the UK tied to EU regulationsa trade deal has not been agreed by the end of  - must be changed.Earlier, Downing Street said the Prime Minister was “absolutely committed” to leaving the EU with a deal on  March, but added: “Clearlywe are to obtain parliamentary support for that deal some changes are going to have to be made.”: Vote on Brexit ‘plan Bs’ could lead to deeper deadlock - Paris GourtsoyannisBut European Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas told reporters in Brussels that the Withdrawal Agreement was “endorsed by leaders and is not open for renegotiation”.Commission vice-president Jyrki Kateinen said it would be “a stupid thing” for the EU to make concessions putting the remaining  members at a disadvantage simply to secure a deal.Mr Kateinen said there was “no reason to give any concessions” to the UK and there was “not much room for manoeuvre” on the backstop.Chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier’s deputy Sabine Weyand said it was “quite a challenge” to see how a majority in support of a deal could be constructed in Westminster, warning there was a high risk of the UK crashing out by accident.: EU nationals in Scotland face ‘unacceptable’ hurdles when applying for residencyMs Weyand told a Brussels conference that negotiation on the Withdrawal Agreement was “finished”.Dismissing calls for changes to the backstop as “like Groundhog Day”, she insisted the EU were unanimous in opposing any time limit.Downing Street confirmed the Prime Minister will take her plan back to the Commons for a second “meaningful vote” as soon as possible after Tuesday’s debate, whether or not she secures more concessions from Brussels.Following two more days of debate in the Commons, a second vote on the deal is likely to take place on  February - six weeks before the UK leaves the EU.Mr Brady said his amendment would give Mrs May “enormous firepower”it is passed.The DUP - which props up the government - is still to reveal how it will vote on the amendment, but yesterday backed the Prime Minister in trying to “face down the stubbornness of Dublin and Brussels”.There are also doubts over whether the Brady amendment will win the support of Tory Eurosceptic rebels in the European Research Group .Senior Brexiteer Sir Bernard Jenkin said it was “deliberately vague because it’s meant to mean dferent things to dferent people”, while former Conservative leader Iain Duncan Smith was reported to have called on Mrs May to table her own amendment to provide greater “clarity and purpose”.ERG chairman Jacob Rees-Mogg said the amendment was “just an expression of opinion” and warned there was “no appetite in ERG to support it as a stand-alone motion”.In Monday’s meeting, Mrs May was cheered after being questioned by Boris Johnson, who asked how the Brady amendment would bring about meaningful change to the Brexit deal.“She basically said, we won’t know unless you support us Boris,” Tory MP Simon Hart said.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: eu nationals in scotland face unacceptable hurdles when applying for residency
story: EU nationals living in Scotland face #unacceptable# hurdles when applying for settled status in the UK post-Brexit, politicians and campaigners have warned.Under current UK Government plans some . million people who hold passports for other EU nations, and have lived continuously in the UK for five years or more, can apply for “settled status” to remain in the country beyond .But the registration scheme has faced criticism after it was reported the first step of the application process involves downloading an app to confirm an inidual’s passport details compatible only with Android smartphones. Those who have an iPhone or other device, or are unable to use the internet, must visit one of  centres around the UK to have documents scanned in person. Only one centre - in Edinburgh - is planned for Scotland.There are around , EU nationals living north of the Border. : Vote on Brexit ‘plan Bs’ could lead to deeper deadlockA spokesman for The  Million, a grassroots organisation which campaigns for the rights of EU citizens in the UK, said it was unfair to expect those living in rural Scottish communities to travel to Edinburghthey required help with the application process.“Scotland has many isolated communities and EU citizens living there will require support locally, especially those who may be elderly or disabled and are unable to use the internet,” they said.SNP immigration spokesman Stuart McDonald MP said: “It is absolutely ridiculous – and completely unacceptable –that there is only one centre in Scotland for EU nationals to attend for person-to person assistance to scan ID documents.“During this period of uncertainty brought on by the Tory government’s Brexit mishandling, EU nationals should not be expected to face this application process without the ability to discuss any issues in person. The UK Government must revisit this as a matter of urgency.“For many, these arrangements could mean travelling hundreds of miles for one-on-one support.“The Scottish Government have taken practical action to assure EU nationals during this time, offering advice and support across Scotland as well as delivering a funded EU Citizens’ Rights Project which will deliver information meetings across Scotland.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: st andrews student cracks code for divinity documents not read for 200 years
story: Coded religious documents have been read for the first time in centuries after a inity student cracked the code.Baptist leader Andrew Fullerleft hundreds of pages of shorthand notes which have baffled academics for centuries.The University of St Andrews said third-year inity undergraduate Jonny Woods has now become the first person in the world to read some of the pages after using a longhand version as a kind of Rosetta stone.Fuller, the son of a poor tenant farmer in Cambridgeshire, became a leader of the British Baptist denomination and, despite minimal schooling, published a hugely influential text, The Gospel Worthy of All Acceptation, which is said to have changed the history of the Baptists.Mr Woods, from Coleraine, Co Londonderry, said it was exciting to crack the code enabling people to read documents Fuller left in shorthand.The -year-old said: “To be able to read something that no-one  has read in more than  years, it’s not something I thought I would ever be able to do and it was an incredible moment. It was quite a few weeks of tough and not very successful work, but eventually it paid off.”He added: “It is such an honour to be the first person to read Andrew Fuller’s sermons and to allow people to get an insight into this incredible man and the amazing stories he has to share.“I’m excited to continue working on the vast collection of work that he has left to us, in the hope that we can understand more about his thinking and how this developed throughout his ministry.”The breakthrough came after Dr Steve Holmes, head of the School of Divinity at the university, found a shorthand document with the heading in longhand in the archive of Bristol Baptist College, which holds hundreds of pages of Fuller’s sermons. Dr Holmes found one headed in longhand “Confessions of Faith, Oct.  ” with the rest of the document in shorthand.Knowing this was the date of Fuller’s induction into the pastorate of a church in Kettering and that he would have been required to give a confession of faith, Dr Holmes wondereda copy of the confession printed in a biography might help him.After discovering the two texts were the same, Dr Holmes recruited Mr Woods through the university’s undergraduate research assistant scheme to help.After a few weeks, the student was able to translate the shorthand using the longhand version as a kind of Rosetta stone, allowing him to read two of the most historically signicant sermons from the collection.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: minister hears plea for debts to be written off
story: Locum costs, hospital bed closures because of staffing shortages and staff retention were among the issues discussed at NHS Shetland#s annual review meeting.The Scottish government#s mental health minister Clare Haughey was attending the meeting, which was held on Monday afternoon.It came after NHS Shetland was forced to close six beds at the Gilbert Bain Hospital because of a recruitment shortfall.Director of nursing Kathleen Carolan said she hoped to have the shortage addressed within three months.Ms Haughey#s visit came after the crippling costs of travel and accommodation connected to locum medical cover was highlighted late last year.During the meeting she was challenged by Shetland integration joint board vice-chairman Allison Duncan.He warned that Shetland had spent £ million on locum cover over  months.#We already know that other local authorities like Dundee and other NHS debts are going to be written off. Even the Western Isles, at .Mbps, has speeds nearly twice as fast as Shetland.List MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston said that the report highlighted a need for government investment in Shetland#s infrastructure.The Conservative member for the Highlands and Islands said: #I am disappointed to see Shetland lagging so far behind the rest of the country in broadband speeds. Shetland is getting a poor deal and it is rightly a matter of real concern for people here in the islands and across the Highlands and Islands.#I recognise Shetland’s unique geography, but to fulfil its own commitments the Scottish government must make it a priority to investment in the islands’ infrastructure – including broadband connectivity.#Paul Wheelhouse, minister for connectivity and the islands, said: #This report highlights what we already know – that it is more challenging to deliver and upgrade broadband infrastructure in rural areas.#The Scottish government has vowed to make sure all of Scotland has access to superfast broadbandby . Mr Wheelhouse said that  per cent of homes and businesses in Scotland already have access to superfast broadband. managing director of home products and services, said: #It’s incredibly frustrating that so many Scots are still struggling to get a good broadband connection when so many of us rely heavily on the internet to carry out important everyday tasks.#The Scottish Government must now press ahead with plans to provide  per cent of the homes in Scotland with a decent broadband connection and make sure that no one is at a disadvantage because of where they live.#..
